reviews.review_text: The single player campaign of Doom has exceeded all of my expectations I initially had toward it. My expectations were that I wanted it to be a great FPS game, and more importantly, a true DOOM title. I started the game on Nightmare difficulty right off the bat.  You will be fighting in the first 10 seconds of the game. Combat is challenging and very fluid with emphasis on speed, which they've certainly cranked up. Stopping is death on nightmare. Glory kills are satisfying, can be a ammo saver, and really don't hinder game flow at all, and can even be upgraded to perform faster (or toggled off in the options).  Level design is absolutely impressive. This was my biggest concern with Doom, and rest assured id FINALLY did it right. Non-linear, lots of exploration, plenty of secrets with hidden guns, secret level unlocks, and equipment.  The monsters are relentless. On nightmare you will get your ♥♥♥ kicked. This is a fact, and there's no way to circumvent this. I honestly felt at times that I was playing Project Brutality on 'Last Man on Earth' difficulty. Monsters boast a variety of attacks, chase you down, flank you, and can be tough as nails (sometimes a little too good).  Weapons look and feel satisfying, great attention to detail. You will use guns interchangeably, each has their respective uses. You'll have to search the environment for health and ammo, aside from the chainsaw kills on enemies, they drop little items- but enough to keep you going (i.e +5 health occasionaly or like 4 shotgun shells). The BFG literally clears an entire room in one shot, and I couldn't help but smile at the results. Upgrades and progression in this game are entirely optional, but really help shift the game to fit how you play (the air control ability is the best imo).  The graphics are incredible too, although you better have a strong card if you want to play on Ultra with anti-aliasing, etc. Uncapping framerate, setting your FOV to 130, tons of options to customize.  And I have to say, Mick Gordon's soundtrack in this game is some of the best I've heard in a while. On the third level, I was literally head banging and rocking out to a soundtrack that felt like a crossbreed between Lamb of God, Celldweller, and Rage Against the Machine.  Overall, I can confidently say that this is the Doom game we've wanted. We all can breath a sigh of relief now that the main portion of the game is actually well-done. That beta we played is absolutely no indicator of how the campaign plays in the slightest, and id did it right with this one. Definitely recommend this title as a gamer, a die hard Doom fan (still play the classic to this day), and FPS fanatic.  EDIT: Since some of you do not take the time to actually explore the game's options and like to jump to conclusions, you can in fact start the game on nightmare. Ultra-nightmare is unlocked after beating the game, NOT regular nightmare. Fact.

You are Doomguy.   Doomguy has had it with these edgy shooters, convinced that they 'mean something' or discuss 'serious issues' in an effective or at the very least parodical manner. Where the modern military shooter falls flat on its face, Doomguy doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥. Doomguy doesn't like it when cutscenes waste his time. Doomguy punches the plot. Literally.  This is a brilliant game about three things: moving fast, killing demons, and metal. It does these three things so ludicrously well that it is impossible not to recommend. Plenty of thinkpieces have discussed at length why exactly this game is so good on such a purely visceral level, so I'll leave it to them to give you the details. Suffice to say, this isn't to be missed.  As a side note: the highest difficulty can be unlocked for the first playthrough with a launch command, and if you're a pretty experienced kb&m player, I would highly suggest doing so. And the MP is garbage - but don't let that dissuade you, as this would stand perfectly fine as a $60 release with only the campaign.

This is how you revamp a classic franchise.  All the gameplay features, enemies, weapons and atmosphere that made the classic so great are present here but updated to what you'd expect from a modern FPS. Besides, it has a few features that make it outstanding: - A proper multiplayer with many game modes. - A level editor to create and share levels. - Demon rooms / play as a demon (multiplayer). - Glory kills: spectacular killing animations you can perform on weakened enemies, it works so well I'm sure we'll see this feature in many future FPS.  The only downside I found is that they had planned a few DLC and a season pass worth $40 since day one, something that has become too common in recent AAA games unfortunately. You get a complete and good experience without DLCs though as they are focused on multiplayer.  All in all, I enjoyed it from start to end and had a lot of fun playing multiplayer too.

I honestly thought I was over FPS games and haven't been interested in one - save for games like Fallout 4 which I wouldn't count - but it turns out that I was entirely wrong about my disinterest in the genre as a whole. It wasn’t all FPS games that I was over but drab brown gritty military FPS games that have lost my interest. Give me a twitch arena shooter like DOOM, set in a world pulled directly from my 13 year old wet dreams, and I am a kid in a candy store once again. I can't stop grinning while playing and every other second I find myself fist pumping - seriously - and saying 'Holy ♥♥♥♥ that was AWESOME' as I dismember another demon or pass through a portal to what can only be described as a pitch perfect recreation of my childhood fever dreams.  The graphics in this game are top notch. I'm running it on a the following: i5-3570K (not currently overclocked) GTX 970 16 gigs DDR3 Ram  I have all of the settings at ultra level - with the adaptive AA enabled - and it's running at 9000+ FPS. I haven't come across a single framerate drop or visual glitch/tear and I've only experienced 2 game crashes in my 16 hour playthrough of the single player campaign. I know that there are people with AMD cards, at the time of this review, that are having troubles and my heart goes out to them. I hope that those issues are fixed soon because this is a game that should not be missed.   Graphics are beautiful and there is so much post processing going on that I've often found myself standing in awe at some of the vistas in hell wondering how there is so much smoke and particle effects going on without dropping a single frame. The lighting is perfect for setting the mood and the enemy designs and animation are top notch. Jumping up on a platform only to find an imp scramble up right behind you is a fantastic experience because you truly feel like you're being chased and running for your life. The gameplay is a breath of fresh air which is ironic since it's due to the stripped down barebones nature of the gunplay. You fun, you jump, you shoot. YOU DO NOT RELOAD. Thank god for that. This game is about speed speed speed in a way that would satisfy Sanic’s need to go fast. If you're on the PC, you NEED to be playing it on the hardest difficulty your first playthrough because this is one of those rare games – ala dark souls – that equal parts challenges you and rewards you for skill based play. You die quickly which means you need to constantly be on the move and if I find myself standing still for more than a second or two I start to wonder 'how am I not dead yet?'. More often than not, it's because you are and you are staring at the reloading screen. Deaths never feel cheap and are almost always your fault. More than once I’ve kited a ton of enemies only to find myself doubled back directly into them. Those are learning experiences that make success feel even sweeter.   The versatility in the gun upgrade mechanic is a surprising plus that I did not see coming and the game is constantly dishing out upgrades and new guns to you to keep things fresh.  The sense of pace and urgency that DOOM creates sets a new gold standard for this type of twitch based arena shooter game. I hope we see a lot of copy cat games try to recreate the style of play you see in doom. I would love to have a resurgence of titles like Painkiller et al.   The level design is great in this game too. I was afraid that we'd be running down straight corridors like every other FPS on the market going from set piece to set piece when the levels in the original DOOM game were more like puzzles intricately laid out to always give the player a sense of forward momentum with plenty of progress markers and just enough backtracking to make you feel accomplished when you get that pesky yellow key and can open up a door that was previously inaccessible.  In a way, it reminds me a bit of the levels you'll find in a Metroidvania style game with lots of areas that are inaccessible without the right item or ability (yes, you get a double jump in the game that makes platforming easier).   The game is still broken up into levels so you can never backtrack from the end of the game to the beginning but each level is a multilayered labyrinth and they did a really good job of making it feel like a proper DOOM game in terms of level design.  The sound design in DOOM expertly sets the tone for the game and evokes the same fast past mayhem of the originals soundtrack while creating a fresh contrast to the frantic guitar with quieter serene moments in between fights. I really do enjoy the voices of all of the characters since they all have a decent amount of post processing to make them seem sufficiently robotic or demonoid. When it comes to SOME of the guns, the sound design is a bit of a mess. There is a missing low end that is really needed - for people like me who game with surround sound speakers with a sub-woofer - that really adds a satisfying punch when shooting. It's not terrible, but it's heavily biased to the mid and high range and lacks a lot of the impact I was hoping for. There is one cool sound effect that I love, though: The muffled sound of the bullets coming out of the machine gun when you aim down the sights (with one of the mods) sounds like someone shredding on a guitar. It's really quite cool.  Speaking of guitar, the soundtrack to this game is epic and they do a really good job with the modular industrial-electonic-metal-choir style that perfectly ramps up from serene moments when you're exploring to head banging metal when you're knee-deep in the dead. The soundtrack perfectly accompanies the violence and mayhem on screen while setting the mood, which is almost always one of the following: “Who did I kill next?!” or “my god…I can’t believe I survived that”. It's not often that I notice the soundtrack to a game and DOOM is a game where I'm constantly grinning because the music is perfectly setting the mood and I couldn't imagine playing my own music - which I what I often do - over this game because I LOVE the dynamic shifts between quiet serene choir chants to industrial metal when you round a corner into a horde of demons. They absolutely nailed it... and it didn't even require Nine Inch Nails this time....  Bad pun..........   If you miss the days of old school twitch based shooters and you lament the current trend of boring brown drab military shooters or cover based mechanics that force you to stand still and play what amounts to a carnival shooting gallery then DOOM is right up your alley.  *Multiplayer component of the review coming soon*  Graphics: 9.5 Sound: 9 Single Player: 8.7 Multiplayer: 7.7 Value: 9 SJW (game supports toxic masculinity and lacks strong black trans female presence): 3   Final Score: 8.8 SJW Score: 7.8

Doom is a good shooter comprised of three separate parts. The campaign is an enjoyable trip down memory lane as it replicates the basic formula that was prevalent two decades ago. With good level design, potent weaponry and smoothly-animated demons, its individual action pieces are stellar. Unfortunately the arena encounter formula persists right until the end, becoming too repetitive. Multiplayer is a competent mix of old and new that brings the hell-themed action close to that of other modern shooters. Finally, SnapMap gives players a fairly powerful set of tools to make simple creations in minutes. Doom’s relentless emulation of its predecessors creates the fire that complements its modern-day brimstone.   Read full review  [www.newgamenetwork.com]

Surprisingly good, played through the whole campaign on nightmare and hunted every secret. While it isn't 100% true to the originals it still manages to remain Doom-esque in level design and enemy/weapon interactions (Preferring to use some weapons against certain enemies but not others, etc). The melee kill animations can fairly safely be ignored (Enemies drop health, but on nightmare the guaranteed health from a melee kill is negligible at 5 points, and the large health drops from kills happen if you're low on health and still happen from ranged kills too) or even smoothed into the gameplay with the rune system, which lets you speed the animations up to practically the point of the Doom 1 and 2 punch animation.  The multiplayer isn't the worst thing ever made but it isn't particularly good or noteworthy. Since you pick which weapons you start with all the weapons have been equalized for balance, there's no frantically running around the map to grab the rocket launcher when everyone can spawn with one and it does piddly damage since it has to be equivalent to everything else.  Snapmap has some cool potential, but since it's based around the MP rather than the SP there's a 2 weapon limit and the players can't pick a difficulty level, the map designer has to specifically set enemy HP, damage, etc. It also has a god-awful search system to try to find maps, so you'll have a hell of a time finding ones that look interesting. Not nearly as powerful as a full editor but some good may come of it eventually.  Overall really damn good. I still enjoyed Doom 3, but this is far closer to Doom 1 and 2 than 3 was. Not really going to be a landmark shooter still regularly played and modded 20+ years later, but what is?

This is a modern version of the classic game that started a genre. It's fast, furious, and true to it's predecessors. Graphics are great and action is lightning quick and silky smooth. There are a few additions to the original Doom, namely gear enhancements ( I wish all the weapons had iron sights, but some have telescopic sites ) but you can happily just ignore all that and do what's best with this sort of game - shoot things.  There is nothing amazingly impressive about the game. In partuicular I am sure there will be complaints about the usual dark, miserable scenery. All the maps are completely unremarkable. Weapons are pretty dull. Sound effects aren't that great. The only thing that really stands out is the movement is very fluid and the shooting fast and precise. This is going to keep the pvp folks very happy indeed. I think this game most reminds me of Quake III arena.  The game also forces you to be fast and furious too. When the monsters spawn there is often no place to hide because the game carefully locks all the doors to make sure you can't run away!!  The game is pretty short. Although there are three bosses, with the original doom there were a myriad of levels between each one, but in this version there are far fewer. I personally think that is a teeny bit of a rip-off. I can't believe that these levels took that much time to create. I love the addition of some of the old ( original ) Doom levels. They are still the best!  With the PVP element and the ability to create user levels, I think they have done their best to emulate the original games, and that's great, but I am not completely sure that there will be the dedicated playerbase that there was with the older games, for one very simle reason - no matter how the game is updated, it's still pretty much the same game, and people will tire of that fairly quickly. The simple fact is that they needed to add something extra but they haven't. Well, lets be honest here, ID have a poor record ~ their original games were out of this world, but since those heady days they have shown little or no innovation, other than technical. You would expect this game to have flawless mechanics and graphics and it does, but that's it.  That aside, it's still a terrifc, fun game to play. It may not have vast longevity, but it's certainly well worth playing. For the truly dedicated doom'er then it's a version worth their attention. If you like the original games, or you like fast paced pure FPS, then this is wholeheartedly recommended.

DOOM is the newest game in the DOOM series. If you don't know anything about DOOM, it's about a marine shooting demons to save the world from demonic invasion, eventually closing up the portal between the human's dimension and hell. I know it sounds outrageous and I was skeptical too to the gameplay when I first heard about DOOM 3 (I'm too young for the original DOOM, DOOM 64, and DOOM 2). But it turns out to be beautifully written with several plot twists and I find the story very engaging and enjoyable. Unlike most other FPS, the combat style is VERY fast-paced where you will literally have to keep moving all the time if you don't want to get burned by fireballs, lasers, or any other kind of lethal stuff thrown by the demons. I'm not a gaming god that has 2000 games in my library so there might be other games out there that has the same extremely fast-paced combat style (like Bulletstorm?) so I assume this combat style as a unique aspect. In short, DOOM is a fast-paced, story-driven FPS that offers unique combat style with a lot of gore and GREAT metal musics that accompanies you whenever you're butchering demons.  Now, I'm going to talk about the good parts of the game. First of all, it's the combat system. I.Love.It. You get to do something called 'gore kill' where you'll kill a staggered demon with an extremely cool kill (and very bloody) animation. You can do a gore kill from above, from the leg, from the hands, from the chest, etc and each of them will show you different killing styles. As I said in my introduction paragraph, the combat style is overall extremely fast-paced. I find myself sitting on the edge of the seat everytime the combat 'session' starts. Graphics quality does not need to be questioned - it's epic. I finished the game on maxed out graphic settings and it was one hell of an experience. The gameplay has a recognizable pattern - you'll start with walking around trying to find a way to get to the next area. During this 'no-demons' part, you get to explore the environment to find various collectibles items like weapon upgrades, DOOM Marine dolls, Praetor suit (your badass armor) upgrades, classic DOOM maps, etc. And then, when you found the next 'area', the demons will start spawning and there you go - the metal music intensifies as you jump around from ledge to ledge, jump over demons and gore-kill them from above, shoot stuff, blow up stuff, lasers, rockets, fire, bullets, chainsaw, blood, blood, blood, blood, more blood, MOAR blood, and boom, you'll start with trying to find a way to the next 'area' again. This pattern will repeat over and over again as you progress through the story. Each combat 'session' is extremely challenging and I found myself scavenging for health, ammo, and armor desperately as the demons throw or shoot stuff at me (or try to crush me). Each demon has their own unique combat style with unique weak spots, since ammo management is critical in this game, it's very important to only shoot them on their weak spots, which makes it more challenging. The soundtrack is also very good. I'm not a fan of metal or rock musics myself but I enjoyed listening to the soundtrack. You also don't need to worry about not being able to understand the story because you didn't play the previous games. It might be pretty confusing at the start but everything will be explained as you progress.  Now, the bad parts of the game. Just like the Wolfenstein series, it has the fps drop bug (FPS stays between 10 to 20 fps on certain levels). I know it's not a serious issue since all you have to do is just restart the game and it will be back to normal. But I find it kind of annoying, especially because I had to wait for around 5 minutes for everything to load and to be able to click Exit. I also don't really like the fact that weapon and armor upgrades are hidden in secret areas. I'm not a fan of exploring stuff or finding secret area so I still have a lot of stuff locked when I finished the game. The BFG9000 (your ultimate weapon) puzzle also lack of clues. I stood on one of the platforms for around 15 minutes trying to figure out what the hell am I supposed to do. I eventually gave up and looked for the solution at YouTube just to find out that all I had to do was shoot stuff. Navigating around the map is also troublesome for me, some areas can only be reached after doing several parkour stuff, so whenever you accidentally fall, you'll have to re-do all the parkour stuff again.   In conclusion, IMHO, DOOM is a game worth every penny. The adrenaline rush during the fast-paced combat is the highlight of the game and I love it! I heavily recommend this game for any gamers looking for a casual gory FPS that doesn't require too much thinking.

For new players, Doom offers an interesting break from the usual first-person shooter style you might be familiar with (Call of Duty, Halo 5, etc.) and instead puts a focus on in-your-face, bloody combat. You'll be close with your enemies in this game, rather than picking them off from a longer distance. And it's this close-quarters focus that really brings out the game's intensity. It's constant, fast-paced action all the way through, with only occasional breaks from the carnage.  For classic Doom veterans, this game is not too far from the norm of a Doom game. It's fast-paced, visceral and brutal. You can feel like a true badass again, destroying anything in your path, but you're never shy of a challenge. The demons will mess you up if you don't keep yourself killing. And of course, just like any true Doom game, you should always be on the move.  The campaign has a nice story to it, but it rarely forces you to pay attention to it. You spend more time killing demons, which is a great thing. Most story segments you can actually just walk away from and continue killing.  Doom also introduces some new mechanics, such as glory kills - fully animated executions performed against your enemies, each one gory and...well, glorious. You have a variety of unique guns to choose from, just like any good first-person shooter, but in singleplayer, you get to modify your weapons with upgrades, new firemodes, and the like. You can also upgrade your suit abilities in singleplayer - anything from blast resistance, to a more intricate map. Further suit upgrades can be achieved through obtaining runes - gained by completing quick challenges. These runes let you get new benefits, such as armor-for-kills or increased mobility.  The multiplayer modes are, surprisingly, a really strong point of the game. Deathmatch game modes can get hectic and crazy, especially if you bring friends along. The 'demon rune' - a powerup that lets you turn into a demon for a short amount of time - can be a real game changer, and ends up directing a lot of focus on the big guy.  There's also a level editor (SnapMap), which has it's design limits, but is still really fun and can be used very creatively. This level editor can make solo/co-op missions, wave-based survival games, bloodbath arenas...I even saw someone make a Harvest Moon-type game.  In both multiplayer and SnapMap, you're allowed to customize your weapons and armor to your liking. In multiplayer modes, things like colors, armor pieces, and extra loadout items are obtainable through an XP system. In SnapMap, though, you earn these by buying them with SnapPoints - an entirely in-game currency gained by playing and creating SnapMap levels. This system keeps you playing and creating for a good while.  Overall, Doom is an amazing game for both veterans and newcomers to the series, and has an outstanding amount of content to keep you going. I would say that id Software definitely delivered us the true return to the series everyone has been waiting for - because believe me, Doom 3 sure wasn't that.

For a long time people weren’t too confident in new Doom, mainly because of Bethesda’s horrid marketing that made it look like a ♥♥♥♥ brown and slow mess. Thankfully new Doom is nothing like this and is another addition to the great single-player FPSes of recent years alongside Doom’s sister series Wolfenstein, Shadow Warrior, and Metro: Last Light. It’s also pretty much the best Painkiller game too.  New Doom is a great blending of the old and the new just like Wolfenstein: The New Order. It has a lot of modern conveniences such as generous checkpoints but it still has some old school sensibilities in how it plays. There is no regenerating health, you got to find packs or get them off of enemies. The game gives some of the best mobility I’ve seen in an FPS, there’s no cowering behind waist high walls here. Doomguy runs by default and stuff like double jumps and ledge grabs add to this mobility even more. The levels are quite sizable and allow you to maneuver around the arenas in multiple ways. The weapons are real fun to use, especially the Super Shotgun.  Doom has a rather long campaign, if you blaze throughout it’ll probably take you around ten hours. But there’s a lot of secrets to find in the levels, including ones that unlock classic Doom levels that you can play akin to playing through Wolfenstein 3D in TNO/The Old Blood. So that can definitely extend your playtime. There’s also a level creator so you can play other people’s maps as well as make your own. There’s multiplayer, and while I haven’t touched it yet, it seems like it’s already been dead due to Bethseda’s misplaced belief that people wanted to have a multiplayer mode in a Doom game.   Doom’s writing is good in the sense that it’s unobtrusive and helps the game along. It’s not like New Order which actually had some solid writing, but the game knows people just want to rip and tear some demons so it doesn’t take itself too seriously. There’s also shoutouts to stuff from earlier games as well.  While Doom is a great game I ran into several bugs, three of which caused CTDs and the other two broke the game. (I couldn’t shoot my guns after going into a teleporter while switching my guns as well as one where the switch to activate a door didn’t appear.) It didn’t really mar the experience but it’s the only flaw it had. Also I wish Bethesda would make single-player DLC maps instead of just having the Season Pass be all multiplayer stuff.  So in the end, Doom is a damn fine game and a must play for single-player FPS fans.

I was initially very sceptical about the game. A very long and troubled development cycle, no review copies sent out before release, a multiplayer that was poorly received and did not sound or look all that exciting.  I did end up getting it anyway (a good deal on greenmangaming), I had to see what id had done to make a follow-up to what was perhaps my two most favorite games ever.  About 5 seconds after the loadscreen is gone you have a gun in your hand and are shooting zombie guys. 30 seconds later you've violently destroyed a couple more in grotesquely violent melee animations and picked up a shotgun. Shortly you're off over the surface of Mars, through a bunch of sci-fi facilities in the sort of style that Doom 3 laid out, but far more open, expansive and brightly lit. The game looks great, even on medium settings (+85% res) that I was forced to run it at to get a performance that'd sit stable in the 45-60fps range. (2560x1440, 2gb 680gtx, i5 3570k, 16gb ram).  Melee finishing animations were a hotly debated topic, but they are so short they don't interrupt the flow of combat. In later levels they become sort of your in-combat health-regen and later on you can equip a powerup to shorten their duration further.  The gunplay is extremely enjoyable, every single gun has a distinct feel, good sound effects, nice visuals and all are upgradable with interesting alternate firemods that can be upgraded further to improve on their effect, ending up in a Mastery Unlock that buffs the alternate mode fully.  The enemy gallery is almost entirely the classic Doom lineup buffed with a few extra new monsters and new takes on former humans.  Absent from the game are the Arachnotron and the Archvile, the latter replaced by the Summoner the Summoner, a sort of new version of the Archvile. It doesn't feel as threatening, but it shares the agility and speed of all the other monsters in this game.  Which is something quite new and fresh in the FPS genre. The monsters literally jump and climb all over the environment, dodging and weaving to avoid your shots or position themselves to rain lasers down on you. You'll be doing the same, moving with speed up and down ledges, no fall damage is present, so your freedom to move is great. Later in the game you'll get a double-jump and a powerup that lets you move faster after performing melee kills, a powerup that lets you control yourself while in the air much like in Quake 1 and powerups that let you engage melee kills from farther away.  All this combines to a combat system that feels smooth, precise, extremely fun and very rewarding.   I find it to the game's credit that dying seems entirely my own fault for not taking good enough advantage of the options allowed me. And the options are many. You can carry all the game's weapons and you will be swapping between them often and you'll have many, many available approaches in every single fight.   The soundtrack is blazing modern industrial style metal in combat, out of combat there is a light ambient drone, all of it heavily inspired by the original Doom soundtrack. There are many, many eastereggs and little things paying homage to the original games in here and it's clear that it's been made by someone who obviously cared a lot.  With the snapmap editor allowing community creations and a robust replayability, I foresee Doom staying on my drive for quite a while. I hope to see more.  I have not had any experience with the multiplayer, but I'll probably take a look at some point, but it's not why I bought the game and not why you should either, I'd reckon.  Highly recommended.

'I'm trying to figure out how to start a review of DOOM, but all of my digressions turn into how awesome it is to destroy dudes with high-powered weaponry.'  'It can't be that awesome. You said the same thing about Painkiller.'  'I know, and Painkiller is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, too. Painkiller's got a gun that's essentially a wooden stake launcher. It shoots wooden stakes the size of tree trunks, and it sticks enemies to the wall when they die. That's pretty ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.'  'It's the one with the gun that shoots shurikens and lightning, right?'  'It damn well is.'  'So why do you want to recommend DOOM when we've got Painkiller holding up the gold standard of the modern frantic first person shooter for about 12 years now?'  'Well, Painkiller's great, and Serious Sam is great, and the original DOOM is, and always will be, great. But the DOOM they released in 2016... holy moly. It is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ furious. It does things I thought I'd never see again in a first person shooter.'  'Like what?'  'The ♥♥♥♥ing tone, for example. It hits what DOOM exemplifies on the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ head - fast-paced, furious murder of demons from Hell. It's about being the most terrifying ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing in the room in the middle of a crowd of demons. I mean, sure, there's the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ token RPG elements, and the 'kill 250 demons with your hands tied behind your back' type quests are out in full force, but I guess we expect those things because people complain about progression and everything has to have a grind now, I guess. So because of those things, the game takes a little while to really get started.'  'But what happens when it does?'  '...holy bejesus, you have no idea. You don't. Sure, the demo gives you a taste of what to expect, but what happens there is nothing compared to what happens after. I remember seeing a Berserk powerup before one arena, and I immediately went for it. Don't do that. Wait until the big guys come out. Then you start chaining together kills - punching a small guy, then another small guy, then you attack this giant beefcake of a monster and rip him to shreds, then the next one, blood and limbs flying everywhere, just ♥♥♥♥ing destroying everything until they're all gone. And it made me feel ♥♥♥♥ing powerful. Like I had transcended. And the game is full of moments like that. Just furious, explosive murder with an optional side of timing if you want the best, bloodiest results.'  'Ah. How's multiplayer?'  'It's ♥♥♥♥ing boring.'

New DOOM is here. I played a couple of hours with it and The Verdict for me with about 2 hours of gameplay. Solid, amazing, Feeling Classic and new. It is Amazing and Great and not something to shrug at because its Bethesda or being Triple A. Granted the Multiplayer is a disappointed in many ways in terms of the 'Default' settings, there is some Classic stuff in Snapmap options but thats it.  On to the real game, If you have the money and you were skeptical. I would say that there is nothing That Wrong with the game. It starts strong, Gets stronger. and its hella fun. the gunplay is exactly what you would want in a classic style like game of the old doom, ROTT and Quake. the Weapon Mod system is not bad addition an feels fluent with how they work. the monsters all have very specific game styles and how to avoid them, Movement is fast and hectic and only stops once rooms are cleared just like how the old days where. there is never a instant respawn of unlimited enemies. Look Fantastic and would say everything there is a good Solid Doom game. Though for me Personally There are some features I dont like but its not a insult or a ruiner of the game but stings me in a small way in terms of the mechanic choose they imposed.  The First one is that the Glory Execution Kills, While Graphical its damn impressive in the mechanics and how much scripting they used, Different animations based on where your Doom Marine position is and where you are looking gives you different types. However, what im not impressed by is you are almost Reliant of them which I was hoping was not the case. When you use any weapon, it takes a couple of shots to cause them to be in a 'stunned' state. then you can just walk up and Press Melee. the problem I see is that if you want Extra Ammo and Health drops from them, This is your only way besides the Chainsaw, To get such items. If you picked up all the health and ammo picks up on the map normally. you have to resort to Animation Kills over and over just to get it back. and the Chainsaw if you want a Plethora of ammo back using its ammo charge in a instant animation kill. I will understand the animations are very quick of about .8 to 1.3 seconds depending on the enemy. But the fact you are Reliant of such mechanic to stay alive bugs me on a personal level.  2nd, Im Perfectly fine with a upgrade system in a game, as long as it doesnt feel forceful or doesnt seem stupid to add upgrades for upgrades sake. and For new Doom, Im hesitant. There are on average 3 to 5 upgrades per Module Per weapon, and there are about 10 weapons in the game I believe. You earn the weapon upgrades through 'challenges' (one example was to do 5 Glory Kills on the possessed) to get Weapon Upgrade points, and are different challenges Per level. Then there is your Praetor suit, which you earn those upgrades through dead elite guards in hidden areas to collect there chips. Then the Argent Cells to permanent upgrade your health. armor and ammo Capacity. THEN there is the Rune system that gives different characteristics that can be changed on the fly. To me personally I feel that was a bit to much upgrading ideas for the Sake of Upgrading. the only argue rebuttal Ive heard was 'it has a New Game Plus, for Nightmare or Perma Death mode'. But for me, If Bethseda didnt claim 'this is Doom back to its roots' or 'no cutscenes fast pace action demon killing' then I would let all of the upgrading slide. but they did and it feels unnecessary to me in Some Departments, not all Mind you.  Those are Personal complaints that no way derail the game or makes me feel its bad, because its not in any way. The overabundance of Secrets to be found. a Map that can be access to figure out locations and areas of those secrets is so much fun again in the years I havent seen such a thing because some indie like titles (like ROTT 2013 Reboot). Im a little sad the map does show you exactly what items to be found, like Elite Guards, Bots to get Mod purchases etc. But it doesnt change how much you can move in this game. It never seems that you are locked out from a passed location During a level. Once you finish what is considered the Level, then you can no longer return to that location and move forward. The Jumping is amazing to feel and climbing everything makes you look carefully for any location that can be used for such puzzles in a sense.  Graphical amazing, Runs super smooth. can turn off Motion Blur, DoF, and have a FOV of 130 for PC (and I believe Consoles now have such a option). Feels fresh then most games and in a lot of ways not something to shine away from. The singleplayer is a lot of fun so far. There are a lot of dialogue that seems to happen but its usually breif with one paragraph of words that you can just Walk away from hearing, to most of it being a Codex system in your menus detailing all environments, datalogs, demon creatures, and the weapons. Happy to be there if you like to read, or ignore for just more killing demons. Its bloody its gorey and it works for a Triple A for once.  Buy it if you have the money, Its not a waste of time. It is not a Disappointed, its not a failed hype train. It is a new Doom that besides some minor complaints I Personally have. Im Happy, Excited and loving to play it more.

DOOM is great.  It's full-on fast paced fun with lots to discover, there's a great and meaningful variety of weapons and unlocks, the health / ammo system is brilliantly balanced, the melee glory kills system is graceful and balletic in the midst of frenetic combat, the levels are chock-full of secrets and bonus challenges, the enemy variety is both interesting and meaningful in combat...  DOOM is great.  The campaign story is played just the right way, there's just enough to keep you invested, it doesn't take over, the protagonist is angry at everything, and your main goal is to blast everything in the face until it dies. There are some big moments, but nothing earth-(or mars)-shattering, but it is varied and interesting enough to draw you through. The art style is great, with a great variety in colours and map styles, and the weapons and models are all gorgeous.  DOOM is great.  The multiplayer is not so great, whilst a throwback to Unreal Tournament style of gameplay, it didn't hold my interest for long, and I'm not a big fan of the snapmaps system (which creates maps that feel clunky and like they're made on a tile system, because they are). Maybe some will get some great fun out of these options, but I considered them some underwhelming extras to dive into if you so wish. The meat of the game is the campaign, and it is glorious.  DOOM is great.

I've hated AAA games for a while at this point; they've conditioned me to expect nothing good or fun from a reboot or modernization of an old game or the schlock that gets peddled and shilled all over the internet (granted that DOOM also got a lot of advertising in the same vein as well). DOOM (4) is the first game in a long time to give me hope, especially from an idthesda game, that it's possible for the old school to get a fresh coat of paint and still look good.  The game is raw and non-stop combat with large sprawling levels with lots of vertical and horizontal movement and plenty of demons to blast. Visuals have only been getting better since the Build Engine, and as much as I've hated the modern idtech engine games (MEGATEXTURES DURRRR), idthesda has managed to actually make them work. There are lots of little gameplay details that keep the game moving (weapon wheel bound to one button, fast 'glory kills' that give back health a la 40k Space Marine, etc). It's one of the best games I've played in a long time and I don't regret paying release price. Their version of the Reflex map-maker and Halo 3's FORGE is great as well; doesn't have the customization of a Build Engine .wad but the gameplay is still there and at the end of the day, that's what really matters.  Multiplayer blows, though. That's just Halo with a reskin. Play it for a bit if you want, but you're not gonna have a whole lot of long-term fun.

Summary: DOOM(2016) is not only just a great game, it is a great Doom game. Unlike Doom 3 which tried to focus more on narrative and horror aspects, DOOM brings what fans always enjoyed about the series. Fast paced action, gory kills, sprawling level design, epic music, and wonderful boss fights. The story is minimal to non-existent, but that is a good thing, DOOM knows what it's doing, providing an avenue for players to experience the most adrenaline fueled gameplay of the past few years in gaming.  Pros: -Excellent level design -Return of 'Secrets' across each level -'Always Run' is back -Old School mechanics (health packs, holding all 10 weapons) -Epic score of industrial/metal music -Excellent visuals -Well optimized for PC -Gameplay is stellar -Enemy design is grotesque and gory -Memorable boss fights -Snapmap is a great addition to the game -Good length campaign (~10 hours on ULTRA-VIOLENCE difficulty)  Meh: -Multiplayer is just OK, some old school Doom fans will be disappointed  Cons: -Some campaign arenas can get repetitive (Gore Bags)  Performance:  Rig Used: EVGA GTX 980 4GB of VRAM, 16GB DDR3 RAM, i5 3570K.  I was able to maintain a flawless locked 60fps at 1080p resolution on ultra settings. When unlocked, fps stays around the 90-100 mark on Ultra graphics settings. I tested at 2560x1440, and was able to maintain 60fps, but with a few frame drops during intense sequences.

This is the most fun I've had with a shooter in many years. With most games going the Skinner Box route (unlocks and achievements) these days, it's really refreshing to play a game where the gameplay is its own reward. There are unlocks and other light RPG elements, but they're implemented tastefully in a way that 1) gets you to develop your skills and 2) never feels like a grind. I'm currently working on Ultra-Violence difficulty and have found it rewarding to try the game at harder difficulties. I'm personally staying far away from the highest difficulty with perma-death but if that's your thing, knock yourself out.  It's kind of strange that id/Bethesda did a couple of rounds of closed multiplayer testing before release. One one hand, they probably wanted to avoid launch day multiplayer issues, but on the other hand, it wasn't well received and shifted focus away from the strongest part of DOOM, which is its single-player campaign. I played a little bit of the multiplayer during alpha, beta, and now release. Honestly, there's nothing really wrong with it. Most of the criticism stems from the fact that it doesn't really do anything ground breaking and is very business-as-usual. Which it is.  You should buy this game for the excellent single-player component. If you're looking for a competitive FPS, Call of Duty, Battlefield, and Counter-Strike pretty much have that space nicely covered. And that's okay. DOOM is still worth your time and money.

Given the early press which focused on the uninspiring multiplayer, I wasn't expecting this game to be very good, but it turned out to have a solid singleplayer campaign, with a lot more vertical movement and jumping puzzles than older Doom games and a focus on set arena fights over clearing out pockets of enemies or ambushes. There are secrets, powerups, and upgrades to find and use, some of which are nods to classic games while others are just plain entertaining to discover. The game also seems to want to be placed on sale quite often, and if you aren't squeamish and are prepared to shoot, punch, and chainsaw demons and explode them into item pinatas, I can't recommend the game enough if it's on discount.  Well, I do have to say the game is fairly demanding and is prompting a refresh of my years-old computer, so while it does have large vistas of alien planets, hellish chasms and tech bases it can push older hardware to their limits. It is also pretty annoying waiting for the game to reload if you die.   Overall though, considering the amount of saturation the genre has had over the last decade, it's almost refreshing how well the developers managed to create something that not only held true to many of the design aspects of past games but managed to make a game that feels great to play even now.

Before I start I wanted to say that before I wrote this review I finished the main campaign, reached echelon lvl 1 in multiplayer and played around with the snapmap for few hours. That all was more than enough to realize that this game is addictive as all hell.  >Campaign< The main campaign was... flawless. Game was full of action, secrets, story. Main campaign had a breath-taking visuals, an unexpected plot and it was also quite lenghty. The constant weapon and character upgrading was really rewarding. Missions and environments were well made and fully enjoyable. My reaction was:'How is it evening already?'  >Snapmap< Snapmap was really convenient. After about 20 minutes of tutorials I was able to create really good looking/feeling missions.(Compared to other mission editors, where I spend about an hour or two before a ragequit). Sharing and saving your creations is also as simple as ABC. Snapmap is easily the best mission editor ever created.  >Multiplayer< In the beginning you will die... alot. As a person who grew up with arena shooters I would say that DOOM's multiplayer is a perfect balance between a classical arena shooter and a modern FPS. If you have ever played arena shooters before, then this game will sure have you hooked for hours. Biggest flaw is that there aren't that many people playing therefore good luck trying to find a match on a monday night around 3AM. I'm 100% going to continue playing the multiplayer, feel free to join me.

Here's my very mixed recommendation. I went with 'Yes' because I at least liked the game enough to finish it and Steam doesn't have a 'Maybe' option. I beat the campaign on ultra violence in 9 hours.  Pros ------------------------------ -It's Doom/Hell themed. We don't get too many gorgeous video games centered around Hell. -It's well optimized. I was able to run the game on ultra settings at 2560x1440 while sticking mostly in the 50-60fps range off of a GTX 980. -The sound design is great. -They give you tons of options for customizing your HUD. -Shooting demons in the face is fun.  Cons ------------------------------ -People seem to think this is just like good ol' Doom 1 & 2 but I really don't think they remember how those played. The levels in this are set up that you'll shoot a few weak enemies on your way to a main objective marker before getting trapped in an area that you can only get out of if you kill every last enemy in the room. This formula repeats throughout the entire game. There isn't a single room that I can recall like this in my beloved Doom 2. This in no way, shape, or form is set up so you can just find the necessary keys and switches to complete a level while shooting anything that gets in your way. Shooting literally everyone in the face is the only way to progress the game. If you have never played Doom 1 or 2, the formula may still bother you but it's not as much of a letdown. -The story is forgettable at best. Even Doom 3 had a better reason for bringing Hell to Mars. -The game has pacing issues. The game has 3 speeds: stuck in a room listening to an awful story, shooting an imp or two while navigating through the map, and drinking from a firehose from hell once you're inevitably trapped in an area and forced to kill several waves of enemies. -Glory Kills are cool at first but once you realize that's the only way to guarantee a kill will yield health, they get annoying. It would be really cool if it was just an optional way to take a demon down but it's mandatory if you value your life. -Some of the weapons feel under powered. It seems like a strange system to let you upgrade the hell out of your earlier weapons only to have them be complete garbage compared to the next gun that uses the same ammo type at stock. -The multiplayer is infamously average and they're selling a $40 season pass for it. Strange call.

Awesome and retro-feeling singleplayer. The story is present, but not overinflated and doesn't get in the way of mindless, fast shootyfun. SnapMap seems like a nice addition as well. Didn't mess around it myself yet, but it seems like talented people can make some really nice stuff. ;)  Overall totally worth the money for the singleplayer alone. Don't play on anything lower than Ultra-Violence (hard)

Disclaimer: I have not played the multiplayer AT ALL. It does not factor into my review.   So, DOOM! I did not play DOOM 3, so the last time I had played a DOOM game was back in the late 90s. I am happy to say that this game both does and does not feel like a game from that era.    Pros:       Gameplay:  Everything feels tight and reactive. The shooting, guns, enemies, and environments are very visceral. I do not know the last time I played a single-player FPS that was this frantic and incredibly satisfying.      Secrets:  I am a  sucker  for secrets & collectables in a game. DOOM harkens back to older titles in that secrets are plentiful and rewarding to hunt down. It was also a nice touch to be able to see how many secrets were in each level, but not explicitly where to find them.      Level Design:  This is something I feel many FPS games do not do well. DOOM nails it. Whilst there are obvious paths to follow, there are also many places to explore and most of them aren't secrets! Arenas are multi-leveled, especially after you obtain the ability to double-jump. This allows for a lot of mobility and dodging during combat, which you will need!      Weapons/Runes:  I have to give them their own seperate section away from general gameplay, because they added so much. Every weapon (with the exception of two) has distinct upgrades that change how you play. I had some favorites, no doubt, but none of the weapons ever felt useless. Every option brought something to the table. The same goes for the Runes.      Graphics/Design:  The game is beautiful, in it's own 'everything is bloody and ♥♥♥♥ed up' way.     Cons:       Storyline:  If you're looking for an amazing story, you will not find it here. Don't get me wrong, DOOM's story is good for what it is, especially if you're into the whole 'Hell is a place on Mars' fiction. However, there isn't much in the way of character development. This is not Bioshock.      Repetition:  This is here mostly to show that I'm not entirely biased for the game. It did not apply to me, but if you do not get into the combat in DOOM within the first few missions, then you will not enjoy the rest of this game. You  will  spend most of the game shooting and dismembering demons. Because, well, that's what DOOM is!   DOOM scratched multiple itches for me that I didn't even know that I had. Amazingly crisp and exciting combat mixed in with searching every level for secrets kept me entranced for quite awhile. I am happy with this game and do gladly recommend it to anybody who enjoys these sorts of experiences.

So what do I think about the new doom? Well there are three parts to judge, and I will review each part.   The single player, easily the best part of the game, the single player of the game is hands down the best of the three features. The single player of this game was so good I bet it will win many best shooter and game of the year awards just because of how enjoyable the single player was. The levels are non linear, have replay value are challenging, full of secrets, monster variety and guns. The game get more added in the later you play and you can carry all your guns through the levels with you making combat much more fun, you have no limits to the number of guns you can carry. the story of the game is great, you dont have to spend for than a few miniutes listening to exposition and most of the time when you do doom guy is angry and destroys anything in the way of him killing demons and that includes a computer telling you story. The game starts out and in a few seconds you get to start shooting things. You can read PDAs if you care about story and you spend 95% of the single player shooting things, the way it should be.   The snap map. How good is snapmap? Well there are two ways to look at his, for consoles it is much better than the map maker in halo forge and will get more added to it in the future so it might get a little better but the issue with it is that there are stupid map making limits in the builder the classic doom builder 2 is a better map maker because you can make a map with 100,000 demons on it while in the new doom game there is a limit to the numbers of monster allowed in game to be spawned at a time and a limit on the number of monsters allowed on the map total as well as a limit on the map size. Clearly the map maker was made with consoles in mind and that would be okay if the game had external mod support like classic doom did but sadly the new doom does not. The snap map builder is easy to use and and I guess a good introduction to learning how to make maps miles ahead of halo forge but if you have used any kind of good map maker snap map is not as good as map builders that are 20 years old sadly but on consoles it is the best map builder available.   The multiplayer.... The worst part of the game in my opinion. I got the game a few weeks after the game came out and the online multiplayer was quite barren with only a few thousand players on it. Why is the multiplayer not nearly as good as the single player or other online shooters? There are many reasons why the doom online multiplayer is bad such as being made by halo developers, having limitations like 2 guns only, loadouts, perks that the game calls hack modules that are basically like power up cards, the game is poorly balanced because a level 1 player has HUGE disadvantages and a level 50 has HUGE advantages. You do not even start with all items or guns, you can save up and earn hack modules that are basically just like the hated cards or perks in halo 5 that if you save up enough of you get unfair advantages over players who don't have these items. Some of the power ups include temporary unlimited ammo, extra armor and knowing both the health AND location of the player that killed you and there are 3 theirs of these power ups bronze silver and gold better the higher the tier. The multiplayer is very unfair and poorly balanced for 4 reasons, 1 The higher your level the more guns items you have that a level 1 player does not. This gives you more variety and different guns to use on players who don't have the same options that you do. Items are also given out to higher levels and they can give advantages to players who can use them on players who don't have them.  2 Hack modules are unfair because the more matches you play regardless of level even if your the same Max level a player who has more hack modules than you has things like knowing your Hp AND where you are on the map, infinite ammo for the beginning of the map and more armor. If you save up these and use them on new players or players who don't save modules you have a unfair advantage over newer players.  3 Demon runes, demon runes are fun the first few times it nice to play as a demon its fun you get a few free kills and you think everything is good right? Well no it is unfair because demon overpower marines. You might think oh its fair because they get some power if I get some power too right? Well you don't un lock all the deom runes at the start of the game you only get one out of 4 and you get 3 demons at level 15. So this is just really unfair to newer players because they don't even have the same runes, guns, hack modules, items, etc that you do. On the other hand haste and quad damage power ups from quake are fair because if you kill the other player you get to take the quad damage from him the second you kill him while the timer for the item is still active. You may or may not get the demon rune because it may not spawn even if you can kill a demon that has much higher dps and health than you. Also the most popular game mods are ones that have the fewest demon runes.  4 Community after a few days playing I have already heard about people cheating in the multiplayer, I haven't seen it to be sure but it might be in the player base. There are not very many people playing the multiplayer so as far as I can tell on PC it is dying. Another hug issue is groups and balance. If you have a few level 50 friends and you as a group go into team deathmatch you will all be on the same team even if the other team is level 1-10 and your team is leveled 40-50. Making the multiplayer even more unfair but at least it is really really easy to play with friends.   So do I recommend the game? I do but it is worth it for the single player alone, snap map is okay but could have been much better with just mod support, and I really don't like the multiplayer because it is very unfair to players in many ways but it is enjoyable and you can get kills easy with the gauss cannon, demon runes and that's fun but it is also unfair when you get killed in one shoot by heat seeking missiles, a BFG/gauss cannon blast or by advantages of hack modules. I payed 80 dollars for the game and I am happy I did. Buy it for single player and if you want to make a few maps or play a multiplayer few matches for only a few hours but you want a great singleplayer story.

I've been a long-time DOOM fan and am really enjoying this release. Wasn't a fan of DOOM 3, but this version takes a lot of calls from DOOM 1 & 2 - it's more fast paced, sillier, and the multiplayer is actually extremely fun. The lack of variety in enemies is kinda eh, but otherwise this has been a really good purchase.  Pros: - it 'feels' like a member of the franchise, if that makes sense - more than the third game did - the flow of play is really good - you can clamber around, climb most scenery, combat is fluid and super fast like the old games - multiplayer is fun & has a lot of customisation options - the map editor (snapmap) is REALLY awesome and employs a super cool visual scripting function - A+ multiplayer taunts - throwbacks to the other games in the franchise - really good sound design (apart from the repetitive moaning of enemies if you're above them)  Cons: - the campaign can get a little repetitive, chalking this down to lack of variety of enemies and sometimes glory kill can be OP - a bit slow to load, but it is a new release - exiting the game to switch modes is kinda tiresome b/c of aforementioned loading times - no matchmaking in multiplayer really

Doom 2016 is arguably one of the best games to come out this year, it's not the best but it is definitely one of the better games to come out of 2016.  Pros:  + Constant sales.  Do yourself a favor, you should definitely get this game once it goes on sale, considering how id/Bethesda is being really generous with this game and the constant 50% off sales I'd definitely recommend picking this up when it's on sale.  + Fast paced  I honestly had a lot of trouble playing other games like Overwatch once I finished having a pretty strong marathon with Doom, the movement of other games just felt way too slow so you may or may not experience a hang over if you try to play this game through long sessions and then trying to switch to other games.  + Solid shooting All the guns feel viable and the situations and how you handle them is usually let up to you.  + Interesting lore The game lacks a story, which is fine, this is DOOM. Not Last of Us. However, the lore in the game is actually really rich if you bother searching for the records that are spread throughout the game.  + Music The music in this game is really great and gets you into the mood of killing more and more demons.  + Optimisation on PC is surprisingly good considering how badly PC ports have been handled lately. >_> Watching you NMS, Deus Ex.  Mixed: ~ Death match was finally added into the MP and id has taken over the Multiplayer aspect as well. We're supposedly gonna be getting bots sometime later but unfortunately this stuff wasn't here at launch.  ~ An arguable problem with the game is how the levels are layed out and this may or may not make the game feel too repetitive depending on the player. The usual formula is travel here > Get locked down inside room > Kill demons > Room is unlocked > repeat. This can make the game feel too repetitive if you're not too into it and compared to the old Doom games, you could find and hunt all demons or you could just run through them and only deal with the ones in your way.  ~ Multiplayer. The Multiplayer was handed off to Certain Affinity, the people that did Halo MP so id themselves had no handling over the multiplayer until after the game was released. It's not bad, it's not great, it's just, okay.    Negatives: - Multiplayer DLC my only gripe with this game is that I can't seem to connect with anyone in the MP and the fact that id/Bethesda seem focused on adding Multiplayer DLC only to the bag to a game that's already dead. I've tried, 5 minutes sitting in the MP screen and I couldn't get a single soul.

Right, cards on the table; I played DOOM on shareware in the '90s. Thanks to PCs being expensive, I next played Ultimate DOOM and DOOM II on PSX. Same goes for Final DOOM. Myself and my friend could not get enough, always playing it on the hardest difficulty we could (ultra violence - what do you expect? It was an FPS with a D-Pad!). Years later, I finally get a laptop and the first thing I put in the CD drive? Doom Complete Collection. DOOM 3 comes out. Won't run on my PC, so I get the Xbox version. It's good, but it's not what I wanted.  A few years later, Brutal DOOM comes along. I go through all the classics again, with touched up graphics, and all the fun stuff it added like executions.  Now? Now we have DOOM 2016. From the footage shown I thought I'd like it. What I didn't expect was for the campaign to be as close to perfect as can be managed, taking into account console limitations.  I haven't played much MP, btw. It's like Halo 2, if it had loads of blood and only took place indoors. Snap Map feels a bit half-♥♥♥♥♥, but the limitations are forcing users to be creative and there's fun to be had in there.  The campaign, which I played on Ultra-Violence, though... Well it's DOOM II, modernised. I cannot give it higher praise. Each fight is a masterfully choreographed ballet, each new weapon adding a step to an ever more complicated dance routine. It's almost hypnotic, and it is beautiful in it's own twisted, blood-soaked way.  You need this game in your life. This is what a FPS should be.

It's been a while since I've played an FPS shooter that just felt  so good . DOOM has so many things going for it that work out perfectly in its favour that I had loads and loads of fun with it. I'm a newcomer, and while I played the multiplayer beta, I found that a bit lackluster, so I'm absolutely, 100% glad that the singleplayer game exceeded all expectations I had for it.  Now, with the praises aside, let's talk a bit about the game itself. DOOM's gameplay requires a lot of movement, and you have a vast array of weapons to literally mow down demons with. You stop, you  die , plain and simple. Each weapon can be modded, so on top of however many weapons they give you, the mods add even more variety and allows flexibility to different playstyles. I thought this was a neat idea, since you can change how you fight on the fly, leading to different chains. Furthermore, weapons are not restricted to levels or sequences - if you find it, you can use it early.  Which leads me to exploring, which the game encourages you to do with secret rooms and collectibles. I thought how they implemented it struck a good balance between streamlining the maps for the player and avoiding making areas too big. Exploring leads to lots of good lore and backstory on characters, which helps give their motivations during the course of the story clearer meaning, if you choose to pursue it.  The plot itself is, objectively, really generic. A scientist goes mad with power and creates a cult, and you have to basically stop her from literally unleashing Hell. A very standard good v. evil story, but I've found that games like these don't really need a strong story to carry it (though it's always welcome). I think id knows that lots of players will be playing DOOM with the intent of going in to rip-and-tear, and I think how they portrayed Doomguy was perfect in that regard. Doomguy doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ (mostly) about what's happening at the Mars facility he woke up in. He has one priority: KILL EVERY DEMON. And kill he does - everything from the copious amounts of gore to the pretty sweet glory kills channels this. Plus, the story plays on his indifference to the other characters' goals, leading to some hilarious moments.  Music and art were both top notch. Metal fans (or anybody into heavy guitar riffs) will enjoy the soundtrack, as it uses leitmotifs from the original DOOM score as an homage and base for the new soundtrack. Music channels the frantic nature of the gameplay and satisfying gunplay and kills and complements it, leading to a rise in adrenaline while playing. I thought with all the times we go to Hell that it would look like the same desolate place, but the artists really captured different feelings and made distinguishable environments in a place that pretty much screams its the cesspit of the universe. No place was really boring to look at in DOOM, which made moving around the maps more enjoyable with good level design.  A minor gripe was the boss difficulties. They get steadily harder up until the final boss. While that boss is challenging, I felt like she wasn't as challenging as the previous boss, which led to a slightly disappointing fight in terms of ramping difficulty. Previous bosses made me go 'Well, I'm kind of screwed,' then experience a rush of elation when I beat it (only to find that it wasn't even its final form sometimes). In a game that does a good job making things challenging, that fight just seemed lackluster. Furthermore, the ending itself was lackluster. I didn't expect a perfect ending since the story was only OK, but they literally end it on a cliffhanger, which I didn't quite like. This is a personal thing though, because I felt the end was abrupt, and left me going 'Is that it?' because I was really enjoying DOOM a lot.  Overall, DOOM did an excellent job with fantastic gameplay that feels good to play, and is incredibly polished in this and its visual and audio aesthetics. The story is kind of just there to bridge the fun demon killing sprees, but DOOM is a solid release that does one simple thing and one simple thing well without sacrificing variety and difficulty. There's a demo out, so if you're still unsure, give it a try!

Campaign - They did it.  They recaptured what playing Doom was like in the 90's and yet some still made it into a game that would work in 2016.  The campaign is one of the best and freshest shooters I've played in years, and I hope adds new life and dimension into what was getting to be a stale genre.  The level design is almost perfect; scales range from Corridors to enourmous arena's just like they did in the originals.  The minions and weapons are just classic Doom redone. They're familiar yet fresh, and most importantly fun and satisfying.  The soundtrack is epic and adds a tonne to the experiance.  Cons   The levels while laid out and perfect, are perhaps a bit too 'doom by the numbers' in Hell they could have gone a a lot more inventive, but stuck to the classic skulls and wall shackles. Doesn't diminish the game at all, just felt like it was an opportunity lost.  While I appreciated they left the story a massive secondary feature, as is traditional in Doom, they could have maybe spent a bit more flushing out who was who, and what was going on. I got just enough that it made me curious and confused who these characters were and what they're motivations were. Thankfully, if you feel like reading, some of this is explained in codex's you can collect.  The multiplayer - It's really not bad, it's twitchy and fun, if fairly unbalanced. It's quality of the campaign makes the Multiplayer seemed almost tacked on. I put quite a few hours in Beta though before the campaign even launched, and I had a lot of fun. Welcome to Hell Motherf***er so grab you baddest armor, your meanest shotgun; strap on your little nuggets and put your biggest smile on. It's time to go kick some f***ing a$$ all guns blazing, heavy metal riffs blasting in your ears  No reloading, no running, hella enemies, frenetic and gore galore.  Forget the early critics (based on Multi betas and limited versions) cause this is what we've all been waiting for. F**k Call of Duty, F**k Battlefield, F**k Halo, this is a throwback made with class and respect to the grandaddy of em all, Ultimate DooM (What doom 3 shoulda been imo).   Random Thoughts :  - The solo is really great with a somewhat basic story (nothing more, nothing than what the original doom story was) but terrific game and sound design. Around 8 to 10hours to play through it 100% but there's a high replay value. - It is viewed negatively for being an 'arena fps'. Doesn't every clasic Doom games play as 'arena fps' ' ?? - Movement is the key (just like it used to be.). Game is really frenetic  - Basically emulates the old school DooM with modern gameplay (still very much Horizontal and Vertical at its core) and stunning graphics - Very easy to handle, there's like 4-5 keys (besides moving) to use regularly, the rest are almost useless - controller friendly (Handles great with thhe Steam controller tho you'll need to tweak the Id Preset. Did not play with a xbox pad but should be good too) - Demons are somewhat varied and very well designed - The arsenal is classic (in the ood way) - You can 'feel' the guns (weight, kick,...) - The CQC animations are very brutal - Soundtrack is brutal too, very fitting, timeless and inspired by the original - The Id Tech Engine 6 kicks-a$$ even on low specs (i play on a laptop with a core i7 and a GTX950M and i can run the game on medium to high with absolutely no lag. The game ain't even on my SSD) - Id seems to have mastered the in-game secrets: not too many neither too few + they are fun (like the little marines) - LOOK FOR LEVERS IN EACH LEVELS (If you know why, you won't be disappointed and if you don't know, you will be amazed and will love it). Levers are the crack of this game. - Not sure if it's a port but it's greatly optimised and does not feel like one - The multi is okay even though the gameplay is a litlle bit diluted and messy (the hacks are nice but they feel to much like pay to win or at least to get an edge even if they are very limited and obtainable for free). The snapmap mode is nice fun with friends - Install size is 53 GB so make sure you've cleared some space  Buy it, on sale or not. You won't regret it and it will be one of the finest pieces of your game library, one you'll still be playing with a fond heart in 20+ years

First off. I had a doom shareware cd, I bought doom2 and quake new. So I'm old.  I've very very much enjoyed (new) Doom so far. It reminds me of the best parts of doom, but unrestrained by technology with a sprinkling of q3arena. Getting suddenly mobbed and blasting until it stops hurting is what doom 1&2 were about, and this offers that, the rate then seemed really fast (remember, doom gave birth to the FOS genre), now? It IS fast.   It also includes loot/leveling aspects that compliment rather than complicate the game. Do I need to shotgun blast 30 imps in the face? No, but I'll do it for the fun, and to get the weapon enhancement.  Which brings me to another interesting point. Many(but not all) characters are readily recognizable from doom I/II, but.. better. Which I really enjoyed.   The bad: It ate my HD6870. The framerate hovered around 24 with passable, but not good graphics, the rendering engine really isn't meant to cater to older hardware. The game's combat engine copes well with lowered framerate, combat slows universally so you don't just get gibbed, but as you'd expect, it damages the pace. Some views were untenable, dropping to 10 or less FPS.  Had to overnight a new card from Amazon, which is pretty typical when a new id game comes out(The purchase, not the overnighting. id has driven much of my PC upgrade process). With the new card I'm getting 100fps consistently and the old school doom 'feel' is0 100%.  Edit: It does not appear to require much CPU power, even with the 6870 it was only using around 20% cpu in a second gen i7.

DOOM is THE game for me. I loved the late-90s/Early-2000s ultraviolence FPS genre. Any attempt to replicate that after those times seemed half-hearted and unfulfilling... until now. DOOM is the essence of that genre, made better and amplified.  Positives : - Graphics : It looks amazing. My jaw drops everytime I enter a new Mars level. - Music : MY ♥♥♥♥ING GOD that music!!! BFG Divison melts your faces and takes your virginity. - Art-style : Amplifies the ambience. Completely unapologetic and in-your-face. Blood, guts, gore, GLORIOUS!! - Mechanics : Fast movement, air-strafing, relentless action, no ♥♥♥♥♥footing, no walking, no 'rubber-banding', no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. - Difficulty : Ultra-Nightmare gets pretty difficult, which means it's that much more rewarding to play. Yet, the 'I'm too young' difficulty should allow unexperienced FPS players to enjoy the game to the fullest without being intimidated.   Negatives :  - Multiplayer is underwhelming. The loadout system and levelling-up system undermines it. But I have a feeling they will listen to the feedback and fix it with the big upcoming multiplayer patch. This game absolutely has the potential to be as good as Q3A, it just needs to be unlocked. - The in-game points/upgrade system in single player is annoying, but thankfully, it's completely optional. You can play through the entire game without bothering yourself with them, so this is only a minor gripe. - Single player campaign not long enough. I was sad that I finished the game in roughly 8 hours. I LOVE IT AND I WANT MOAARRR!!  - Expensive season pass just for some multiplayer maps and playable demons(???). Should be free, but I'll reserve judgement for that when it comes out. But once again, it's completely optional.  Verdict : Best single-player FPS game EVER for a certain demographic (myself included) and a 'must play' classic for every other FPS fan. This is THE 10 out of 10 game, the game that all other single-player FPS games will be benchmarked against. Rip and Tear!!!  PS : If you think it's too expensive for ~8 hrs of gameplay, I can somewhat agree but I will say that the game was thorougly utterly satisfying and to me, you can't put a price on that. If you can't buy it at full-price, please do yourself a favour and buy it during one of the sales.

A Loyal Tribute to the old ID Software  , i got the same experience as Doom 1 & 2 while i played this one. This edition makes a nice link between Old Fast Paced FPS & Modern Shooters connecting the 'Non regenerative health, Hardcore Difficulty and Tough Enemies' with the impressive visuals and graphic effects we see on Modern Shooters. Along the campaign i saw a great team behind working on the Single Player which focused on the distinctive style of the previous games; Good Length, Amazing Level Design, Awesome Tech/Optimization (related to idTech 6), Kinesthetics, AI. This game is Great in so many aspects that outshines one of the worst multiplayer modes FOR this kind of Franchise... Yes, it's bad.    Fast, Brutal & Immersive Experience   sounds like the secret recipe of the Doom series, and this one doesn't miss anything... But, i must confess that i expected more of Mick Gordon on the OST, there's something that don't belong to the background music, such as the Slowness of certain tracks, some of these really works on certain levels and ambients (metal/synth tracks), but is not comparable with the old ones.    AI and Animation works flawlessly , the arenas & level design takes the player on a journey where mercy is not allowed, and invites him to 'Rip and Tear' between each demon you see, it doesn't matter if these launches rockets from its arms or shoulders, spits fireballs, or split you in half with their bare hands.  I Think Romero and Carmack should not worry about the franchise because it is in the good hands of Bethesda/Id Software.... EXCEPT; Multiplayer Mode, made by another developer who made Halo Multiplayer. First of all, they implemented several features of console/'modern shooter' that made the fans hate this mode because it doesn't remember at all the style of Doom or even remotely the Quake Gameplay where Arena's were the dominant mode on Lan Party's in the late 90's/early 00's, in these matches each player was tested by skills and don't recompensate losers with 'consumables', Second; The multiplayer mode is so unbalanced with the demon runes which makes the round almost unrecoverable for the team who doesn't have the demon. I must say that i don't hate or disagree on certain multiplayer modes/implementations that are very similar to this one (looking to you Halo), i only say that IT DOESN'T FIT AT ALMOST ALL ASPECTS WITH THE FRANCHISE.  Now... Snapmap is an invitation to make your own maps, but at this time is very limited in various aspects (max demons, objects, space) which is understandable from a hardware perspective, however i would like an improved version of snapmap in the future where these restrictions ends permanently, and developers add new features such new arenas, or even make new ones, mods, script modifications, who knows what else with this great franchise.   The Veredict;   This reboot makes the player feel the original sensation made in '93 at technological, visual and mechanical levels where fast paced action is the main role of the franchise, several ticks of the checklist has been made flawlessly but it's true that is not perfect (OST & Multiplayer), besides that i really appreciated that i preordered the game ever without knowing if Id Software/Bethesda made this title with all the hype and gameplay videos, which is the reason why i preordered it (good one marketing...).  Last note, I grew up with this franchise and PC Gaming, i also love CoD 2 and MW franchise and others. To all other players from different generations; You must play this title, even better if it is on PC.     Excellent Title, BUY IT!      Rip n' Tear out of 5
