DOOM is brilliant in all regards. Gameplay, guns, graphics, sound, music, etc. It is my GOTY, hands down. I haven't enjoyed an FPS like this in years.  One of my favorite things about DOOM is how well balanced it is on every difficulty and when playing on Nightmare difficulty, enemies are not bullet sponges. Enemies deal massive damage but the game's mechanics allow you to dispose of them quickly and survive through movement, dodging and stunning. You quickly notice how your gameplay improves when you adapt a more primal go-and-mow playstyle, which for me has been long forgotten after a decade of CoD-like shooters.  I hope more games in the future can reproduce the feeling that id and Bethesda got with this DOOM game. This game single handedly resurrected my desire for FPS games after a decade of stagnation.  If I had to say anything negative about the game, it'd have to be that the Pistol isn't great, the auto-save system is sometimes annoying, I wish the game had COOP so I could go through the SP campaign with friends and the biggest of them all is probably the lack of modding ability. SnapMap is cool, but what kept the original DOOM games alive to this day is the fact people are able to create completely new content.

Something also to note is that I rarely play multiplayer FPS games, so my opinion is based solely on the campaign which is potentially 'missing the point' I'm sure.  I rarely get the time to really pour hours into a title, but after a fairly hairy month at work I had bough an evening to experience one of my old loves - killing demons. All that said, I sat down last night and fired up the game and even from the title screen I had goosebumps. The game iteslf is certainly not perfect, and in the initial levels I had felt like switching it off and coming back to it as the story and gameplay hadn't really gripped me, however in around the third or fourth level the pennt dropped. This game is wonderful, gory, fun, and has a brilliant learning curve and drip-feeds you the mechanics throughout the campaign really well.   The games ability to embed; story, humour, cool mechanics, rapid gameplay and homage to the older titles is great and I can honestly say I enjoyed my experience thoroughly. If you are a fan of the older titles (DOOM and DOOM II in particular) I feel like you might just need to give this a go (and give it a couple of hours, don't quit when you feel it's just not right, give it a little longer, it might surpirise you). Thanks id, you've made and old fan incredibly happy.

'Dood, it's DOOM!' If that's not enough to interest you then here is a bit more. . .  DOOM (2016) is 3 games in 1! First is Singleplayer Campaign Mode. This is the main reason I bought the game and it is without question fun and challenging! There are the classic secrets that you'll find when you check out 'Every nook and cranny.' They've also added suit and weapons upgrades that you'll find when you explore. The story is thin, but it's there and it's all you need to KICK-A! The AI is smart, the glory kills are bloody awesome, and music will get your blood pumping!  Second is Multiplayer. There are about 9 game styles. Even if you lose you'll earn XP Experience Points. As you progress up the levels features will unlock. You'll be able to access more Weapons, Equipment, Hack Modules, Loadout Slots, Suit parts, Colors and Patterns. By Level 17 I had all weapons and equipment available. DOOM Multiplayer may not be all that unique or 'original,' but frankly there isn't much to MP games. You run, you shoot, you frag, you try to stay alive. It's still a lot of fun and the maps are cool! Plus you get to play as a Demon! How cool is THAT?  Third is SnapMap, a level/game creation tool. It's relatively easy to use and the possibilities are endless! Tutorials are included, although they don't do an in depth job of explaining the logic/syntax of the system. You'll need learn those to build more complex maps and actions. But there are already dozens of tutorials on YouTube showing how powerful SnapMap can be. There are a couple of limitations. One is that created maps can only handle 4 players total. I hope they increase that to at least 8! The other is that at release there is no outside modding planned. So for example you can't add your own textures or models or sounds. SnapMap is still very cool and I've already played a few dozen maps.  Overall the graphics look great with lot's of sharp detail. Even on a modest graphics card, like my GeForce GTX 750 Ti, it plays smoothly and looks incredible! The game play is fast and bloody! I Highly Recommend it.  Dood, it's DOOM!

I was very excited for many years about Doom. Weeks before release I dropped hundreds to play it on proper hardware. My Doom Career started in '93 and lasts today, still mapping, playing, etc.   This game is good. Combat is very addicting and you're always moving. A few slips and you're knee deep in death. The Graphics are fantastic, vibrant colors, many things happening at once. I love every monster design besides the CyberMoose, the one demon they couldn't possibly screw up they did and modeled him into a weird half-tard Moose (SPOILER) that you only encounter once. (SPOILER)   I was on the fence about Glory Kills and Arenas but after beating the game twice they're nicely done and complement combat very well. It's similar to a Serious Sam but more Doom. The stuff I miss from Classic is monster closets and a little more open-ended map layouts, but what's here is still better than anything we've gotten in years. Weapon mods feel fluffy and it seems design time could have maybe better spent elsewhere, Doom's always been about combat and quick heel & toe work.  Certain Affinty developed Multiplayer so you're getting a weird mix of Halo and COD, but neither of the two. It has no real identity, it's not bad, it's not great. I was hoping they'd revive skill-based MP with things like item control, timing etc, but that's just not the case, especially from a gang of hacks like Certain Affinty. There's a weird flip-flop here where the Singleplayer requires the skill Multiplayer should have but doesn't. So if you like Singleplayer shooters this is the one to get.  SnapMap is good but prefabs suck, along with console limitations. It's good for combat, though, and that's all I really care about.  The game is worth 60, and though the time of Romero and Carmack at id has passed, the new id team did a great job.

Although I am getting a lot of crashes. Like one every 10 minutes or so I am still having a great time playing. It's like going back to 1986 only with great graphics and the gameplay is much more enhanced, but in a good way. Perfectly balanced across all lines. Not too horror (like DOOM 3 did).   Anyway, *I recommend it. Especially today with the once a year sale. New games never typically give a 35% discount but Bethesda is not too greedy to see the tree in the forest.

If you are a fan of the DOOM series, you owe it to yourself to buy this game. I admit, at first I was not convinced; poor multiplayer beta and was underwhelmed while watching videos of reviewers playing the beginning of the game. Despite my negative initial impression, I decided to take the plunge and bought the game on release.   I'm glad I did! This feels like a DOOM game - keeping traditional elements such as fast-paced action, monsters, and weapons, while taking advantage of modern developments today. The combat feels fantastic; at first I thought the gore kills were gimmicky, especially when I saw other people play it. In fact, it doesn't just feel great ripping a demon apart, it adds to the gameplay and keeps it unique; most modern FPS want you to take cover and reload. Not DOOM. It encourages you to dive into a demon mosh pit by ripping them apart so you get more ammo and health!   The game also makes good use of weapon upgrades, allowing them to be used in different ways for multiple battle scenarios. Although the format of combat gets repetitive, it always feels fun. Also, upgrades to both weapons and your marine are optional - if you want to play it without them for a greater challenge, go right ahead! The multiplayer is basic and pretty uninspiring (perhaps it will get better in the future), but DOOM is all about the single player experience and modding community!   I admit I am a DOOM fan boy. The original DOOM is one of my favorite games of all time and I have enjoyed all the others (including Doom 3 and Doom 64). I feel this one is particularly strong and with the addition of SnapMap's user-generated content, I believe there will be plenty of replay value.

If testosterone had a digital format, it would be this game.  Long story short: - Brutal and fun gameplay that requires all of your senses to master makes you improvise in several violent ways; - Gorgeous and very well thought visuals with visceral sound design that bring each complex level to life; - The way the story of the Doom Marine is retold will make you feel like the true colossus you're incarnating; - Soundtrack by Mick Gordon - 100% low tuning industrial metal boner guaranteed; - MP is like Quake Arena spiced with demonic cocaine (with even more weapons than the SP).

It's difficult to not enjoy this game.  The good: -Excellent gunplay. The way each gun feels and sounds to shoot, the amount of ammo you have, the rate at which you acquire new guns and modifications for existing ones is the perfect balance to prevent you getting bored. -Excellent level design. Some really fun to traverse combat arenas littered with pick-ups and secrets as well as large open levels with multiple paths to your objectives. -Excellent soundtrack and sound design. I even went and bought the soundtrack seperately when it was released. -Very impressive graphically. Had some issues running it on an older PC that just scraped the minimum specs but on a newer machine with everything cranked up it's an amazing game to behold. -Cool enemy design. I mean that both in terms of aesthetically and mechanically. Each demon, even the regular posessed humans look terrifyingly awesome. Add to that solid AI that forces you to adapt your playstyle and weapon choices to whatever combination of enemies you're fighting, and it makes for a fun time. -The multiplayer is solid. As with seemingly most people it wasn't exactly what I wanted (basically a modern Quake Live but shinier and more extreme) it is still an enjoyable game to play online on the whole with some decent game modes and cool levels.  The bad: -Unfortunately the multipler still isnt great. The absence of a deathmatch mode for the longest time was a big negative. The weapon balancing, at least the last time I played it, was also total garbage. Depending on which level you're playing you can almost guarantee what weapon eberybody will be using. For example playing this game just after launch and in the beta, the majority of people on each team would be running round with a rocket launcher and super shotty because they were the most effective combination on most maps.  -Enemy variety. There are a realitvely high number of different enemies in the game. Unfortunately several of them are essentially re-skins of existing ones with changes to their abilities so slight it makes little to no difference as you wade through them. For the final few levels after you've seen all the regular demon types that aspect began to get a bit monotonous. 'Gee whizz another 2 floating eye dudes and a couple revenants, just like that fight 10 minutes ago.' -Too many secrets/collectibles. From what I can recall there are preator tokens, argent cores, doomguy toys, codex files, audio logs, classic doom levels and just general 'secrets'. I enjoyed exploring the levels in this game but that's just too much. And while it's good that you're rewarded for finding them, what's not good is accidentally finishing a level only to find that you missed half the stuff and the only way to get them is to replay the whole thing. -The biggest blue-balls ending to a game since Halo 2. No spoilers but if like me you think cliffhangers are cheap and lazy then you will hate the ending as much as I did. An alright game.  It gets somewhat formulaic in that you traverse from large area A to large area B with some light platforming occuring in-between. So anytime you reach a relatively large area there will be an item you need to interact with and a bunch of frequently spawning enemies that need to be taken out before proceeding. It's pretty much the same for the entire game; some easy to beat enemies might be lying on the path as you get from A to B but many of these are really easy to beat and can be melee'd to death.   As for the platforming from A to B, it's pretty well done for a first person title. Most of the platforming is grabbing onto ledges rather than making precise jumps onto small platforms. You jump and face a ledge, and the game gives some leeway with this so that it doesn't have to be PRECISE jumps and timing. And that's a plus, because this isn't a platformer it's an FPS title with platforming elements. It's nothing too heavy and it works fine.  Along the way there are a lot of explorable areas. Small nooks to get into and get upgrades and/or unlock classic Doom levels. The maps are large enough to have a minimal amount of exploratory elements to them, but nothing massive. This isn't Metroid Prime.  There's a plot in there but it's pretty sh*t and no one cares for it. I don't understand why writers create plots but never bother to think, 'is this rational? Would an actual living human being with a regular IQ do this?''. That has always irritated me; I can suspend disbelief but when a file tells me that, ''we let this creature power himself but kept him effectively braindead whilst creating him; in retrospect it was a bad idea letting him power himself cause he just got out of the braindead state by powering himself''. What? These ARE scientists of high caliber, right? Where'd they get their degrees, Trump University?  Anyway it got pretty formulaic for me towards the end and there was nothing to draw me in to finishing it quickly. It's got good production values and is generally above average, but pretty formulaic. The environments are pretty to look at, even though it's all brown as ♥♥♥♥. Even hell is brown.  I came into this game with no preconceived notions as to what a Doom title should be like or what the previous games were like. So take this review from the perspective of someone that came in fresh into it. Personally I liked The New Order better since there was more depth to the experience, but this game is alright. The devs didn't fu*k up and it was a good experience, albeit nothing astounding here it still got the job done. Get it for...you know, I'd say 40 bucks or less since there's actually a lot here.

This is a true return to the olden days. DOOM is back with all the gory and glory of destroying demons. The whole package is well worth the price. To be honest the single player alone is worth the asking price.   DOOM’s single player is one of the best in recent memory. It truly trumps any FPS single player campaign of the new generation. There is no hand holding here. When you start you are thrown right into the action shooting demons right away. The progression and pacing is spot on and there is very little exposition and story here. You can find out more about the story through pda data. On the easier difficulties it can be too easy so I recommend starting out with the hardest difficulty you can. Once you beat it you can play on the highest difficulty and then you will have quite a challenge. There are a lot of secrets to be found and challenges to complete. You can also upgrade your armor and weapons and it is integrated in it seamlessly. But if you don’t like all the upgrades you can play it thru without upgrading anything and then you can have an extra challenge. The single player is truly a throwback to the old days.  Now then you have two more modes. First snap map. In snap map you can create your own levels. There are a lot of tutorials to help you get acquainted with the ins and outs. Creating levels is quite easy yet a little bit limited. But there are all kinds of options to create your own custom game modes for multiplayer to creating coop missions and single player maps. I am sure creative individuals will be creating quite the contend to keep you going back playing more of DOOM.  And then there is the multiplayer. Now the multiplayer is more akin to the olden arena shooters, but with modern tropes like loadouts and progression. The progressions is quite nice and for the most part you unlock cosmetics and at the beginning the weapons. All of the weapons you will unlock pretty quickly. The multiplayer is fun and hectic. But it’s not as good as the single player or snap map. It’s kind of in the middle. It’s definitely not the reason to buy DOOM. There is also a season pass for multiplayer content. But am not so sure the multiplayer will be relevant for long so it’s not really worth buying. Overall the multiplayer is casual fun but don’t expect it to hold you for long. And even tho the game isn’t long out there are already cheaters. And there is no anticheat system or anything so the cheaters ruin it just like every PC multiplayer game out there. The DLC season pass is also disappointing as it only includes multiplayer content.

You know those clutch moments in FPSs where you're pushing an objective? And you're in the middle of a fight? And you get that rush? That rush of adrenaline as you slam on your mouse and keyboard harder and harder, and you struggle to come out on top. THAT is what DOOM is like. This is not a CoD reskin where you can hide behind cover for a couple of seconds and regenerate all your health. This is a frantic, raw shooter game where there aren't any gimmicks that help you play, like auto-aim or regenerating health. Whether you live or die depends on your skill, and not if the dice happen roll in your favor.  There are two main components to most games: gameplay and story. Some games are mostly focused on story. Tales from the Borderlands for example. Others are more of a mixture, like Mass Effect or Half Life. DOOM is a primarily gameplay focused experience, with short snippets of story in between long bouts of gunplay. This is not to say that the story in DOOM is bad; it is very good and interesting and you can read up on the lore if you so desire. The point is that DOOM doesn't try to force-feed you story; it tries to keep the gameplay in the spotlight, but provides tools for reading up on lore if you want.  For a game like DOOM, with a large campaign and a 60 dollar price tag, replayability is a very important thing for me. I'd say that DOOM has a medium-high replayability value, for a couple of reasons. First, people are afraid that the game will get repetitive because of the cycle of run, shoot, kill, that you will often find yourself in. However, in my experience, this is not the case; with the constantly changing environments, variety of enemies, many weapon options, and challenges unique to each level, I never found myself getting bored. Secondly, the game has FIVE difficulty settings, ranging from 'I'm too young to die' to 'Ultra-Nightmare,' where if you die, your playthrough is over. The only thing that will get repetitive in DOOM is some of the story dialogue, but only after you've played the game through several times.  Overall, I think that DOOM 2016 is an amazing game where the story may get old, but the GAMEPLAY never will.

I cannot recommend this game enough. The story is rather average, but the gameplay is phenomenal - frankly, unmatched in my opinion. One of the most fun games I've ever played. You'll see an odd review here or there that's sour because it doesn't stay true to the DOOM franchise, but the real question is - who cares? I mean, honestly...play this game for 10 minutes and you'll realize you made the correct decision in picking this up.  The campaign is quite long, actually, which is a huge bonus. And its replay value is extremely high, given that it is nearly impossible to pick up all of the secrets/collectibles and complete all of the mission challenges on the first playthrough without using a guide. Not only that, but the campaign offers 5 different difficulty levels (including a perma-death difficulty which has never appealed to me), so you can play it casually or you can challenge yourself. The game can become really frantic and challenging, and getting through some of the later battles is exhilirating. You are also offered a wide variety of weapons, and can carry all of them at once, with NO reloading necessary...so swapping between weapons mid-battle just adds to the chaos.  And after ALL OF THAT...you STILL have two other features - Snapmap and multiplayer. Snapmap is a mode where players can create their own maps/scenarios, either solo or multiplayer, co-op, PVP, whatever you'd like...and post them for community play. I haven't utilized it too much to this point, and I don't see myself actually making a map in the near future, but it basically offers unlimited playability of community-submitted content. Preface: I'm only reviewing the single player portion. I haven't touched multiplayer, and probably won't until id/Bethesda fixes it.  Man, where to begin with this game?  This has been some of the most fun I've had with an FPS in years! I think it's a brilliant reimagining of the original DOOM, which I played countless hours of. If you're a DOOM veteran, I think it would be difficult for you NOT to appreciate this game. All the original enemies make a return in a glorious fashion. Some enemies even share the death animations of the original DOOM (updated for modern times, of course). The enemy AI is incredibly well done. They're tough as hell, but absolutely fair. They pursue you relentlessly. You really can't stand still in this game, or you're toast. But because it's so fast paced, that means you're constantly blasting enemies, switching guns, chainsawing for ammo, jumping on platforms, etc. I've literally exclaimed 'holy ♥♥♥♥' countless times while playing, due to the intensity  There are so many little easter eggs and hidden things in this game that it can take you hours to 100% a level. I've put 33 hours so far and I still have a few levels left, I estimate it'll be around 44 hours before I finish it. I felt that modern id really has created this as an homage to old id, and they did a great job.  With that being said, it has its flaws:  1. Glory kills are really, really wonky. Some challenges require you to perform glory kills in a certain way, and no matter how hard I try to do them, it seems impossible. I think they could use some work. With that being said though, they're still really fun to execute, and a necessary part of survival in DOOM  2. From watching videos/trailers/etc, I got the impression that you could be attacked at any moment. However, this isn't the case, and you can always tell when a fight is about to occur. Takes a little bit away from the suspense. Not a dealbreaker, though.  Those are the only flaws I can think of.  TL;DR: If you're an avid id/DOOM fan, buy this game. It's masterful and some of the most fun I think you'll have with a video game in years!

Doom is back and Bethesda did it once again. I was in love with Doom the second I installed that shareware disk that I picked up from a cash register display at Staples. This newest iteration of Doom managed to preserve its fast-paced, badass feel that made me fall in love with this franchise all over again. I really felt Doom 3 kinda stuck you in the position of taking things slow and strategizing your movements, leaning more on story and adopting the horror genre that was very popular at its time of release. Everything about this game is love-letter homage to the floppy disk original -- equipped with modern, polished and very immersive graphics, the inception of the Glory Kill (enough said), weapons upgrades and secondary options, incredible level design, grappling mechanics that allow you to reach high ledges and more. Bethesda does an amazing job with the level design and strategically placing enemy spawn points to always keep you on your toes. This is NOT the game where you dig in behind cover. Actually there's very little by way of cover, and if you want to survive, you have to run head-first into the demon hordes. This game is fast, it's in your face, it's everything it was back in 1993 save for the floppy diskettes. Now for the setbacks:  1. No local LAN/co-op 2. No private game mode 3. 6-player maximum party online  So, if you're looking for a good LAN party game, Doom has sadly exited that arena. We had set up a LAN party for release night. We had to split up into 3 parties and could not all play together. Doom was the game that introduced me to LAN parties! Sad to see it go! Wonder how they're going to adjust this for official competitive gaming?  All in all, single player is a wonderfully-emersive experience. Doom purists will certainly be more than satisfied. I certainly was, and new gamers will undoubtedly go into this iteration of Doom experiencing the feel and the spirit of the original.

The bottom line is this game will probably win every award there is for a FPS. Outstanding game play, storyline and flow. Outstanding audio, music and special vocal effects. Nice and long campaign, fantastic bang for the buck. (I didn't even try multiplayer yet) Outstanding graphics, artwork and 'environments'. Weaponry, weapons upgrading, the Praetor Suit thing...well just about everything in this game is awesome. Truly a work of art and technical expertise.   If you like PFS games, if you liked Doom 3 and Quake 4 (both of these were very good for their era), then you should really feel impressed by this iteration of Doom. Like challenges? Then this is it for you. Even the default difficulty can be very challenging for the average, ordinary player in the 'big fights'. Elite players may not think it so challenging, but there are few of these players actually. Most players are solid in their skills, even though they are not top tier. Whatever level you feel you are at, you will become a lot better player after this game. Because you will forced to improve at fighting while moving continuously, you will probable get better at the standard FPS Deathmatch, like the new COD BO3...seriously.   As the game progresses the fights get tougher. Like the reviews have said, keep moving or die! You simply cannot stay still much at all. Run and gun all the way. Fortunately the game is such that there is a very good balance of increasing challenges and weapon-Praetor Suit upgrades that keep the fighting in balance. You get to choose the nature of every upgrade to suit your style. There are plenty of choices. The last few missions have some very tough final fights, even on the default difficulty. Especially that last two missions. The 'boss' demons are challenging enough that many players will probably check out a youtube video to see how they're supposed to play the mission ending.  Then there are the 'Rune Challenges'. These are not necessary to play the game, but if you succeed in each challenge there is a reward in powerups, weapon enhancements and such that help the player handle the fighting a bit easier.   I honestly believe that the 'replayability' of this new Doom iteration is higher than anything I have ever owned. You could try playing at the next higher difficulty than default, or try different Praetor Suit configurations and weapon configurations. Maybe just replay your favorite battles and missions, or even only do the Rune Challenges for a quicky before you go to work. The Rune Challenges are actually hard enough that everything needs to be done just right to succeed.  All in all this is an exceptional fine game. I had zero glitches on the first play through on the default difficulty. The initial release is quite polished, probably more than any other FPS I've ever played...and I've played them all going all the way back to FarCry 1. Many awards await this new Doom.  At the initial $60, it's worth every penny. ANY sale pricing is a steal, litterally. You can't go wrong with this guys.  My comp specs might help in the enjoyment and emersion as I have a very strong computer. Corei7 4790K, 32 GB DDR 3 at 2400 Mhz, EVGA Nvidea GTX 980 SC, Asus Z97-A MB, NEC monitor playing at 1920 x 1200 resolution using the games chosen video recommendations, which it cranked up quite abit. A super nice headset SteelSeries Siberia Elite rounds out the show. The SteelSeries headset sound is absolutely incredible, so my game emersion as far as sound effects go is outstanding. I highly recommend playing this game with a high end headset to take advantage of the incredible work that Id and Bethesda did on the audio in this game.   Thank you Id and Bethesda, great job! This one will go down as one of the very best FPS of all time.

Ok, for everyone wondering whether to buy Doom 2016 or not: I have completed the SP and I will not spoil anything, but it is in some sense of the word a remake of the original Doom (1), so in case you where wondering about the 'story'.  tl;dr: its a good, solid, fast shooter with more under the hood that you might think.  Speaking of which: there is some very thin story running in the background just to tie set pieces (and 'objectives' - and I use this term extremely very lightly here - together). In the end, save for one or two rooms maybe this game will throw you into one arena after another and pit you against an increasingly difficult monster mix. Rinse and repeat. Sounds boring? It definitely should be and I can see how this formula can overstay its welcome, But the game manages to keep the action itself extremely interesting. For one: shooting stuff in Doom is extremely fun. The Weapons feel right and powerful, the enemies react well, you get a good sense of damage. It just works, the people who made this game knew how to make it work. The other part are the arenas and how tactics work in the world of Doom. The action is very offensive, fluid and fast paces. I you ever played Quake 3 you will get flashbacks, since it is not rare that you make some cool acrobatics just to hit that one target just right and it all fits together perfectly. As for the tactics: there is a lot of that here. Just running in blindly will get you killed, especially in the later fights. Using the territory to your advantage and especially making use of the glory kills for health, sometimes ammo or armor and also to save that one bullet, or getting in that one chainsaw takedown for ammo is crucial for survival. Since all this has to do with the enemy placement and enemy (re-) direction, these kills do not slow down the action, but reward you for risky maneuvers in sticky situations. Its a fluid, organic part of the gameplay and works extremely well as a complete package. It also forces you to make good weapon decisions. Not splattering that one imp with a rocket, but instead going for a glory kill, because you a low on health, or even saving him for an easy glory kill later on when you might be low on health or ammo is the stuff that you need to think about and that the game will teach you. Resource management is what its all about and this makes even the pistol a essential part of your armory even in later stages. Ammo is spread out juuuuust right, so that you cannot blast your way through everything with just one gun, but need to change up your tactics according to the situation, enemy type and ammo available. To change up the pace a bit, there are many, many hidden secrets. Some extremely well hidden, others a bit more obvious, but its always rewarding. be it a Doomguy Chibi-style collectible, or a mega health and armor, exploration is rewarded and will make you keep your eyes peeled at all times. Finally, there are challenges for each stage that will reward you with weapon upgrade points. This will make you try out different stuff in the levels and go for risky kills in heat of battle. Sadly, most of the upgrades don't feel like much and in the end, I simply left that part out, since all weapons where almost completely upgraded already and there are simpler ways of getting weapon points. Is Doom difficult? Well, it certainly is no Dark Souls, but the difficulty can ramp up, and I did have my fair share of deaths. I would not call it hard though, but the later battles on higher difficulties will most probably be a challenge for some people.  So, while on the outside, Doom is just one arena fight after the other, there is a lot more to it than you might see at fist glance. The game is just long enough to not overstay its welcome, but it is on the edge. the final few battles where already borderline tedious, since there are no new enemies or weapons and you start seeing the same situations a couple of times over. All in all it was a blast blasting my way through Hell and back, but before I even think about touching Snap-Map I need a break.

Now that I have gotten all achievements and have completed the game 100%, I feel like I can leave an accurate review. Let's break it down just like the main menu does.  Campaign  Positives: Some might say it was short, but if you go searching for secrets and challenges they you can end up sinking quite a bit of time on the levels. The combat was very fluid and tearing an imp's face in half is really satisfying. There are plenty of glory kills to experience as well, so approaching from different angles just to see how they die was a real time sink of mine. (Another time sink was just looking at the scenery, especially in outdoor levels.)  Bosses were actually really well done. You need to see attack patterns and dodge, attack when the time is right, and when you do, attack hard. Glory kills on bosses were well worth the effort of the fight, too.   The best part of campaign is that when you find a classic doom map secret (there is 1 per level) you unlock the full level to play on the new engine from the campaign menu.  Overall the campaign was gorgeous and really fun to play. It is the crowning achievement of the title hands down.    Negatives: Most negatives I have are simply bug-based. Sometimes progression on a challenge would not save, often the game gives and errorless crash. Another time, I was glory killing an enemy, and fell through the map and died. These types of problems are killers if you are playing Ultra nightmare. (If you die, you're done. It even leaves your helmet behind with your name and how you died as a warning to players, or just to laugh at someone's misfortune.)   A complaint that I had was that some enemies only had maybe 2 distinct glory kills, while the lesser demons like imps have upwards of 5.  The biggest negative of all was the lack of Co-op campaign. It was beyond frustrating but I understand that the campaign was built for only 1 player. Maybe next time design it as such where co-op is considered from the beginning? (Yes, I know it was stated before release that campaign would not be co-op.)   Multiplayer  Positives: This is where most people are complaining and I have to say I can't disagree with what they are saying. What I can say is that if you get your team in a group and they stick together the whole time, you will decimate any poor enemy player that happens to walk by your horde of marines.  Every gun is good in its own right but ones that stood out to me are the chaingun and lightning gun. Like any game, however, a determined player can master a gun and run with it.  Becoming the demon is very satisfying. You get a rush of 'LOOK AT ME NOW!!! HEY! REMEMBER ME FROM EARLIER!?' as you leap through the air as a prowler and snag some poor guys head to slam into the wall.   The fast paced environment is also quite hectic. Explosions, lightning, plasma, bullets and demons all at once can make for a ridiculously dodgy, fun time.   Negatives: Here is where I see some design that I wish had been done a little differently. Balancing is sometimes off. For example, you wonder why your team is losing 60 kills to 30, then you press tab and see that they have almost twice the amount of players that you do. I wish they did a better job at populating those empty team slots mid-game.  Guns feel overpowered/ underpowered at the same time. Ever wind up the chaingun and start getting hits on a guy, and while he is being hit, he winds his up and kills you first? Yeah, that. Though, in other instances, I go on a 6 kill streak with the thing. (On a side note, 2 players with lightning guns can take down an army at close quarters.)  Getting the demon rune is almost completely random. Maybe it spawns near you, maybe the entire map away. Maybe its always around some corner where an enemy is already grabbing it to kill you. Maybe you get killed as you are about to grab it for the first time in 6 matches. All of this happens on the regular.  Guns need variety. There are a handful of them and you cant even choose the attachments like in the campaign. For example, I only really use 2 loadouts because I can't put a grenade launcher on my combat shotgun so I dont need another shotgun loadout. Get what I mean?  You also unlock them super quickly. In an afternoon you have unlocked basically every weapon and demon. There will be 3 more multiplayer packs containing maps (it needs more), weapons, (it needs more), and demons (definitely needs more). Oh, and more customization for your marine. All in all its negatives don't feel like enough to make me NOT want to play the multiplayer.   Snapmap  Positives: I actually had a really fun time using snapmaps. There is a lot of potential here and I can't wait to see what some creators can make. I have already published 2 maps myself and one of them I am quite proud of. (A co-op survival/ escape map with weapon and equipment shops.) The logic and flow portions are honestly the most fun, too. I could potentially make a king of the hill map for example where there is a demon player, and a timer. If I wanted, I could make it such that killing the demon makes you the demon. If you are the demon at the end, you win.   Executing the logic is quick and easy too. You can test the maps before publishing as well which is nice, and if you happen to notice something you want to change, simply re-upload and it will replace the old version of it, regardless of name change. That is probably my favorite feature so far.   Tutorials are really easy and the puzzles are there to show you a few more examples and give you ideas and are really fun to complete. There is no shortage of reference material either. (There are youtube channels dedicated to snapmap tutorials already, so even if you can't figure it out, the answer is probably out there.)   Negatives: Co-op test play. It doesn't exist. If I want to test a co-op map, I have to publish it (i usually put beta in the title), then host and test with a friend, find a problem, go back to the editor to fix, and re-publish. Note: they side- stepped this problem with the republishing ability, so I doubt it will be changed.  Weapon varieties could be more diverse as well. If I want my team to start with the siege version of the Gauss gun, I should be able to put it in my map. If it's in the campaign it should be in the editor. It's not like a lot of competitive gameplay is going on in snapmap.  Another complaint I had on snapmap is that there werent any rooms from classic doom. You tease us with classic model options for keys, but don't allow classic rooms.  Overall, these shortcomings don't even put a dent in my opinion of the game I love it and feel it earns its spot in the Doom library.

PROS: - Graphics are great and runs at a solid 60fps on ultra on my GTX 970 - will look at uncapping that. - The level design is amazing and feels very open. Where do I start? DOOM is a pretty damn good game, although like any other game it does have its faults, I'll give you the rundown.  First of all let me get the multiplayer out of the way as I feel it is the weakest part of the game. The multiplayer in this Doom just feels like a cashout, all it is is a more gorey version of Halo and there isn't much else about it, it's pretty fun to play but it doesn't feel like it should be in this game. Not to mention the season pass ONLY has multiplayer content in it so I assure you I will NEVER pay for it, I don't know what they were thinking with that because it only splits the player base and I'd never pay money just for extra multiplayer content, the only Doom multiplayer I'll be playing is ZDaemon.   The campaign. Well this is the best part of the game because it incorporates everything we've seen in past Doom games. Great weapons, enemies, gameplay and ofcourse gore. You play as the doom guy ofcourse (or as the demons like to call you 'doomslayer') and you wake up in the UAC laboratories to once again fight like hell against the demons and take back Mars. There's a pretty interesting storyline in this game and I won't go into details but I'd say it's pretty damn good.  Weapons/Enemies. The weapons in this game are very true to the original DOOM however there are some new weapons like the Gauss Cannon and a couple different types of grenades which I never really used. The main weapons which I used most to kill enemies are probably the Super Shotgun, the Rocket Launcher and the Gauss Cannon as they do some great damage and have some good special abilities. The Super Shotgun is probably best for staggering enemies which gives you a good few seconds to fill them with some more bullets. The only problem with the weapons is that you don't really use most of them that often unless it's against a boss. You never use the pistol after you get the shotgun and you never use the shotgun after you get the super shotgun, also the chaingun is one weapon I didn't use a lot as it didn't do much damage at all in my opinion. Aside from that all the weapons are pretty damn cool and almost all have their own abilities that will help you kill more demons. The enemies mostly are the same as the previous games however there are a few new enemies like the shield guy which is pretty hard to kill because as soon as you manage to shoot his shield away he brings it back in like 2 seconds, best to use the gauss cannon against that guy. There is one enemy that doesn't seem to be in the game, the Arch-vile. However there is an enemy called the Summoner which is similar but it darts around spawning enemies and shoots out some red energy rather than yellow fire or whatever the arch-vile shoots out. There are a couple other problems with the monsters such as that the imps are a lot smaller and less threatening than in Doom 3 and the Hell Knight would of been a better fit in my opinion. Also the Pinky enemies are way stronger than in any of the other games which is odd but what's even more surprising is the invisible versions of them are way easier to kill for some reason. Aside from that the enemies look badass and can mess your day up.  Combat/Upgrades. The combat in the game is mostly like any other Doom aside from extra little things like the grenades, the weapons abilities and also the chainsaw runs on gas and you need a certain amount of gas to kill different enemies, the harder the enemy, the more gas you need, it's a great weapon for taking out the one big problem in the area in one big gorey slice. One of the main differences in combat is that you can execute every enemy when they are in a downed state, this is pretty damn fun and although you'll be doing it quite a lot it never gets old. Let's talk about the weapons abilities, You find little robots roaming around each level which can let you unlock a ability for one of your weapons, from there you can play through the game and unlock points to upgrade the abilities. These are very useful as they help alot against the bigger enemies, they do things like freeze the enemies in place, shoot barrages of rockets, extra damaging bullets and many other things. You can also upgrade your armor/suit throughout the game which can do things like negate damage from explosive barrels, help you find secret areas, increase grenade capacity and many others. But no I'm not done, there's more. You can also find another upgrade material which you can use to upgrade your health, armor and ammo capacities. This is probably one of the more mandatory things you can get as you're going to be taking a lot of hits. But wait there is more to come, there are also runes you can find throughout the level and when you interact with them you will be taken to an arena where you can do a trail to unlock a rune which is basically an extra perk that you can also upgrade to be more effective. These runes can make an enemy stay in downed state for longer, make powerups last longer and a bunch of other random stuff I forgot about. Now honestly I feel like there are WAY TOO MANY upgrades/upgradables in this game, it's like they put that in there on purpose so the game would last longer but I don't mind myself cause I like being able to slowly get stronger over the course of the game so the upgrades work pretty well.  To finalize I'll talk about some of the main things like sound, graphics and other random stuff. The graphics are amazing, even though I wasn't playing it maxed out (one day maybe I'll get the gtx 1080) it still looked pretty damn astonashing, the framerate was pretty solid most of the time aside from some slowdowns in some areas, just so you know I'm playing on a GTX 960 and honestly I never had many problems, there was one point where randomly the framerate was terrible for no reason so I had to quit out, I went back in and played for a bit longer then the game randomly closed for no reason, so I just reset my pc and had no further problems. So the graphics are pretty damn good overall and it is well optimized. The sound is great, the stomach churning gore and badass weapons sound wonderful and not to mention the music which is very true to the original Doom games, if you play you'll be sure to hear something familiar. One big problem though that I had with the game was that it felt like one of those dungeon crawler/rogue-like games alot of the time because most of the enemy encounters are after you've completed an objective in an arena-like room, once you've flipped the switch or whatever all the enemies start pouring in and you can't leave the room until they're all dead, I would have much preferred if the enemies were just spread about the maps rather than just spawning in little arenas for you to battle them in.   I've probably missed a few things or left out some information but whatever, here are the positives and negatives for people who don't care to read all my rambling.   Positives: +Awesome weapons and enemies true to the previous games +Good lengthy campaign +Lots of upgrades and collectibles +Lots of backstory and enemy information +Interesting story +Great graphics +Great sound and music +Awesome bosses  Negatives: -Very un-doom-like multiplayer -Season pass only has multiplayer content -A few bugs and glitches here and there -Way too many things to upgrade -Most of the collectibles and upgrade materials show up on the map so they're not hard to find -Some bulletsponge enemies -Not much replay value unless you want to get all the achievements and collectibles -Most enemy encounters are arena-based  Overall it's pretty solid, some problems here and there but every game has problems. I'd give it a solid 8/10 but I'd say you should pick it up on offer, unless you're loaded with cash, then just buy it at full price. If you don't mind paying $60 or whatever for about 10 hours campaign, map editor and multiplayer then pick it up.

iD has pulled it off and managed to recreate the essential FPS experience.  Fast and beautiful, this game really throws me back to Quake 1 & 2 - which I have played a LOT more than Doom 1 or 2 - while retaining some of that awesome atmosphere and presentation from Doom 3. The throwback is a good thing, mind you: instead of a corridor experience, you get actual maps brimming with secrets, rewarding exploration. Combat is visceral and sounds fantastic, while the equally awesome soundtrack blasts away and encourages you to dive into the fray head first and guns blazing.  The melee kills are a nice addition, as they provide a perfect means of staying in the fight and regain some health. Instead of taking cover, you constantly take the offensive to get an execute. Animations are short, meaning that they never interrupt the flow of the game - even more so if you use a certain rune that speeds up the glory kills significantly. Note that you can disable the somewhat unimmersive glow marker on enemies who can be finished off, which looks better, but can greatly increase difficulty.  Shooting is what you would expect from an iD game, and works very well. Enemies stagger appropriately and guns feel and sound impactful. A simple, yet effective upgrade systems adds up to two secondary fire modes to each gun which can be exchanged mid-battle. These upgrades completely change the way you can use a gun (such as the grenade launcher for your trusty boomstick) and mix the combat up enough to constantly keep it fresh. You also get to upgrade your suit and passive abilities to help you toss more grenades or find more secrets. The upgrade system, while seemingly alien to a doom / quake game, works extremely well. I am not a '100%' gamer most of the time, but here, I felt compelled to unlock all 'ultimate' attachments which is done by completing mission AND weapon addon specific challenges. Lock and load.  And you need those weapon mods, as the game - no surprise - throws progressively harder and more enemies at you. Demons and posessed soldiers behave according to the standard archetypes, closing in for melee or firing from a distance, and usually boast one or two particularly nasty moves that you want to watch out for, quickly teaching you to peel your eyes and ears for the audio and animation queues that lead up to them. I HIGHLY recommend to play on a difficulty that feels challenging to you, because combat is what this game is. Instead of shooting fish in a barrel, you fight your enemies, and you fight them hard. Ultra-Violence recommended for the first playthrough - unless you have too much trouble.  Unless the level design gets far worse from where I am currently, I must say that I am impressed and delighted by this return to form by iD Software. Highly recommended for any FPS fan. EDIT Just beat the final boss. After 25+ hours of battling and upgrading, trying to get everything there is (you can replay missions and get all the goodies) I fought the final boss which goes out with a mind-blowing bang (pun intented) and left me happy except that I wanted more. The visuals of the enemies and locations are fantastic. Animations top notch. Audio is satisfying and crisp. This game's presentation is pretty much perfect. Play it.  Note that all this applies to the single player portion ONLY: the multiplayer, which was not developed by iD software, looks bland & generic and never peaked my interest in the first place. There is plenty on that on the Tube if you are interested. It's not Quake multiplayer, and that is that for me. Odds are I'll never play it. The single player is well worth your time.

If you are a fan of the DOOM series, you owe it to yourself to buy this game. I admit, at first I was not convinced; poor multiplayer beta and was underwhelmed while watching videos of reviewers playing the beginning of the game. Despite my negative initial impression, I decided to take the plunge and bought the game on release.   I'm glad I did! This feels like a DOOM game - keeping traditional elements such as fast-paced action, monsters, and weapons, while taking advantage of modern developments today. The combat feels fantastic; at first I thought the gore kills were gimmicky, especially when I saw other people play it. In fact, it doesn't just feel great ripping a demon apart, it adds to the gameplay and keeps it unique; most modern FPS want you to take cover and reload. Not DOOM. It encourages you to dive into a demon mosh pit by ripping them apart so you get more ammo and health!   The game also makes good use of weapon upgrades, allowing them to be used in different ways for multiple battle scenarios. Although the format of combat gets repetitive, it always feels fun. Also, upgrades to both weapons and your marine are optional - if you want to play it without them for a greater challenge, go right ahead! The multiplayer is basic and pretty uninspiring (perhaps it will get better in the future), but DOOM is all about the single player experience and modding community!   I admit I am a DOOM fan boy. The original DOOM is one of my favorite games of all time and I have enjoyed all the others (including Doom 3 and Doom 64). I feel this one is particularly strong and with the addition of SnapMap's user-generated content, I believe there will be plenty of replay value.

Bottom line: If you're the type of person who enjoys a skill-based FPS with a challenging difficulty, then Doom2016 will be fun. If you play single player and you don't select a difficulty that is genuinely challenging, you will probably find the game boring and monotonous. The formula for this game is: enter new area, kill demons, auto-save checkpoint, repeat.   I'm only playing the single player campaign, and I'm playing on Nightmare on my first serious run. The game is challenging enough on Nightmare, that I find it enjoyable. Each 'fight' in an area is challenging enough that I often need to learn from multiple deaths to develop a strategy for clearing the area. (e.g. Start with gun x and kill 2 specific demons, switch to gun Y and kill the 1 demon that spawns, and jump to that ledge and snipe with gun Z, etc.) The game also has 'rune trials' which are skill-based challenges with a single weapon.   I played the first mission on Ultra-Violence, and I found it too easy. I was able to clear all kinds of fights on my first try, and I saw myself getting bored with it pretty quickly.

The single player at least is a modern classic and tons of fun.  Great level design, tons of enemy variants, tons of hidden secrets, tons of awesome weapons with weapon mods that further increase their destructive capabilities, no weapon limit, fantastic graphics, super well optimized, great boss battles, big open levels.  The large levels also have a lot of verticality to them with some platformer elements that I actually really enjoyed. They're just great fun to explore.  There's a story sort of but it's not intrusive at all and is just there for context. The little story there is, is done well enough. There's also a ton of optional lore related logs to read that give more of an understanding of the world and the situation.  The combat is one of the most satisfying since Wolfenstein The New Order. The overall quality and performance is much better than The New Order thanks to id Tech 6.  The multiplayer isn't anything that special but there is fun to be had and the Warpath gamemode is especially fun.  The campaign alone though is brutal and worth getting for.

I highly recommend this game to any FPS fan. The compaign alone, is worth your money. With non-stop action and adrenaline at its peak I am at constant state of awareness. No other game has ever provided such an experience. If you want a real challenge I recommend starting on Ultra Violence and moving up from there.

I didn't really like the original Doom game, I have to say; I was more into Quake and then absolutely fell in love with Quake 2, and Half-Life. DOOM is a very refreshing experience for a large budget FPS in 2016.   When Doom started to interest me was with the Doom 3 released in 2004, however with a mixed reception from the fans Doom 3 was generally a great atmospheric game… but it wasn't Doom, even I could recognise that. The extremely high detailed models and textures for it's time forced the game-play to be designed around more 'scary' moments with smaller fights (presumably to avoid FPS problems). This, fundamentally, was fighting with the spirit of the originals; which had fast movement, lots of guns with variety, lots of monsters on screen, and so on.  ID Software has masterfully taken the Doom IP back to the roots, and reinvented it with respect for the content, understanding of the original games, and a huge amount of passion.  So enter with DOOM (2016). This development team yet again has advanced the state-of-the-art in computer graphics (and also implementing the new 'Vulkan' rendering support API). Quite simply, the game looks and sounds absolutely amazing. Even on the lowest settings the game looks great. Pump up the settings and the game becomes something else. With the Vulkan renderer enabled there is a huge performance boost. On top of this, there are a large number of settings to play with. Wonderful effort has been put into polishing this game.   The campaign is a visceral romp into the UAC space stations on Mars, with teleportation into HELL and back again. The story writing works well, with a demon worshipping scientist unleashing hell onto Mars on the pursuit of some sort of deal with the devil. Your main mission is to close the Hell gate and destroy her (just as she is gifted her demonic form of the Spider Mastermind).   There is some interesting social commentary on 'what will mankind do to make life easier' with a hilarious take on this concept, with the UAC pumping energy directly out of Hell (and Demons too). You will come across background audio-spam from UAC hologram in visitor centres, pleading for you to just accept what they are doing.  The over-all theme is very DOOM. You got your fast movement; You got your wide selection of weapons with different utilities; You got your health and armour, and ammo resource management to consider as well.   But also takes from the Half-life era of gaming, which followed suite from Quake 2. The story plays out with your Doom Guy as a mute protagonist (just like Half Life), and they have some great exploration and platforming mechanics going on here; which is buffered with the double jump boots that you find half way along the journey.  Map design is crafted with a lot of attention to detail, bodies, notes, computer screens all dripping with the theme and horror of Hell opening up. The maps have multiple level segments, sometimes criss crossing around, giving a great range of tones for an FPS title. Other games just stick too horizontally, and become boring fast. In DOOM you are expected to move around (all demons have strong melee hits), and jump/edge grab to different levels of the map. These simple but perfectly utilised mechanics enhance the game-play and add to the visceral nature.   Battles are sometimes from traditional means, and some fights are locked in a room with spawning-in demons. What DOOM does here is 1-to-1 what you see is what you get for monsters. Other modern titles seem to have stuck to an idiotic system of infinite re-spawning soldiers that doesn't stop unless you hit invisible triggers by running forward. This is not what happens in DOOM.   You get a feeling that you are sweeping through the levels, removing the taint as you go along. You are the Doom slayer, after all. This is emphasised throughout the game-play too, from boss monsters and final bosses (that we used to have in games!)  The close combat is granted via glory kills, which you can activate when a demon has staggered from a lot of damage. While time still plays out, and demons can move around while you are camera locks into the glory kill, they don't attack until you are done. These mechanics work extremely well as they reward you with health/armour and sometimes ammo.  The special items return in this instalment of DOOM. Quad damage, invulnerability, haste, and also the new berserk mode which sets you on a spree of glory killing madness.  Weapons are found across the campaign, and so are support drones. These bots carry a weapon mod system that allows you to pick one of two paths for each weapons (usually, since the pistol and super-shotgun have no mods). The mods allow you an alternate firing mode, giving you some more flexibility in combat.  The rune system grants you bonuses (usually associated with killing and using glory kills for more rewards). The Praetor armour can be upgraded by exploring and finding tokens; Argent cells are used to boost your characters health, armour and ammo limits; and then you also get weapons modifications. None of these things were in the original games, all of them are great and work well together in this game. I got a Bioshock vibe from this game, since they allow you a wider variety of how you want to play out the campaign by offering you some choices with respect to your gear.   Overall, the single player run would be about 12 hours just gunning to the end. I played a second time on the hardest difficulty available by default (2 higher ones are presumably unlocked piece-meal). Exploration is almost a necessity, otherwise your character is significantly weaker than if you found all the upgrade mods, praetor tokens and argent cells.  I completed a second run in Ultra Violence finding all items and secrets; completing all combat missions (for extra upgrade points), and finding and upgrading all runes. This was a blast, and probably took about 22 hours to complete by itself. Some gripes: restarting a level removes everything you earned from it (how annoying), otherwise you can load to previous checkpoints and re-do some map content to level up your weapons upgrades or complete challenges). I would have liked a few more characters in the game to flesh out the plot a little more.  Overall, the story is communicated very well and you learn about your character and the DOOM universe. I presume the main arc ended on a cliffhanger, another guy (A creepy scientist in charge of the UAC who happens to have sold out his own soul by becoming a huge robot) who has power over you leaves the scene with some menacing words. DOOM is a great FPS title, a fantastic set of game design mechanics, performance and multi-player to boot (though I haven't tried that yet). It even has custom player maps with the Snap-map system. Even more DOOM for your money.  Recommend to anyone, particularly if you like fast shooters with game-play and story like Half-Life 2 (though it is simpler with very few characters in the game).

I wasn't sure I could still enjoy a game like this. First person shooters have changed since they first arrived as virtual shooting galleries in the early 90s. Games like Deus Ex and System Shock added a heavy dose of narrative and choice, and eventually led to modern classics like Bioshock and Dishonored.   The idea of a first person shooter focusing on the *shooting* almost seems quaint in 2016. Sure, Doom gives you a few side missions here or there, and the ability to upgrade your weapons a bit. But this is hardly an RPG in disguise. This is a chance to dive in, move fast, and shoot demons in the face.  I thought I had outgrown that.   I was wrong.  Doom is an easy contender for the best game of 2016. It's unapologetically fun. It never takes itself too seriously. The weapons are powerful and cathartic. It provides a stiff challenge without being unfair. And, amazingly for a Bethseda product, it is almost freakishly well optimized, running smooth as silk with the settings cranked up high.   It's a must-play. And that's coming from someone who rolled his eyes when it was first announced.

As someone who grew up with the original DOOM, I can say that they really nailed the feeling of the classic while modernizing in all the right ways. I don't mean story-wise, I mean mechanically. For instance, I have been playing ultra-nightmare on this game for a while now. I've never made it past the 7th level, and I have died many times on the first level. I've probably played the opening battle 200 hundred times... and the damn thing is different every single time! It's literally never the same battle twice, even though I often approach it in the same way. It's challenging every single time. I'm still astonished at how frickin perfect the combat feels and how entertaining it is to kill these demons. As for the multiplayer, I don't understand all of the criticism. It's a lot of fun and they are constantly adding to it. Buy even if the multiplayer didn't exist at all (and I haven't even messed around with snapmap yet) this game would be worth the money just for the single player campaign alone.

id did an outstanding job in this modern approach to the classic fast-paced, arcade-style first-person shooter.  DOOM is balanced differently than most other FPSes. The overarching principal of gameplay is 'push forward' combat: demons move fast and can quickly inflict lots of damage, there is no regenerating health or cover system, and your ammo limits are lower and can be quickly exhausted. To offset this, enemies drop significant amounts of health and ammo, often in types you're low in. The result is that you need to actively fight to survive—while there are situations where you can snipe a few demons to reduce their numbers before moving in, you need to stay in motion or you'll get mauled quickly. The ammo limits and fast-paced combat also means you need to be able to make tactical decisions like choosing weapons quickly—you cannot just rely on one weapon for most fights. The end result is a dynamic and intense shooter experience that tests both your reflexes and your wit.  Levels are remarkably detailed and the game plays well even on older (albeit high-end) hardware. On my laptop (Core i7-4800MQ, overclocked GeForce GTX 780M), the game plays smoothly on (auto-detected) medium settings at 1080p, maintaining a stable 40-60fps. Vulkan support helps a bit as well, though not as markedly as it does on AMD GPUs (detailed performance metrics indicate the game is GPU-bound on my machine regardless of whether OpenGL or Vulkan is selected).   One caveat for those picky about DRM: This game uses Denuvo Anti-Tamper. id did an outstanding job in this modern approach to the classic fast-paced, arcade-style first-person shooter.  DOOM is balanced differently than most other FPSes. The overarching principal of gameplay is 'push forward' combat: demons move fast and can quickly inflict lots of damage, there is no regenerating health or cover system, and your ammo limits are lower and can be quickly exhausted. To offset this, enemies drop significant amounts of health and ammo, often in types you're low in. The result is that you need to actively fight to survive—while there are situations where you can snipe a few demons to reduce their numbers before moving in, you need to stay in motion or you'll get mauled quickly. The ammo limits and fast-paced combat also means you need to be able to make tactical decisions like choosing weapons quickly—you cannot just rely on one weapon for most fights. The end result is a dynamic and intense shooter experience that tests both your reflexes and your wit.  Levels are remarkably detailed and the game plays well even on older (albeit high-end) hardware. On my laptop (Core i7-4800MQ, overclocked GeForce GTX 780M), the game plays smoothly on (auto-detected) medium settings at 1080p, maintaining a stable 40-60fps. Vulkan support helps a bit as well, though not as markedly as it does on AMD GPUs (detailed performance metrics indicate the game is GPU-bound on my machine regardless of whether OpenGL or Vulkan is selected).   One caveat for those picky about DRM: This game uses Denuvo Anti-Tamper. While this is not an issue for most players as it is vastly less intrusive than the old StarForce or SecuROM DRM systems (it certainly isn't an issue for me), it does need reactivation on hardware changes and imposes an activation limit of 5 per 24 hours, which may impact players who switch computers or change hardware very frequently.   Edit:  Denuvo protection was removed in Update 5.  This game is a must-buy for anyone who's a fan of fast-paced shooters.  Recommended.

***I bought this game on Xbox One, and then I got it on PC when I finished building myself a PC because it was on sale, so I have over 24 hours of this game that aren't here because I played it on Xbox originally.***  -SINGLEPLAYER SECTION-  The singleplayer has tons of hours of enjoyment and is open to let you stick around the levels hunting for secrets. Level design is really good and the model details are amazing. Animations are fluid, cutscenes are short. In fact that are barely any cutscenes.  The level of settings there are is really good, and you don't even have to change everything if you don't want to with the presets for graphical/advanced settings. The game runs really well.   Gameplay is great. It feels like the original DOOM. Sometimes I've run on into a room and fought everything and other times I hid behind corners and ran away. That was the original DOOM. The amount of secrets and the difficulty of finding most of them is great. I find myself going back and fourth searching for some things, and if you don't want to do that you can always just go on your way. The feature of going back to the original levels is nostalgic while also feeling new. I love just how different the levels are. One of the things missing from the original was an almost puzzle like feature, but I feel that's fine.   If you want this game for anything other than hunting for secrets, hiding from enemies, and fast-paced fighting, then you're out of luck. This doesn't have crazy mechanics or advanced puzzle solving, it's just 'go in there and kill everybody.' One mechanic it does have however is 'glory kills.' Glory kills are a way to make you get upclose and use melee. I think they really improve the fun factor of the gameplay without ruining the fast-paced fighting. They're short animations.   -MULTIPLAYER SECTION-  While singleplayer is amazing, multiplayer feels at least 'OK.' Personally if I had to vote on a DOOM that was only the multiplayer it would be hard deciding whether or not to recommend it. It feels kind of boring because nothing goes on half the time. Not even music plays during the game, (which is fine, but added with how you aren't even fighting a lot of the time, it makes it a bit more boring.) The multiplayer fighting is pretty fun. There are level systems as most multiplayer games go and there are power ups like turning into a demon. The demon part is fun because it switches up how you play. As soon as you get to become a demon you have to use different weapons and everything, which can make the game fun. To be honest I never played much of the multiplayer, so this review is technically only for Team Deathmatch. I MIGHT edit this later if I play any of the other multiplayer stuff.  Lots of customization for your character. You can do the weapons, which have individual parts to put colors and patterns on, you can do your character which has tons of different models, and you can change your loadouts/modules.  It does have fun parts and boring slow parts sometimes, but the one thing I absolutely hate is the amount of multiplayer DLC. There's a lot of this stuff that they're still releasing. They even have achievements for this stuff. I'm actually glad they're not releasing singleplayer DLC though. I dont want to spend 50 dollars for them to add a couple things. I'd rather wait for another game, even if it means years.  -SNAPMAP SECTION-  Snapmap feels very nice. You can do so much with it. Creating levels is easy to do and there's so much you can create. There is soooo much decoration to this thing it's like DOOM's version of Planet Coaster's building. Beside any of the decoration there is also triggerable things such as audio files. There is a lot of stuff for that. I mean someone built a piano out of all the stuff. It's always fun looking at what people have uploaded. I have not played snapmap in a couple months but from what I remember there was a limit to things. Enemy limits. Building size limit (while this itself is okay, the game limits this a lot.) But overall snapmap is good.  -CONCLUSION/ETC.-  Soundtrack is amazing. I turned down the voices and effects to hear the music more. I listen to this with Apple Music all the time. It's industrial metal through most of the music and it switches to almost fully electronic music near the end (of both the soundtrack and the game.) It fits the theme of how brutal Hell is and all the sort of energy in Hell and electronics of Mars.   In conclusion this review was probably way too long. so LISTEN HERE IF ITS TOO LONG. Overall this game is amazing. Everything fits the feeling of Hell and Mars and the gameplay feels like I could never stop playing it over and over. While multiplayer is kind of boring and that sucks, singleplayer and snapmap are both very good and both have a lot to offer. Overall this game feels amazing and is easily one of my favorites.  ***If you have any suggestions for how I could improve this review, please post in the comments. I'm not going to try to shorten this review though.***

I think the original Doom was one of my first games on PC back in 1993. It was revolutionary and I have so much good memories with that game that it's really hard to surpass it. In fact the Doom (2016) can't surpass it. Can't because it's a totally different game. It's good, visually nice, but today's FPS games can't really give back that old Doom feeling. If we compare it to the old game, it's a completely different gameplay. Enemies are far fewer but more skilled of course.  In my opninion the developers did not even want a pure FPS game (in the the classes original meaning), they wanted some kind of survival horror feeling. Unfortunately for me it failed to give me the horror. You get too soon, too many weapons and never seem to run out of ammo. This means you always feel completely safe. That's not really good for a survival horror wanna be game.  On the other hand the shooting/combat part is fun. So if you take the game as pure FPS it's good. HUGE id Software and classic DOOM fan. Was skeptical of this game initially but it's turned out to be very metal and fun. The gameplay model isn't my favorite à la Painkiller where you're fenced in till the last enemy is slain but it's tolerable. Glory kills are a big aspect of gameplay that do an interesting job of giving you a second to orient yourself as you slaughter wave after wave of demons. The best glory kills belong to the chainsaw which are hilariously brutal. It gets even better with berserk mode which is ridiculously violent where you don't merely pummel demons to death but rip them apart with your bare hands. You don't get any more metal than that. I think my favorite feature has to be arcade mode and centering the gun to make it like classic DOOM. Playing it like this in arcade mode brings this game very close in feel to the original DOOM which is an extremely impressive feat.  Now as far as the game's aesthetics go, the id tech 6 engine is superb. id Software continues to remain competitive, if not the leaders, in 3D game engines despite John Carmack's departure. Even on low settings everything looks stellar. I think a lot of this is owed to exciting, varied map design.   What I'm not a fan of--and this is subjective and totally irrelevant if you're artistically ignorant (I'm an opinionated b*****)--is the look of the demons. I don't know who the f*** the art lead was on this project but they did an awful job and took this in more of a complex alien than simple demon direction which I HATE with a passion. None of these demons look fierce or beastial. They look like they were designed by hack comic book artists with all this unnecessary detail and these stylized pointed shapes to them that make them look more comical than *believable*. Cyberdemon and spider mastermind look absolutely stupid. I would have liked to have seen more serious, classic-looking demons without such an obnoxious art direction. Wish Adrian Carmack had been lead. At least they stayed close to the DOOM 3 design for the hell knight which looks tough.   The soundtrack by Mick Gordon (of Wolfenstein: The New Order and Killer Instinct) is the best game soundtrack I've heard since the original Metal Gear Solid. It's LOUD, metal and has a noisy, industrial sound reminiscent of previous id collaborator Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails. When the demons start swarming in and you've got this music on your side, it gives you added strength. Incredible soundtrack.  On the subject of audio, I do however wish to opine that some of the guns sound a little underwhelming like the shotgun and assault rifle. This is very disappointing particularly because you hear the sounds so much. The gauss cannon probably sounds the most powerful and devastating of all the weapons.   As for the story itself, it's quite dull, unfortunately. I could barely pay attention in most scenes with dialogue and I don't even understand or recall the origin they give to our character or why you wake up chained to a table. Nothing shocking or exciting or memorable even, but this can be forgiven as this is DOOM/id Software and story has never been the studio's strong point. (Recall John Carmack's quote: 'Story in a game is like a story in a porn movie. It's expected to be there, but it's not that important.') Honestly, I've never even played a game for the story but I really do appreciate good writing. Alas, none to be found here.   Finally, what I MUST give praise for is the decision to NOT give DOOM guy a voice or lines. After Dead Space 2 and Fallout 4 where our characters were imposed with a voice (thereby ruining both games for me) rather than it left to our imaginations, I was worried DOOM may have been the next victim. Fortunately, id stayed true to the franchise and didn't fall victim to this. THANK YOU!   To sum up, DOOM (2016) isn't artistically perfect like classic DOOM but it does succeed in having rather fun gameplay and replayability: an absolute must which is what keeps me firing up classic DOOM year after year.
