Absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing savage, what a true DOOM reboot should be, and one of the best FPS games I have played in years. I have played DOOM since 1993 and still play and make maps to this day for the originals. So my review is based on how it it as a reboot to the series, and how it pits itself against modern FPS games. 10/10 for the Single Player.  The weapon system is awesome, choosing what upgrades to use, when you want to use them, switching between each weapon flawlessly and quick feels so fluid.  The monsters are designed beautifuly, including the bosses who are heaps better than what DOOM 3 had to offer, anytime I would see the \'Arch Vile\' (Summoner) I would actually go into panic mode as it was the only monster that I had issues with.   The enviroments are absolutely beautiful and detailed as hell.   The music is badass and fantastic, the OST needs to be released, I would happily pay money for it.  The action is actually extremely fast paced in SP and a blast. There wasn\'t a dull moment in DOOM that I could find.   The optimization for this game too is amazing, only running a 950m and i7-4720HQ and can play this game flawlessly. 30 ish FPS on medium, and 45ish FPS on low. (Yes I know time for an upgrade but building a PC when the 1080 comes out.)  I loved this game so much I bought it twice, once for PC and once for PS4.  Multiplayer 7/10  Don\'t get me wrong, I love the multiplayer, i\'ve had a blast with it. But I personally didn\'t think it lets itself up to be what it could have been. Loadouts, and game speed are the killer for me. Other than that, the multiplayer is great, tons of stuff to unlock, badass armour to equip, and running a match where you absolutely dominate just feels so great. The demon runes too are a blast to play as, as well. But all in all, besides Demon Runes, the multiplayer doesn\'t offer too much new ideas. Still fun though. (Biasm due to obsession with DOOM as a whole may be included in this multiplayer review.)  SnapMaps 5/10 hopefully 9/10 in the coming months, and 7/10 if you don\'t know how to or never will mod.  As of right now, Snapmaps is a boring, useless tool, and I don\'t see many great things come of it... yet...  12 monster limit, bugs in the logic (weird bugs.), limited things about the way you can build maps, and the presets are boring as hell. Spent 2 full days making a map, and probably won\'t ever make a map again. If I only got the game on PS4, I probably would rate it higher as it is a wonderful map editor for console. But for PC, it is ♥♥♥♥. Doom needs true modding support, and there should be way less limitations on snapmap for PC. Plus no boss monsters on snapmap? Disappointing. Although ID/Bethesda plan to release a lot more content for snapmap, I don\'t see it ever becoming a replacement for modding support. However for people who can\'t or never will pick up modding it will be great for you. Also the menu\'s for navigating snapmap maps is a mess right now, with the same content appearing on the front page all the time.  There is work that needs to be done for snapmaps at the moment. A lot of work.  My 4th and final critisicm of the game is no modding support as said above. Hopefully someone can find a way to make modding possible, but as of right now I don\'t see that happening for a long time.  As for DLC, if all they plan to release is multiplayer related DLC and snapmap related DLC, I think they are going in the wrong direction. The fans (from what i\'ve seen and including myself) want Singleplayer DLC.   Other than that here\'s a recap.  Singleplayer: 10/10 Multiplayer: 7/10 Snapmaps 5/10, 7/10, 9/10?  The Singleplayer experience alone trumps the MP and snapmaps enough that I highly, highly recommend it to anyone who likes FPS games/ DOOM games/ or action games.  PS. If you love Devil May Cry, or DMC, you will find this game right at home for you.

Every time I receive a weapon upgrade from a flying robot I punch the hell out of it for absolutely no reason. This is Doom.   The campaign does everything right that the multiplayer (and Doom 3) did wrong. This is the classic Doom experience dropped into the excellent id Tech 6 engine while still preserving the rules/gameplay that defined the original. Modern updates to the formula, such as weapon/suit upgrades, serve only to enhance the core experience rather than re-defining it. Anyone for whom Doom was a formulative gaming experience will quickly fall back into the rhythm here, while those who cut their teeth on Halo/COD might feel like fish out of water temporarily but will fall in quickly with a bit more investment.   Gameplay is fast and furious with the original Doom 'glide' in full effect. No reloads, no cover shooting, this is a game that rewards aggression and constant forward momentum. That would be a problem if the engine/mechanics didn't support it, but the movement and shooting are as tight as any arena shooter in recent memory. The new execution mechanics fit perfectly into the aggressive/fast gameplay style, and along with the chainsaw (which generates ammo) incentivize a pace that comes as a breath of fresh air after a decade of duck-and-reload shooters.   Bottom line, if you have any fondness for the early PC FPS era or you want to try out a new experience that feels significantly different from other modern shooters, you can pick up Doom without concern that it throws the baby out with the bathwater. This is a labor of 90s-era FPS love, and you can feel it every time you shotgun an imp and then explode its head with your bare hands.

After recently finishing the new DOOM, I decided I should share my opinions and thoughts on if you should buy the game. In this review, we will be looking at the Pros, Mixed, and Cons of DOOM (2016)  Pros: + Extremely fun and satisfying gameplay. As everybody knows, DOOM is a FPS, but DOOM (2016) is not Doom 3. The gameplay is extremely fast paced like original DOOM games, like The Ultimate Doom and Doom 2. As much as I liked Doom 3, I found it extremely slow and at some points boring. DOOM solves this greatly by making it extremely fast paced, which is something I think fans of the original game were looking for.  + The graphics are extremely good, especially when set to higher settings. This game graphics much better than Bethesda's Fallout 4, which were showing the age of Skyrim's engine. Also, it runs a lot smoother than Fallout 4, which only adds to the gameplay of DOOM, allowing it to be fast paced.  + An extremely long  story  campaign. The game will take you around 12-13 hours to beat, or at least for me it did.   + Tons of replay value. In Wolfenstein: The Old Blood, I noted how I thought the game was fun, but there was this section that took me more than 2 hours to beat, because it had force stealth (When stealth is forced upon to beat a section or at least make it barely impossible) in it, which ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off greatly. However, very few sections in DOOM are frustrating. If I died, I felt that it was usually my fault and it was not extremely difficult to the point of making it a chore to play, except for the Final Boss, but what do you expect. I would honestly replay this game, especially since how fun it was.  Mixed: - SnapMap and Multiplayer are not that good. I would have put this at cons, BUT I am thankful that they at least tried it. Wolfenstein: The New Order nor Wolfenstein: The Old Blood had multiplayer, which makes me happy that they at least tried it. I haven't really tried Snapmap, but from looking at it, it is something that could have potential in the future.  - No modding tools except for Snapmap. This could be considered a killer for some people, but I need people to remember if the core game itself isn't good, but mods make it better, than the game is not good.  Cons: - Crashes. Throughout my entire experience, I had around 5-6 desktop crashes and one full computer crash, which was annoying. Luckily, I did not have to restart a major part or lose any of my data, but I would imagine it being hell if anybody had to restart the entire campaign because of a crash corrupting their saves.  - Glitches. At first, I was surprised at how I experienced NO glitches. UNTIL mission 12, where I experienced a major glitch, forcing me to restart at the checkpoint. Basically, an enemy was invisible and impossible to hit. I looked around for maybe 20 minutes, trying to find this enemy, but could never do so. I gave up and was forced to restart from a checkpoint.   FINAL VERDICT  9.5/10  That is my review of DOOM (2016). I recommend buying this game right now, by right now, I don't mean a minute, I mean RIGHT DAMN NOW. This game is extremely fun and it is worth every penny. I hope they make a sequel and I am damn excited for the DLC.

SP Campaign  Love the single-player campaign. Playing on Nightmare to start and the game is challenging, which is refreshing for an FPS. The game is very much focused on the gameplay over mechanics such as QTEs and cutscenes. Like Dark Soul 3 or Alien Isolation, I recommend you play on harder difficulties to get the most out of the experience. If it's too easy, you'll get bored.  Multiplayer  Multiplayer is solid as long as you don't go into it with expectations that it was supposed to be Quake. Warpath and Clan Arena stand out as solid competitive modes. There are some imblanaced weapons at the moment, but that can be easily corrected. Customization is solid and there's no pay-to-win features. If the game had competitive matchmaking in the same vein as CS:GO, it would be golden.  SnapMap   SnapMap has a lot of potential and reminds me of the Starcraft 2 level editor and Arcade mode. I'm looking forward to what people create with it. I played through several of the pre-populated maps at launch with some friends and we had fun. If they provide additional toolsets for this, we could see some really great maps.  This game is worth the money. If you're even remotely on the fence, I recommend getting it.

When it came to gameplay, I absolutely loved the short time I spent playing Doom. The gfx were wonderful, the gameplay happened at a rapid pace, and I was starting to get involved in the SP story line. Unfortunately, I happened to be a victim of the developer mode bug. In a nutshell, out of blue I received a notification that I was put into developer mode, and as a result certain features of the game were disabled. According to the dev message, the solution is to delete my SP Game save and start from scratch. Unfortunately, this did not work. Even deleting the files and folders in C:\Users\me\Saved Games\id Software\ did not solve the problem (there are a few more steps that I followed to try and resolve this problem, but I digress). When I first open the game after deleting the files I can play just fine. However, as soon as I quit Doom and then re-launch, I get the 'you are in Dev mode' error.  Fortunately, I had played the game for less than 2 hours so I just ended up requesting and receiving a refund from Steam.  If it wasn't for this absolutely horrible bug, I would definitely recommend this game. In the end, I simply cannot recommend purchasing at this time until Bethesda releases a fix (as of 06-02 this bug has been met with silence).  Honestly, I have no idea how many people its affecting; for all I know it could be less than 1%. That being said, there is currently a 500+ post thread on Steam regarding this issue. Ironically, the thread was started by a Bethesda Developer. Long story short, if the Dev Mode bug gets resolved, I will definitely purchase the game again. Otherwise, I am happy with my refund!  Just FYI, I strongly recommend any new purchasers test out their Doom install as soon as possible to determine whether or not you are affected by this bug (If you play the game for more than 2 hours, Steam will not give you a refund). Based on my experience, the best way to determine if you are affected is to simply exit out of the game and then re-launch it. If you receive a message about network services being disabled and dev mode being enabled, you are most likely affected by this bug. Honestly, you should perform the exit/relaunch process as many times as possible. Some people don't run into this issue until they are hours into the game. IMO there is simply nothing you can do to fix it at this time.  Hopefully Bethesda will at least post an update as to whether or not they are planning on fixing this.

There's pretty much no reason for me to write this review, but I'm going to anyway.  This game is what happens when a legendary developer does not become a crippled abomination over time. Growing fantastically into the new age of next generation gaming, id brings yet another one-ton diamond to the table with one of the most replayable, entertaining, satisfying shooters of all time.   The weapons are punchy, the executions are fast and brutal, and few games will give you the sense of classic joy that this game brings. Run and gun, blast demons back to Hell, all to the tune of sick metal riffs. If we were worried that this Doom would follow the path of Doom 3, we can set those worries aside.  Multiplayer is wicked fast and great fun, requiring speed, prediction, and coordination.   The Snap Map is brilliant, and I can't wait for updates or DLC to add new parts and pieces to play with.  That said, sometimes the formula gets a little bit stale in both visuals and set pieces. In general, you walk around, look for secrets, stumble upon this hellish portal looking thing, rip a flesh blob off to shut it down, and then fight the inevitable demon wave. This is basically on repeat. Despite the beautiful visual effects, there's so much red and orange that you'll actually notice when things are different colors. This can lead to occasionally stale environments, which don't combo well with the aforementioned 'shut down portal, fight monsters, repeat.'  Regardless, you'll be hard pressed to notice its few missteps when you're curb stomping a demon with his own leg (that is an actual thing you can do), or desintegrating the upper half of a huge demon with a two-handed gauss cannon.  Buy it. You won't regret it.

DOOM 4 is a great addition to the series, for a modern rendition of DOOM it did a fantastic job.   TL;DR: DOOM 4 singleplayer is fun as ♥♥♥♥ and it's good, multiplayer is mediocre, snapmap is p gud.  Honestly when they announced and showed off DOOM 4 I wasn't impressed, what's this bull ♥♥♥♥ glory kills? why is it slow? I play ALOT of doom 1-2 and still do to this day using Zandronum. But after playing through the single player and 100%ing it, I can say that it's a blast. It's a lot faster than it seemed when they showed it, the action is fast paced and brutal.  Yes it is a modernized DOOM, but that's not really a bad thing when it's done right, if you want to play classic doom, just go play classic doom man. Glory kills are almost completely optional (bosses require it to FINISH them off) but I never found myself really getting tired of all the different ways Doom guy can murder a demon, sometimes it feels good to get up close and personal!   The maps are mostly nonlinear in exploration and the secrets are all pretty damn good, I had to go to some maps several times to find them on my own, the game kept getting more interesting at it went on, none of the maps felt too similar to each other.  We see a lot of returning weapons with a modern flash, with some weapon mods to spice things up. The guns felt great to use for the most part and most of them have 2 different mods to choose from, allowing for a secondary function. Being able to upgrade your armor and weapons is a welcome change in my opinion, fully upgraded you feel stronger, but not cheaply invincible, especially on higher difficulties.  The singleplayer is a love letter to first person shooters in this modern age, maybe we'll see more of it. Multiplayer on the other hand is pretty forgettable, the net code or something feels off and the modern 'load out' function is 'eh' I don't really have much to say about it, it's fun in short bursts but it's not really something many people will find themselves playing all night.  Snap map is pretty interesting and has a lot of options on creating unique levels, I spent a couple hours in it and made a map and found it to be kinda fun, a bit clunky to use but legit none the less. I never really mastered it or played too many maps but I really liked it, don't have much else to say.  Also the added lore is pretty decent, doom boy is a fantastic protag, A+

Summary: Singleplayer is best part, rest is pretty mediocre, wait for sale ~$40 maybe lower of possible. 8/10 Singleplayer, 3/10 Snapmap, 6/10 multiplayer  Firstly i'd like to mark this review as mixed. this is made for the general gameplay. Now out of the 3 main features (Singleplayer Campaign, Snapmap Creation/Co-op, Multiplayer) i'd give  this a 2/3  [Singleplayer Campaign] [1] Now this is the most quality you will get out of this game, from what i've played  (which atm is not alot but enough to write this) it has the most features, its the  most 'Doom-like' you could probably get with a little extra like moddable weapons and collectables im honestly having a blast with single player, this should be the reason you buy it if you do.  -probably the biggest thing wrong with the campaign is no co-op in the campaign which I find to   be strange that they didn't add it seeing that doom 3's Co-op mods were fairly much the most   wanted mods out of it's time, from what i've heard. hopfully they will add it in a future update   or even a DLC. but them not adding co-op is such a dissapointment to me but whatever.  [SP][Speed] The gameplay does feel fast (a bit faster than multiplayer) but it's clunky, if you like a challenge  and play on nightmare you need to be able to move fast and fluidly but quite a bit of the enviorment seems to grab at your feet and completely stops you (at least that's been my experience since I tend to jump around everywere)  +Along with jumping around, the levels seem to be pretty open and in some cases require back tracking  [SP][Glory-Kills] I do have to say that I love the glory kill system, letting you rip apart the demon horde and take a small bit of health after, but one thing that does bother me is when you run up to a 'Glory Killable' guy and Rip him apart in that time you could get surrounded by nearby demons and just get over run, not really a down for me since I usually try to go for em as much as I can without thinking but it just get's annoying, not really a down just a note.  [SP][Checkpoints]  This is just a personel thing for me but I hate the idea of checkpoints, sure there handy but I much rather manually save like the original doom. sure it prevents 'save-scumming' but why should the devs care about that when it comes to the game as a whole, and the checkpoints tend to be fairly far appart as a note. why they didn't include both, who knows...  [SP][Will update if i forgot anything]   [Snapmap/Co-op] [.5] In all honestly the snapmap feels like it was definitly made for console players, being that it doesn't really let you create that much on your own, from what i've seen you can make little scripts for when you walk into a room and a load of demons spawn but that really seems like themost advanced you could get. the 'Snap' feature just feels like your putting templates on top of templates inside of templates, not really that much for people who really want to go crazy and make a game inside of a game, or just make a good map in general.  -This was a big dissapointment but atleast they put some kind of co-op, just not the   co-op the fans (who wanted co-op) wanted.   [Multiplayer] [.5] Pretty much a copy and paste multiplayer, feels like a zippier halo, still fun but gets old fast. and from what i've seen people have been getting a harsh time with match making which is a bit bad. there is a leveling system that unlocks weapons but atleast the weapons have a short level lock, shortest being level 14 for the last weapon and level 17 for the last playable demon. -and as a note the multiplayer to my knowledge wasn't made by id, why they gave up on the multiplayer and handed it to the people who made the halo 5 (i think) multiplayer I dont know why but they really shouldn't have, that could of saved the game from it's pretty mediocre feel when it comes to the WHOLE game.  +The multiplayer is still fast paced to a degree and does require a bit of skill but still, zippier halo.   [ALL in ALL] wait for a sale for like $40 at most, not really worth $60/$80(Australia/New Zealand) when the most you'll get out of it is a pretty good single player campaign and a Copy and paste multiplayer that gets boring after a while but still kinda fun if your into it.  If you want doom with co-op i recomend one of the many Doom modding platforms, not sure which ones are still alive but there out there.  sorry id, but atleast you made a great campaign.

Notice : this mini review is only about the single player campaign of the game for now.  It took me a couple of hours of gameplay before I started to fall in love with DOOM (all over again!). Apparently, games and gaming develop new ideas relatively slowly, because although I thought I remembered exactly what it felt like to play the first generation shooters, I was initially stunned when faced with a cutting edge, modernized version of the simplistic format in the DOOM reboot.  Like so many have already observed, it's basically fast-paced closed area arena combat - one after another. Repeat. Prepare for the next battle. But as your skills improve, it grows on you. You start to see little things. Like how much the devs must have enjoyed putting this or that over-the-top display of gore and violence into the design. In the end, It's all about the attitude of the protagonist. Anger could hardly be simpler as a theme and motivation, but it just works. Cranking up the volume, tasting blood in my mouth, I charge into the  face  of the towering monster, tear it to pieces and love it all!

(I make it a point to not do long reviews, so this is pretty off-the-cuff.)  This is definitely an FPS for people with ADHD. There is almost zero opportunity for you to go slow. At first, the game eases you into the idea of getting your @ss handed to you by being pretty laid back with the enemies, to the point you might even be disappointed. After all, DOOM is about waves and waves of enemies, right?   However, somewhere near the end of your first main objective, though, you'll find yourself starting to sweat a bit, even on Ultra-Violence (the first, highest difficulty you can play until you unlock/tweak the higher difficulties)  (I do appreciate any scientific installation that has a 'Demonic Invasion in Progress' warning already cued up, though. So, in the world, someone had to honestly say 'You know, we have all these warnings about disasters... What about if we're overrun with Demons? We should have a warning for that.'... And someone on the Safety Team agreed.)  Overall; there's zero reason to have a plot in this game. I have no idea why they even bothered. DOOM does not need a plot, unless it's to avenge the death of your bunny!  Weapons are, eh. Standard FPS faire, each with a sharp throwback to the originals. Even the current stand in for the BFG is alright. I'm a fan of the Pulse Cannon and the shotgun/mortar combo, personally. Melee being added in makes for some interesting fights, and the Glory Kills never get old.  Where DOOM really shines, though, is the fact that peppered all throughout the game are little touches and throwbacks to the original games, especially once you stumble into Hell -- which, to date, is probably my favorite rendition, even beating out Painkiller.  Is the game worth the hype? Hell Yes. It just depends on how much 'HYPE' you pay attention to. it's a shooter that requires at least a bit of strategy for each room; can't say that about too many FPS' today. The real clincher for me is that there were plenty of points where I forgot precisely how long I was playing -- this goes for SP and MP as well. If nothing else, that's a mark of quality.

Excellent modern retelling of classic DOOM. Within seconds the game makes you clear you are here for one thing only: to kill all the demons infesting a Mars colony. The story is pretty much literally thrown out the window! And that is just the way it should be.  The guns feel hefty and that makes it great to shoot things. Each weapon also has two weapon mods for alternate fire modes. Also back is finding many secrets, with expansive levels full of nooks and crannies to explore. Technically the game performs marvellously, with 70-80 fps on my GTX 970 on 1440p and more importantly: no hiccups.  Doomguy must be pretty angry, since he just rips demons in half with his bare hands... New to the game are glory kill executions that fortunately animate swiftly, and grant the player health and (later on) armor. So as long as you are slaughtering demons without getting hit too much, you can keep your dance of death going. The selection of demons hasn't been changed all that much (mostly DOOM and DOOM II enemies), but they do have received more interesting movement patterns and some new attacks.  Also new, are some very interesting weapon and character upgrades that require you to skillfully kill demons with the weapons' alternate fire modes, as well as arcade style challenge arena's that require you to skillfully kill demons.   The multiplayer is not very interesting (although perfectly funtionable), but the single player is absolutely fantastic. A great way to channel any agressive feelings you might have. :) There's also Snapmap that allows you to create, share and play user created maps. I have not tried Snapmap yet as of writing. What I miss the most is campaign coop, although Snapmap does support coop with up to 4 players.  All in all: what a blast, DOOM is back! Highly recommended game.

Ever since it's announcement since last year's E3, I've been looking forward to it. Every piece of footage they've shown since then has gotten me even more hyped for it. When they said they were holding review copies until release, even I was scared. Scared but hopeful. I've been playing the original doom games since i was young, they're some of the finest games ever made, and I was hoping so much that this would be good.  Then it came out.  And it's completely blown me away  I'm incredibly happy with this game. I've been wanting a game like this for a long time, and finally, i've gotten an amazing one. It's just demons, guns, gore, and a good bit of story for those interested  The single player is undoubtable the main selling point of the game, and best part of the experience. It alone is well worth the price of admission. With a length of around 10-16 hours for your first playthrough, not a single moment was boring. Every second of this game is exhilerating and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing. Weapons are satisfying to shoot, enemies are satisfying to kill, even the pre-canned execution animations are so fast they don't break up the pace of the game at all.  This game makes you feel POWERFUL, but soft. You can ♥♥♥♥ up enemies in record times with powerful weaponry, but on harder difficulties you are also quite squishy yourself, which combined with the speed of the game makes an extremely skill-based experience (A quick note, the game feels a lot faster with a high FOV. It's not super slow at 90, by any means, but at 130, you rEALLY feel the rush of moving extra fast, and it makes it more enjoyable). The weapon attachments are a nice touch to the game, along with the armor upgrades, adds for a bit of nice progression through the story, that can be completely ignored if you want of course. The enemy types from the originals are all there too, colorful and with great silouhettes and sound effects that let you know what you're going up against. They all have a really nice redesign, but elements of the original design are kept, that make many of them instantly recognizable as the classic demons you know and love. They have excellent AI too, they don't all just run at you blindly, they all act differently, be they an imp, running away and grabbing walls to line up a good shot, or a hell knight, relentlessly hounding you and attempting to beat your face in. They're all expertly designed to make you prioritize targets and make the senseless ripping and tearing a bit more strategic. The music is absolutely amazing too. It's not quite as memorable a soundtrack as the original's, but it's a fantastic mix of metal and electronic, that's brutal as hell and ABSOLUTELY matches up with everything that's going on onscreen. The boss fights, the few there are, are reALLY GOOD. They could be a bit harder, but I'm willing to bet they'll be harder to deal with in Nightmare (of which, i played ultra violence). But they're all really cool, with multiple attacks and the works. They're ABSOLUTELY good boss fights, and are very fun to fight, but there are some ways they could've been improved upon to make them even better. Though even with that, they're the best boss fights in the entire series.  The lore, what little there is, is actually very interesting to me. It's by no means extensive, but as a fan of being able to read up on lore of doom 3, the little bit of reading there is to do for every monster in this game satisfied me greatly. A little bit of context and story is good enough for me. The characters are nearly as intriguing as the demons, and i loooove reading up on the demons. The doomguy himself is given an interesting backstory, but doesn't talk, and through just his body language you can get more character from him than most big budget ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t exposition machines. Besides that, there are VERY FEW story sequences which lock you in rooms and require you to listen to exposition. And the few there are are pretty much all within the first few levels of the game, so it's not all that bad.  There are secrets too, you're rewarded with health, ammo, and even some classic doom levels you can mess around in, like in wolfenstein.   I think i've gotten through everything good I wanted to say, so now onto some of the bad things (what few there are). For one, there are a few graphical and audio glitches here and there. Every now and then it's easy to run into a physics glitch where a body will get stuck in the geometry and make some noise. but these aren't very bad, and barely hinder the game's experience, if at all. The bosses I enjoyed fighting, but theres one boss that I'm legitimately surprised they left out. I was almost certain they'd have the icon of sin in as an actual boss. I know it was just a wall in doom 2, but with what they did with the other bosses, I'm sure they could've found a way to make a modern icon of sin fight. A damn good one at that. But it only shows up as an environmental thing near the end of the game, though honestly with an extremely amusing easter egg attached to it. This also feeds into how I feel the boss fights could've been improved overall. They're GREAT, and absolutely fun, but each one is just in a circular fighting arena, and i feel like they could've been improved if lengthened, and put in bigger areas that allow for more running around, perhaps mixed with some regular enemies as well. They also don't have the arachnotrons anymore, though in the end I still had 2 slots in the beastiary empty, so I don't know if or how I missed 2 enemy types, but i doubt they'd be arachnotrons. The level design is great, the arenas and everything are well made and fun to run around in, but it plays a bit in that respect like a serious sam game, where you run through halls with little enemies in them and then the big baddies come out in big fights, which some people may not be a fan of, but I personally feel it matches what this game's going for and works well. But as the game progresses, the level design falters a little bit. They're by no means just infinite straight hallways like other modern fps games, they have secrets and damn good design in general, but they do feel a little linear in that most of the time you do just have a single path open, to which you get a key and then have just 1 more path, and so on and so forth. I definately remember levels like this in the old games, and it isn't quite as bad as doom 3, but I do feel the levels could've had more open levels later on. I also aren't a huge fan of the gauss cannon and the weapon modifications. They're nice, and don't ruin the experience or anything, but i feel like they can get extremely overpowered, especially the gauss cannon, which quite frankly, is a nice weapon, but is so ♥♥♥♥ing over powered i'd rather it just not be in the game at all. The chainsaw is cool, with limited ammo, and giving you ammo drops when you kill enemies, but playing on ultra violence i never really needed it (Though I plan on playing the game through again on Nightmare without any mods or upgrades, so hopefully it'll be more useful there). The bfg having such limited ammo is good too. It's incredibly powerful, to the point where I never wanted to use it though, as it would make things simply too easy. Though again, all of the upgrades and everything is optional, that's why I'm choosing to not use them in the next playthrough.  Now onto the multiplayer and snapmap, of which there isn't much to say really Multiplayer is a bit of fun, but mediocre, not well balanced (due to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t loadouts lmao), and mostly meh. It's a bit of fun here and there but it's probably going to be dead soon so. The snapmap is a harmless addition, it's fun to play around with but lacks the depth to make really good maps. They really should allow better modding   Overall, doom is FANTASTIC. I loved it from start to finish An easy 9/10 for the single player alone  Rip  And  Tear

Wow, I am 18 hours into this game and still haven't completed it. Talk about a meaty campaign. One thing I liked in particular about the melee takedowns was that each enemy has a different character animation in how they are dispatched depending on what part of the body you attack them from i.e. from above or below or from behind.   Only downsides - I think some battles you are overwhelmed by the amount of foes who attack you. Sometimes you think the battle is over then two huge enemy types spawn along with other foes and they need taking down before you can progress. Also I got lost on a few occasions in the game what with all the keycard backtracking and the map I found to be very difficult to navigate. A solid return to form for Id.

I'd give it a three out of five. Gameplay, excellent. Graphics, excellent. Combat, excellent.  Language, plot... not so much. Of course, the saving grace on that score is, who the hell plays Doom for the plot? Not like it's ever had one before anyway.  This is an excellent twitch game; takes me back to when I was eight years old, and makes me proud I still have the reflexes for it. Your character is a lethal badass that gets right out in the bad guy's face and rips it off. Unrealistic as hell, but also fun as hell, so I won't knock that part.  The part I will knock is... well, all the parts--rare and fleeting as they are--where you are NOT shooting something. Those parts all give me the same feeling as reading the badly-translated package of a cheap Chinese toy. 'Doom Marine'? Fourth wall much? 'Glory Kill'? REALLY? Who in blazes even uses the word 'glory' anymore? Nobody I ever talk to; it's a good way to make something sound childish. Or, okay, Chinese. And that bit where it does this pathetic, kitschy zoom-in of a screaming Imp to call our attention to the new and improved Imp Style... blech. The only thing more sad than a cheap jump-scare is one that fails that hard. Hell, the new Imp doesn't even look that scary; it's like a monkey wearing a Star Warsy mask. And that scream? N  So whenever the action starts, I get a hell of a rush; whenever it stops, it's just, 'What the hell?'  Worth playing for the action, but... seriously, don't make the mistake I did: wait until the price drops, 'cause this is NOT worth sixty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bucks.

** See my comment below   Single player only review.  Doom (2016) is truly worthy of carrying the legendary name. It feels like a spiritual successor to Doom 2, with a few bits of Doom 3 and Quake (Quad Damage baby!) thrown in.  This is in the same fine caliber of remakes/reboots as Wolfenstein: New Order, which is one of the best single player FPS games I've played in recent years.  The FPS mechanics are close to perfect. At first I frowned at the double jumping and ledge climbing, but soon realized how these mechanics helped keep the pace of the fights high, as your great freedom of movement on all 3 axis pretty much always leaves you somewhere to go, even when you're not familiar with the layout of the map.   The level design is actually pretty reminiscent of Doom 2, with both narrow corridors and large open areas. Plenty of secret areas to explore, which gets rewarded well.  The good old gang of monsters and weapons are back (with some additions), and they all look, sound and handle superbly. This is pure no-nonsense, balls to the wall, Doom action with just a bare minimum of story and cutscenes.   Generally you'll face fewer, but tougher versions of the hordes from hell. The 'Baron of Hell' is pretty fearsome now, so it feels better than ever to pick up a 'Beserk' powerup, put a grin on your face and blast your 1-hit death machine fist into his sorry face.  The game is impressively true to it's herritage, even though the old dog HAS learned a few modern tricks...   Health and ammo no longer has to come from traditional pickups. Damage a monster so it almost dies, and it staggers for some seconds, during which you can perform a 'Glory Kill' by using your melee attack. This triggers a badass gory kill animation, and results in some dropped health.  The trusty old chainsaw has become a fuel guzzler, but in return it makes the sliced foes drop ammo. The tougher the enemy is to cut through, the more fuel the saw consumes.  All weapons (except for the pistol) have 2 unlockable modifications, and each of these mods have 4 upgrades. The first three upgrades are unlocked by spending weapon upgrade tokens, which are rewarded by fulfilling challenges, finding secrets and having some sort of algoritm evaluate your performance at the end of each level. The final upgrade level of each gun is unlocked by completing a challenge related to the usage of that specific weapon mod. Some of the mods are friggin' kickass, and really help keep things fresh and varied as you progress.  Your suit too has upgrades. Four categories of them actually, and these are unlocked via Praetor tokens, which are found on the corpses of Elite Guards.  Even passive 'perks' are introduced in the form of 'Runes' which are unlocked on special challenge maps accessed through portals. These runes can also be upgraded by fulfilling challenges. You start with 1 rune slot, but can unlock up to 3 slots.  And finally your max health, armor and ammo capacity is upgraded by finding and collecting 'Argent Cells' which are spread across the maps.  At the end of each level you can see how many exploration items you missed.  Overall the presentation is great. The id Tech engine performs excellent, so the awesome detailed artwork never once stuttered on MAX settings in 1200p on my GTX 980ti. I loved the industrial/metal themed soundtrack, but I reckon it might annoy the more faint eared folks out there :) It sets the mood perfectly regardless.  One of my few complaints is that I would've loved a thick layer of badass cutscene driven story full of colorful characters. If it can be done in a Wolfenstein remake, it can be done in the Doom universe as well.  The game crashed to desktop 4-5 times during my 10 hour playthrough, which never happened for me with previous id Tech powered titles.  That aside, it's my pick for best single player FPS of the year. Well done id Software - you're still a force to be reckoned with.  93%

The game is great. There are plenty of reviews out there to tell you that. Hell, if you're here, you probably know it's great already, as there's nothing but praise for this game out there, and for good reason. There really is not much I can say about the gameplay that hasn't been said already. The shooting feels amazing. The maps are very well-designed and every encounter is filled with gory joy, though one complaint that I do have have regarding gameplay is that there's too much downtime between fights, whereas the original Doom had almost no downtime at all unless you killed everything on the level already. The music is amazing and fits the gameplay perfectly, and the sound design is great in general, especially on the guns (as you might imagine, that's important on a game that focuses on shooting and not much else). The game is very well-optimized, and I noticed very few bugs, none of which interfered with gameplay. Overall, this is easily one of the best titles this year.  HOWEVER, and that's a big however, the recent update that introduced Vulkan also introduced always-on DRM to go with Vulkan, meaning that if your internet is down and you wanna play DOOM, you'll have to play an inferior version of it because the performance gains from Vulkan are quite significant, especially for AMD cards. Now, some people might live in the illusion that everyone has a perfect internet connection, but that's not true. Some people live in rural areas, some people live in developing countries, some people just have a bad ISP, and even those who have a generally solid internet connection will lose it sometimes due to technical difficulties on the ISP's part or problems with their router. Point is, not everyone has reliable access to the superior version of DOOM, and for no good reason. DOOM's single-player has nothing to do with online connectivity. To lock enhanced performance behind an online connection that doesn't contribute to that enhanced performance is strictly ANTI-CONSUMER. Make no mistake, this decision was made to fight piracy. Unfortunately, it also hurts paying customers. It treats everyone like criminals, except pirates didn't pay for the product. Paying customers did. Thus, by punishing both equally as much, the side that really gets hurt are the paying customers. Does it make some would-be pirates pay for the product? of course, but then, they become paying customers and are punished for it, thus discouraging them from paying for more products of the same publisher in the future.   To conclude this rant, you should know that if you are buying this game, you are validating an anti-consumer practice, effectively telling Bethesda/Zenimax and potentially other publishers 'this is profitable! you should do it more!'.

Not played the MP or had a go at the SnapMap because I've been having too much damn fun with the SP game. This is a proper SP FPS with none of the linear set pieces of modern shooters. None of that 'follow me for twenty minutes and shoot when I say', none of this stealthy stealthy shushy shushy nonsense.  You wake up, you pick up a gun, and you shoot demons. And thats pretty much it. the guns get bigger, as do the demons, and at times it gets pretty hectic with spawns happening all around you.  There is a much greater sense of using the environment to stay alive, its almost parkour, but parkour with rocket launchers.  As an oldie who remembered the originals when they were just that, this game is definitely more Doom than 3, which had you corridor shooting your way through predictable spawns (usually at the back of you). This has wide open spaces, indoor and out, with a fantastic array of iconic demons, incoming fire you can dodge, secrets galore and some great meaty gun effects.  What they added, works. Weapons that have dual modes lending a great amount of tinkering on the players part, upgrades to the suit, Runes, and the controversial melee system serves to keep the action flowing by dropping health and ammo, pushing you relentlessly forward. I'll break down specifically what I felt were pros and cons:  Pros: Definitely acknowledges the original games Lots of fun guns in the game Fantastic visual design/level design Interesting audio/ambience tracks An fast-action romp  Cons: The game is very buggy. Some sections of the game are devoid of all ambient sounds, the main menu is laggy as hell when you first launch the game, first load time takes forever. Weapon graphics look bizare sometimes (plasma rifle shots just look weird). It feels like a lot of the guns are desynced from the sounds being played too.  Because the game is an action romp, the action can sometimes be almost too fast. A lot of the gameplay basically comes down to 20-30 seconds of hectic moving around and shooting. Some people may like this, as it feels like Serious Sam, but I just don't like the pacing. Essentially, fights are a contained area/arena that you have to navigate around before moving on to the next area.  The story itself is just weird. I can get weird stories, but DOOMs just -really- makes zero sense. The in-game entries are a nice touch, but often times just leave me scratching my head for one reason or another. Also, about the entries, a lot of them typos...  Theres a lot of meaningless side-stuff to do like timed trials. I just don't understand what the point of these were for as it feels like they break up the pace of the game and serve as a distraction. You can actually play through the game without doing any of the trials.  Honestly, the majority of the game's difficulty comes from having to maximize the Doom Marine's health, armor, and ammunition pools. Once you have one of those maxed out, the game becomes fairly easy. Seems like a really lazy way to make the game hard, but there you go.  Overall:  It's an okay game but there are other games like it that are better. Serious Sam, Painkiller, etc. Might as well just play the original Doom too. I wouldn't recommend Doom 2016 though.

DOOM 2016 is an absolutely great game! It is simple, straight-forward, fast-paced shoot all the mean demons on the screen, and find hidden rooms and secrets. On the highest difficulty (EXCLUDING perma-death mode), the game is super tense with every fight potentially being the last.   There are some additional bonus things to do in the game that give levels replayability, such as completing all the challenges in a level if you missed them (which normally pertain to finding secrets or killing a typeof demon in a particular way), finding the health/armor/ammo upgrades, and weapon mods. DOOM 2016 gives you so many new and fun options to shoot things, it's great! Heck, the Glory Killing mechanic is a lot of fun too, since it's a fast execution of an enemy, and it doesn't feel like it breaks the quick pace of the game.  There are also custom maps with workshop content that you can make (also multiplayer potential), and a multiplayer team deathmatch with objectives for when you want to break from the campaign (or want more than the campaign, with the custom maps). They can feel rather bare-bones.. but it's certainly a good alternative.   So the review is lookin' like I would recommend the game--- but I can't. Not right now. I haven't looked or asked around if anyone has the same issues as me, but the game is frustratingly difficult because of the following bugs. Do not buy the game until the price goes down, or if you REALLY like DOOM and a simple-shooter with some exploration, buy it when all the bugs are patched up. I wasn't expecting much, seeing how from the videos I've seen and playing the open beta repetitively which I enjoyed though wasn't something too special.  The single player though is quite much like you would expect in a classic shooter game, you're running around dodging a bunch of ♥♥♥♥, while at the same time using the essential weapons for the essential situation you'd be in, much like how in the Serious Sam series you know you would definitely be using shotguns against enemies that would try charging at you. Now much like so in Doom, Pinky is not a joke anymore, and using the shotgun actually matters now especially considering he would shrug off your weapons from the front unless you shot at it's weak spot.  It's such a mixed but still a great experience nonetheless, you're placed into levels still designed much like how Doom 3 was except you're still running around and killing demons instead of occasionally dodging into cover while moving rather slowly unless you used sprint which would be limited unless you were in the Hell levels. In this game? You are ALWAYS running, much like how it always should be in our shooter games, cause we all know damn well enough it doesn't fit into an 'FPS' game like you know, CoD.  And listen to me when I say this, when I say that you HAVE to keep moving, you HAVE too unless you want to die pretty quickly, cause the demons in this game are in a completely different kind of ambushing strategy, and it works!  I haven't spent enough time yet for both multiplayer and the snapmap mode but surely enough after I felt I spent enough time I will provide information about that, but so far, yes! This Doom is actually worth getting! Though I would still wait at least a little bit until the prices drop at least like, 20%, but either way, the single-player mode itself alone still has a LOT to offer, mostly it being map exploration, a map system you can actually check out on, secret areas, secret levels, collectible DoomGuy action figures! After reading so many great reviews and glowing reports from friends I was very surprised to find this game was heavily scripted and tedious to play. The developer attitude towards the player might best be summarized by the unskippable dancing company logos when the game is launched. The entire game is like that: for every cool or beautiful gameplay element there's something that's decidedly player-unfriendly.  Bits of story text are collected and viewed in a tiny window on an otherwise unused screen, forcing the player to scroll through as few as three paragraphs of story. The 'glory kills' basically pause the game for 2-3 seconds every time, and like... Near the beginning there's an elevator. Push the button, wait for it to arrive, get in, push the button, wait for it to close the doors, wait for it to move to another floor. At the end of a short hallway, literally the only thing on this level, there's a key. Back to the elevator, push the button, wait, resume playing.  None of these things are game breakers, but they keep piling up, like a heap of tiny offenses and after two hours I found I was basically playing it angry, it wasn't fun.   And there are games out there I will enjoy more, so I'm moving on.

This was the first game I bought on the release date since GTA 5 so I had high hopes! Some came true, others died a sad death...  So lets go on a rollercoaster of feelings shall we!  I always loved the Doom singleplayer and damn...I was NOT disappointed! Constant chaos, carnage and other words starting with c's. The oldskool area 'hold-the-fire-button-and-run' shooter is back! The story was flimsy, the exposition and plot twists about as exciting as a Teletubbie episode. Just the way I like it because that just means there's more time for great graphics, intuitive gameplay and non-stop action packed missions. And of course all of the OG favorites are back like the Pinky's, revenants and Caco demons.  Definately worth giving up daylight for.  But of course there's also multiplayer...and that's where the ball was dropped...forgotten and erased from memory. Let me eleborate: The first few weeks I had a blast. Running for powerups while dodging rockets and unleashing a quad damage chaingun. It's like the area shooter never left! But then the fire nation attacked...errr wait... server logic happened. There apears to be no ranking system whatsover, meaning one round you play with pro's and the next round it's glue sniffing n00bs as far as the Railgun can shoot. No consistency in the ranking of players or lobbies. Just chuck people in a lobby and have fun (or don't). But at least you could play. Since a few weeks even finding the glue sniffers has become a real time consuming task. If you're lucky you'll find a full lobby within 15 minutes. If, off course they stay and wait the (90!!!) second interval between each match.  So if you want a kickass single player, buy it and have a blast. If you want multiplayer, you're about 2 months too late because the MP community is populated by tumbleweeds and chirping crickets.

Unfortunately I NEED A STORY!!! I am old enough to remember the first DOOM and I am also old enough to remember that I hated it! Believe it or not but it is possible for a game to be ferociously difficult and yeild an interesting and engaging story at the same time! Doom: 2016 somewhat manages to do this. Although there is a story there it isn\'t enough of one to keep me as interested like other games do. I like Doom: 2016 I really do, but I do not love it. Its to repetitive for me to stay interested and want to finish the game. So far I\'m just about finished exploring everything that Hell has to offer. Unlike other repetitive games, Doom: 2016 doesn\'t have anything to make me want to continue the repetitiveness... It\'s not worth it. If there were some kind of epic storyline to keep me interested and wanting to know what happens next I would be playing it right now. Although I do enjoy the chaos, it gets old to fast for me... Therefor I feel I wasted my money. The graphics are gorgeous and the carnage is non-stop... I just want more out of it. The controlls are super tight and the Doom Marine will do whatever it is I want it to do on a dime... I just want more out of it. I want more than just good graphics, tight controlls and lots of carnage... I want substance. Did I to mention that if you like to collect loot, the first few levels are mind numbing! There are enough corridors and hallways to make a sane man mad, I think the M on my M-Key has worn completely off from me checking the map so many times durring those first few levels. I liked Doom 3 because of the engaging story and I was hoping (despite the storyless prelaunch rumors) that this Doom would also have a story. Man was I wrong!  If you are a gamer who thoroughly enjoys lots of gore and mass carnage teamed up with lots of shooting and awesome graphics you are gonna love this game and I totally recomend it. If you are the gamer who enjoys the above but has to have substance, plot twists and interesting characters in your games then I suggest you hold off on this game until it goes on sale... I\'m gonna check the thumbs up as this Doom is actually a really good game, It\'s just not my type of game.

For me this game is a 7.0 out of 10. Decent, but cannot describe it as being worth full purchase price. It's a consolified version of Doom, which, as it turns out, works kind of.     The Good     Graphics (might not run well for you, so no promises)   Gunplay has variety and is functional   Fair amount of content (crappy map editor and multiplayer)   Makes good use of jumping   Fast paced and somewhat old school doom...ish   Good boss fights    Somewhat  open levels     The Bad    Multiplayer is absolute garbage (only listed in bad, since Doom is mostly about singleplayer)  The gunplay is marred by a forced press a button and watch an animation aspect for melee   The story (it's doom though, who cares?)? Nobody cares, but the kiddy voice overs for demons are annoying.   Gunplay isn't as fluid as in other comparable shooters (don't even get me started with the original). Annoying animations that will either get you killed, or bore you to tears after 10 hours of seeing them (thank you modern day shooters)    The UGLY    Map design is pretty bad.  90% of your fights with demons are in quake-style arena maps   that have been copied and pasted over and over again. I think I would really like this game but the 10 or so frames of mouse lag is a huge killer. It holds you back, forces you to play super safe since you cant reliably aim/track/shoot enemies on reaction, which basically removes a huge part of the game for me along with being the most frustrating mouse movement I have ever experienced since using a steelseries mouse back in 2012. This alone is a big red flag that pretty much nullifies 80% of the game. Sure, you can push on even with the input lag but it doesnt feel worth it. Wolfenstein: The New Order is capped at 60 fps and I had no problem doing 90 degree flickshots after getting used to it. DOOM isnt tied to a framerate limit which is great, but the input lag issues persist.  Enough about input lag, you get the idea. Before all the Doom 1/2 and Quake purists yell about how the game has been casualized or cinematic QTE-riddled you need to understand that the E3 footage they showed is pretty much nothing like the final product, at least from the first 3 hours I played.  The character movement is at a plesant speed, not too slow and not too fast to be overpowered. You can no longer shift-cirle-strafe-sprint around enemies at sanic speed, which I found to be borderline broken in the original game. Its funny how in the original game, it was actually harder to play with the invisible powerup as monsers would shoot in random directions instead of straight at you, and you had to dodge the projectiles based on reaction.  The new Doom doesnt do projectile prediction, usually enemies come from multiple directions, and move way faster. Since youre limited in terms of movement speed you usually have to resort to dodging multiple directions at once, without shift-sprint, against faster moving enemies. They found a nice mix between freedom and limitation. For those who are used to running through E1M1 in 16 seconds and outrun monsters by 10x speed, its going to feel 'casualized' but honestly shooting slow moving targets who cannot projectile predict while running at sanic speed is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing easy compared to newDoom's harder difficulty, if youre looking at it that way.  The game looks great even at the lowest settings with everything disabled. They should have toned down on the colour filter a bit but its just a minor design choice criticism. It stays somewhat true to the original game with no reloading, keycarded doors and armour pickups. There is a small narrative but its far from interesting and not essential. They shifted towards the original games focus more than Doom 3's 'horror action shooter' approach with jumpscares and dark corridors. I'll admit the levels in new Doom are a bit less complex than the old ones but its whatever to me, as long as it isnt a straight corridor.  Of course, all of this is overshadowed by the horrible mouse handling. It could have been a great action fps experience.

While it can be dangerous to enter a game with expectations, when it comes to new version of the classics, it is almost impossible not to do so.  With Doom (Doom 4) I was expecting a classic demon/monster slaughter game. A follow up to Doom 3. That however is not what I got from the latest instalment of the popular FPS franchise.  Gone are the dark and momentum building narrow corridors and sharp corners with demons lurking just around them, no more waiting for the attack announced by the sinister musical ambiance. Instead the game is much more bright and the music is more 'party on' then 'evil is coming'. The new Doom is designed to be more fast paced then it's predecessor, which at times was a bit to slow and the player could lose focus.  The game is follows a simple premise. Keep the player active while staying true to the Doom universe, and so it does. Note that I used the word active rather than entertained. The reason for that is as simple as the game itself. The game is not all that entertaining. True, for the first 3 mission you collect weapons and read through the 'mod' abilities as it is called, and you meet new daemons as well. But that soon passes, and since there is basically no story, you are left with only the actual gameplay.  The gameplay is typical of an FPS game. You have different weapons which do only slow you down while selected as well as 3 different kinds of equipment. The weapon selection is also staying true to the Doom universe. ranging from a pistol with unlimited energy, which means that no ammunition is required, to the much beloved combat shotgun which in this incarnation also host the explosive shot mod upgrade, turning it into a kind of grenade launcher. This is something different, as most FPS games traditionally attaches the grenade launcher to a rifle or otherwise machinegun. This mod is going to be very popular, as the claim could be made that the original Doom made the shotgun the popular and effective close-range weapon it is today. The combat shotgun has always had one weakness, and so it is in most FPS games, namely it's lack of long-range effectiveness. That has now been solved with the explosive shot upgrade. Thus turning it into the default selected weapon in your load-out. Every weapon has two mods, the combat shotguns other mod is charged burst which fires 3 rounds in a closer cluster then the normal firing mode. All weapons except for the pistol, which only has one upgrade tier, follows the same system. But while the heavy assault rifle and the gauss cannon have their advantages via their mods, such as the heavy assault rifle's micro missiles and the gauss cannon's siege mode, they never become the default weapons.  Doom tries to give the player customization options via the weapons mods and suit upgrades but also via the runes you can collect through rune trails. Rune trails are small challenges within the games missions. If you complete one, it will grant you a rune. At first you can only equip 1 rune but you will later be able to equip 3 at a time. These will give you various abilities, some of which are very useful and others which you the player will properly never use.  Now we come to the actual experience of the game. Whenever or not you like this game, will depend more on your personal preferences then it will on the games ability to provide you with entertainment. The game is overall dry and displays a lack of creative thinking. Each mission is the same. You follow the path of the map, searching for secrets along the way, killing daemons as you progress finally culminating in a large battle. Every mission is like that. However, each mission does not necessarily end with a boss fight.  The weapons and Praetor suit upgrades quickly become a stagnated element of the game, and the search for secrets is only interesting doing the first 3 missions. With the exception for the BFG9000 and assuming you have found the secrets, you will have all weapons available to you, after which it becomes more of a tedious task then a fun and necessary part of the game.  The whole time you move around you do not truly feel like you are actually playing as the character of the Doom Marine. it feels more like you are wearing ice-skates and the entire surface of Mars as well as damaged or destroyed parts of the various complexes and buildings are made from smooth ice, which you are just 'skating' over. Combined with the lack of atmosphere you never really feel the game and so remain the player rather than becoming the main antagonist, the Doom Marine. There is also the problem with the crosshair. Many FPS games can be made much more intense when played without the crosshair. In Doom however on the pistol has a zoom function, and that is to fire it's alternate firing mode. Without the ability to zoom, you need to crosshair. The heavy assault rifle and gauss cannon can be upgraded so that they do have zoom capability, but again this is in order to fire their alternate/mod ability. And here we have another problem. Many FPS games have different weapons not only as to offer the player interesting alternatives and variations, but also because different enemies are vulnerable to different weapons. In Doom however you can kill every enemy with any weapon with the exception of the pistol.  There is also the fact that id Software are simply trying too hard. Customizations are called mods, executions are called glory kills and alternative/secondary firing mode is given the name of the active mod. This seems more like an attempt to set the game apart from other FPS games rather than a meaningful or integral part of the gameplay.  Where Doom really falls through is not because of the repetitiveness, lack of ambiance or the quickly grow boring secrets. It comes from the unfulfilled potential. Characters like Olivia Pierce and Samual Hayden as well as the A.I. VEGA could have been developed so much more. Pierce you mostly hear over the public announcement system or via holographic projections. You only come face to face with her a few times, primarily in hell when she is sucked down into a pool of blood and one assumes, transformed into the final boss which looks like Krang from the original Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Samual Hayden guides you throughout the game over the intercom in your suit. The same goes for VEGA. While the emotional neutral but friendly artificial intelligence communicates with you at the beginning of the game, telling you about the capabilities of your suit and how it can help you upgrade those abilities, eventually VEGA becomes second to communication with Hayden. before going back to hell, the Doom Marine does backup VEGA before overloading his energy matrix, which causes a rift to hell to open. Doing the missions, you will actually be going to hell twice. The first time you will be sucked in and the second time will be when you overload VEGA un purpose. This feel like a way to alternative not just the scenery but also give the player a non-singular progression within the game. However, since the game is the same regardless of mission, environment and scenery this does not work. You are doing the same you did at the Argent Facility before being sucked in and at the facility which houses VEGA.  At the end of day, or night as the game was released at 01.00 (1AM) in Europe, what do I think of this new Doom? The answer is in their review above. But I will summarise.  Doom is a classic FPS game. The problem is, that this is 2016 and you need more than just big weapons and daemons to slaughter. If you are looking for Bullet Storm meets Unreal Tornament, then by all means get this game. If you are looking for DOOM, go download the DOS Original.   It's not all bad though, the graphics are pretty and the sounds are very well done. This is to be expected with Bethesda games and full points and thumbs up to the graphics and audio teams. That's where it stops.   Controls DOOM guy slides around the stage like he is ice skating the whole while, which is decently smooth, but it handles like being locked on TURBO in old Doom. The absurd footstep sound effects that accompany his rediculous Dhalsim yoga strides are laughable.   Sound: So remember how I said they had great sound, well it is great... the first 40 times you hear it. If you'd like to experience, what i can only discribe as the 'cacophony of disgust', stay in a room with 2 or more zombies. Their overlapping, hideouse, rapid fire, cries of 'dear god shoot me so you don't have to listen to me', will make anyone want to mute all sounds. The music also is nice and has a nostalgic feel but it falls prey to the same blunders of only playing during the wave fighting and just ends into static ambiance as you enter a very dull stage till the next fight. I can understand that you need high impact sound tracts during the highest points of action and/or tension, but dont drop me like a the ball Bethesda was holding when they OK'ed this game to ship. I guess the scenes do fit the lifeless and dull atmosphere of mars when you are out of combat.   Combat:  I can't tell if they intentional wanted to take an epic crap all over DOOM or if they just thought wave combat made Doom 3 good.... I'm suprised one of the level designers didn't slap the developers upside the head with a 2x4 when they desided on wave battles. They lock you in tiny arenas in which you have to run around in circles like a constipated weener dog while firing idiotically at anything that happens to cross infront of you. I mean, if i wanted to play Quake Arena, I WOULD HAVE BOOTED UP QUAKE ARENA. I'll get to thier AI in a later section.  The regular level enemies, be they few and far between are a nice DOOM touch, it almost convinces me that this game was inspired by the original Dooms. I can see why they had to go with the atrocity that is wave combat. It's due to the awkward level design that just doesn't support original DOOM style play. They give the players grenades and a backpack full of weapons (i'll get to those later), to try and sell the 'You can play whatever style you like'. Its a lie, a straight up, bold face, 'it's 4 player co-op', LIE. The designers have forced players into the previously stated, running around like a constipated weener dog style. You can try and play it like an older Doom, Duke 3D, Blakestone, Wolfenstien or an other early era shooter, but no... you will die insanly fast due to the way that drops and AI is dispatched at you. Basically they have made it 'play our way! or face the consequences!'.  Weapons So you're hoping for that sweet sweet Plasma Rifle or a Chain Saw to dispatch some demonic justice? To bad, so sad, devs gave you the finger. Not in the, 'that's rudde' way, in the 'THAT'S NOT WHERE FINGERS GO!' way. Plasma Rifle, now #3, and worthless. It's basically like opening a bag of Skittles and throwing them in the face of a stampeding Rhino. If the bolts manage to hit, they do little to nothing at all. Chainsaw? Nope, runs on gas now so you will rarely be shreading some demon meat, to the melodious reving of a Gore Machine. The Shotgun? well that's about the only thing that can stagger a Knight... works even at long range. Odd, cause 20 rounds to the dome piece with other weapons and he doesn't even flinch. The Heavy Rifle is nice but is worthless till you can get some ammo upgrades. Really it would take to long to go into deatail about every gun and how they blow a walruses enourmous equipment, so I will just give you the good gun. The Pistol... that's it... the Pistol. Had to be one of the Halo fan boys watching too much Screw Attack and getting upset, but the pistol is the best gun in the game. Upgrade it and you can plow through enemies faster that a Backpack full of guns on the new DOOM... go figure.  Multiplayer Well if you heard the devs talking about how there was Co-op, might as well take your hopes and dreams of a fun time with your friends and bury them out back with gran-grans missing coarpse. That's right, they lied to us all. No story mode co-op, in fact, you wanna play co-op? then go build all your own stuff in this bull crap knock off of Doom Fever for 20 hours. The Devs just couldn't be bothered with making Doom, true to Doom. So take your sobbing and utter disgust for them elseware. But seriously, I like that I get a Doom game builder but COME ON, WHERE'S THE CO-OP CAMPAIGN?! Some one should be punched in the balls until they die for that one.  Seeing how this game has gone so far, I refuse to play this Deathmatch online.   Final So, the only reason I got this game after I swore off Bethesda (the new EA) was because I was nagged into getting it. I would have just pirated it and not felt utterly ripped off. On the EXTREAMLY off chance it was good I would have appologized and paid real money for it. But this attrocity, of a sham, of a garbage heap left in the summer sun for 3 weeks, force fed to people with pretty words and broken promises, should not stand. I would be completely fine with all this games innumerable faults if it just had the campaign co-op. I want to over look the terrible forced game play style, the atrocious sounds that should be patched, the bland levels and horrid wave combat arenas. I'd even ignore the fact that these dickless cads absolutly failed at capturing what Doom was, and instead gave us bobble heads of nostalgia and product placement. But I can't, and nor should anyone else.   There's only one way Bethesda can ever make it up, Seppuku. Take the blade, you know what to do... die with some form of honor.

So, I've played my fair share of this game. I'm leaning more towards not recommending this game until some patches get released. Not all of the issues can be fixed with patches but we'll get to that.  I've had nothing but bugs, glitches and crashes. I shouldn't of expected any different with Bethesda's name attached. The Beta was way more stable than this game is. I actually enjoyed the Beta.   I've had the world drop out, I've gotten embedded in rocks and walls, I've seen demons half in half out of the groumd, I've had a total of 11 crashes, one of which decided to corrupt my save file of 18 hours and then I had to redo the entire campaign again.   The campaign is definetly lengthy but a lot of it is kind of just padding, finding the key cards is fine but when it's overused, not to mention the gore nests that are basically just wave survival sections. In one level you have to do 4 nests in one area, that's over 40 minutes worth of gameplay right there, so there is definetely a load of that.  Gameplay itself, if you ignore all of the issues I've had, if you pretend they never existed or hopefully in the future, patched out. Then the gameplay itself is solid, it's a very decent shooter, it does it's job, unfortunately some of the level design I have issues with, constantly getting stuck on walls or small props, so that you then get scewed by demons.   You need to keep moving and shooting at the demons, but you can't shoot the demons if you are looking where you are going and you can't move if you are shooting the demons because you end up getting stuck on everything.  Despite the fact that you have a double jump mechanic and a climbing mechanic in this game there is an unusually amount of invisible walls and non climable surfaces that the game just decides on a whim what's climable and what's not.  The story is kind of lack lustre, the Doom games have always had a fairly decent story but it seems the devs decided to go the whole Dark Souls route and make it so the only story information you get is from reading small descriptions. In typical id fashion, they've done this for their last few games, RAGE etc. People weren't too happy about that but I guess they didn't learn anything. OK, so here goes:  TL:DR This is a 5.875/10 game at best.   I bought this game thinking it will be much like Doom 3; so full of in depth story that will make you question your very exitance...  I only gave the single player a go, and am yet to play multiplayer; though judging from the open Beta, it will feel like another Halo reskin, catering to the masses… I was expecting a Quake 3 / Doom 3 type of mutiplay; none of this loadouts/levelling BS. I don’t think the oldskoolers will be pleased.  The melee takedown of demons gets boring after the 3rd level of this game. I will give them credit though, the chainsaw takedown is boner inducing!  While the Demon Army vs you stays true to the original (think late 90’s) DOOM series, the secret/s exploration is rather counter-intuitive of the evolving “moving forward” combat feature... I spent 70% finding the secrets/upgrades of each level, and the rest blowing up Mars and its (former) inhabitants.  I will give ID/Bethesda some credit though; the weapon/suit upgrades were quite the nice touch (shotgun/assault rifle rockets anyone); only if you can locate the friggin bots that give you that option! Additionally, the berserk power ups are as satisfying as a Maccas (McDonalds) run during a drunken nigh out (punching Demons back to hell anyone?). The objective/s compass needs some re-work though.  The main story: sh*t, what main story? There’s as much depth to main story as there is to a drunken Californian chick dancing to Kesha’s “Take it Off” at a party, completely off her face on bath salts…  Overall, this game feels like a Serious Sam series, but with a DOOM twist. I recommend saving your money, purchasing a 6 pack and/or a few joints, acquiring Doom 3 and Resurrection of Evil and modding the sh*t out of them.  At least then you come across some “oh god I hope that was a fart” type of moments.  Peace, The Doc

I've never written a review before, but Doom 4 is so good I have to. I'll start by saying I don't like very many first person shooters, but Doom is one of my favorite series. I had pretty low expectations for this game after seeing footage of the multiplayer beta (which I'll admit I didn't actually play), but I was pleasantly surprised that the singleplayer campaign at least, is the best game I've played this year so far. Doom 4 stays true to the source material, while still bringing it into 2016. This is how you revive a series.
