You can generally tell how old people are by the reviews for this.  If they are under 21 they'll complain about lack of story, too fast etc.  If they are 21-29 ish they'll complain about how it isn't horror and Doom 3 was nothing like this etc.  If however your 30+ and remember playing Doom in early / mid 90s you'll love this, (unless your total classic doom purist)  I'm 30+ and I remember playing Doom back in 1994, you couldn't stop playing it always 'one more level'. Well I was playing 'one more level' last night and the night before.  This isn't Classic Doom, but it feels like what Classic Doom would be if made in 2016, all the good bits with the addition of things like the glory kills that spawn ammo and health, not to make it easy but keep the brutal pace of the murder at breakneck speeds. It's keeps things going.  It takes some things from Quake too like Quad Damage and double jumps (Quake 2 IIRC).  It takes away all the things I hate about Modern Single player FPS, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t story, waiting around for doors to be opened, everything is serious no humour, only 2 weapons, health regen etc etc etc.  Wolfenstein: TNO was a breath of fresh air and showed you do old school Single player FPS with a story (And given the setting of Wolfenstein vs Doom it makes this that would have more story)  Doom is like a hurricane of fresh air, it destroys everything in it's path it's truly amazing, it has story sure, but it's not important it's optional... killing is the main meat of the game, just like it was in 1994.  I hope we start to see some more single player FPS like Wolfenstein: TNO and Doom...... A Lovecraftian Quake 1 Single Player campaign WITH a decent multiplayer would be awesome.  It also runs like a dream, on my i5-3570k @ 4.7 ghz, 16gb Ram, 980ti it averages 120fps with dips rarely below 100 on Ultra + Nightmare Settings.  To top it all off Mick Gordon's soundtrack on this game is amazing, his work on Wolfenstein: TNO and Killer Instinct was great but this legendary, one of the best original soundtracks in a game I've ever played.   So do I recommend this... If you played Doom in mid 1990s yes 100%.   If you want a Doom 3 like experience... NO  If you want a new CoD.... try it you might like it.  Also play it on Ultra-Violence minimum, it isn't a complete walk in the park then, it's a challenge.

Now. Before I start the Review off: I have as of this moment NOT Completed the main Story.   <This is a Spoiler Warning. Do not proceed if you do not wish to see the Main Plot Spoiled.>   DOOM 2016 is here to bring back the classic fast-paced gameplay of Id's original DOOM released in 1993. but Just how well does this game hold up? From a Story perspective It involves you in the Story much more than the Original game did. To a point of having moments where the Pace of the game is broken by, Say. being locked in a room while you're spoken to. Although from a Gameplay perspective, Ignoring all moments of Pace-breaking Dialogue and In-game Cutscene (That is to say, a Cutscene where you are free to Move Doomguy around the map.) This game is VERY Fast-Paced, You can tell right off the bat that the Devs wanted to keep the player constantly on the move. and it Shows. taking a hit in this game is Punishment in it of itself, as much like the Original 1993 DOOM. Your only method of repairing health damage is to pick up a Medical Kit. although they have improved upon this with the Glory Kill system, which Plays a fancy little animation in which an enemy dies in a Spectacularly gorey way by your hands, Said enemy drops a Set amount of health (Dependant on what Percentage your own Health Bar is at.) Singleplayer has also handled Bosses quite well. (Well. the One boss I have faced.) As the Cyberdemon helps to both bring new things to the Table, while retaining it's old feel. For example, the CD keeps his missiles as his Main method of attack. but starting with his Second Phase, he begins slashing with his Blade Arm, making you constantly have to Move.   (Multiplayer.)  From a Multiplayer Perspective (Bear in mind, I have only played Ten matches of it to formulate this Opinion.) DOOM Brings back the Gameplay of Arena-Based Shooters, While incorperating the Custom Loadout functions of Modern FPS games like Halo, Call of Duty. Battlefield, you get the Idea. And much like these other games, You can also customise your Multiplayer Character to look 'Unique.'  Now to the gameplay. It's an Arena Based shooter, where sadly you cannot Pick-Up another Enemy's weapon upon their death. Which I find to be an interesting choice as Many other First-Person Shooters allow this function. Another thing of note is that you find Powerups. Be it Partial Invisibility or Quad Damage. You can also find two 'Power Weapons' on the Map. one of them is the Classic BFG-9000. while the other is the More recently-added Gauss Cannon. Both of them are Equally Devastating (With the BFG Being slightly moreso.) The last point of note is the 'Demon Rune.' in which If you pick it up. you are Transformed into one of four demons of your choosing. This I feel is a rather Irritating addition, as if an ally picks it up. Your team is Denied kills as this Ally Gets the Instant-Kill abilities of whichever Demon they have become. And if an Enemy gets it, Your team will be Respawning constantly. unable to kill this Unstoppable Demon. That's why they had added a Newer function. If the Demon Perishes prematurely. you can pick up the Rune, and become a Demon yourself. with the leftover Countdown of the Other Demon. this cycle continues until the Pickup dissapears, Or the match ends.   I unfortionantly cannot add my Two Cents for Snapmap, as I wish to wait until the game is several weeks old - So that Snapmap will have had time to recieve Well-made levels, and Possible updates.   Overall. My review. Singleplayer - Highly Enjoyable. Multiplayer - Needs work, but I do Enjoy it. Snapmap - N/A

I should start off by mentioning that I only played this game's single player. I'm not big into competitive online shooters, but I do like a good single player experience. Doom 4 is a great single player game. It's love of keeping it old school makes it a breath of fresh air in a genre that at times suffers from a lot of sameness. Doom 4 is a game that has absolutely no interest in realism. Health and ammo explode out of demons for no reason, Doomguy can double jump and always runs at full speed, and reloading is for ♥♥♥♥♥es. I love that there is no regenerating health in this game. The best way to get health is to weaken and then melee kill a demon. In other words the game is structured in a way that the best solution to your problems is never to hide behind a wall. Instead, the best way to improve your situation is to kill demons and never stop until the credits roll. It's easily the most Metal game I've played in a long time and if you want a different kind of shooter then I'd highly recommend it.

I am going to give a seperate review for each mode of the game.  Multiplayer: This mode is extremely fun, with competetive as well as cooperative gameplay with a variety of modes, and apparently modes within modes. It is extremely fun to play. However, the 'deathmatch' mode doesn't work for me. Whenever I select it the game doesn't load past the 'connecting' stage. It isn't that big of a deal, however, as all the other modes still work.  Campaign: This gamemode is possibly the center of the game. The good things about it are: The gameplay is extremely fun, fast-paced, and challenging. The secrets are hard to find but very rewarding when you do find them (and very fun to search for). The bosses are easy enough to be fun to fight, and hard enough to not be disappointed. Also, the storytelling is very good. There really is nothing that I have to complain about this.  Snapmap: I don't have any complaints for this mode. None. So, why don't I talk about the good things? For starters, this mode is extremely fun. This is basically a community-powered multiplayer mode, and is fun to see what other people come up with. Also, it is extremely fun to contribute to the snapmap community and be creative with your level designs.   Miscellaneous: The game crashes. A lot. I have had it crash four times during normal gameplay, and it crashes almost every time when trying to load up a mode of the game. (i.e. Campaign, multiplayer) So basically what you have to do is Load up the game in campaign mode, load it up in a different mode, restart your computer, load up the game in campaign mode again, and THEN load it up in the other mode. It is really quite time consuming and annoying. Also, I haven't been a victim of this yet, but I have heard many complaints about the dreaded 'Developer mode'. If this is as bad as it sounds, I would recommend fixing it. I think it should quite possibly being your first priority when addressing the issues with this game. Also, this didn't affect me that much, but after the second crash during gameplay when I loaded the game back up I got a notification saying that some of my data became corrupted and deleted. The things that got deleted were: My classic maps in the campaign and all of my multiplayer data. It would be disappointing had I not only been level 2 in multiplayer.   In short: This is a great game. Excellent storyline, great graphics, fast-paced, and extremely fun modes. Also, you get to absolutely massacre demons. I don't think I mentioned that yet. Thank you for taking the time to read this extremely long and time consuming review.

Doom is a brilliant homage to it's predecessors. Doom does a great job feeling like a Doom game. It's face-paced, gory, silly, and does not apologize once for this mix. It attempts to tell a story, but I wonder if we're supposed to care about it. That's not saying the story was bad, it just didn't drive the game. Hunting for secrets and shooting everything that moved was more than enough.   Doom is brilliant with it's simplistic combat system. Doom is a callback to the shooting games of old. There is no spamming reload to keep a fresh magazine for 'when you need it.' You simply collect bullets for your favorite gun and shoot as long as you have ammo. The only exception is the super shotgun, which I suspect reloading is only for balancing the damage.  Somewhere along the way we've forgotten that our shooting games could be fun which makes Doom so much better. It's FUN, and that's the most important part about it. The game literally tells you almost every chance it gets through tips and hints: 'Don't stand still.' Most shooting games, encourage you to wait in the shadows for health to regen, or to pick off opponents from a distance with a sniper rifle. Not Doom. Doom kicks that school of thought square in the teeth and encourages the player to charge head-long into the fray, shotguns blazing, raining brass over the fallen corpses of your victims.  FINAL thought: Buy this f$%king game right meow. If you like murdering EVERYTHING.

Hello to all you people who are uncertain about buying this brutally amazing game.  This is Doom, in all it's glory and gore. From playing the singleplayer campaign (for just a short time), it is clear that this 4th instalment maintains Doom's perfect action - horror mix (unlike a certain game who's name I wish not to remember, let alone mention). For a minor insight: about 10 minutes in, Doomguy ripped a possessed soldier's arm out, and smashed the soldier's head with it, right in front of my eyes. Simply epic. Now, the multiplayer, I don't really like that DOOM needs to restart in multiplayer mode in order to play the demon multiplayer, I find seeing my steam window mid gameplay rather depressing, like my game has suddenly crashed like they all used to on my craptop, although I guess I should get over this eventually. The gameplay itself is fast paced, much like that of the campaign, the weapons are fun and well balanced (although I find the chaingun slightly OP), and the demon summoning element is as exciting as it is challenging - all great fun!  A few minor flaws: - Always online DRM, I don't really see much of a problem with this, i play on my gaming PC, so I've always got a network connection, and it does kind of help against piracy, so I don't see this as a reason to dislike the game.  - Settings from singleplayer won't be applied to multiplayer (and vice versa), so if I configure my graphics settings in singleplayer, I have to do it again for multiplayer (and vice versa).  - And one small point: when a new colour is unlocked for either my armour or my weapons, it isn't unlocked for the other, which I was rather confused about to begin with, it would be nice to have my armour match my shiny weapons.   Overall, DOOM is amazing, and people are leaving bad reviews for nit-picking problems.

I am well aware I am not the first person to say this. Massive levels, large kill rooms, and a near endless way to kill monsters, and be rewarded for it, in both the literal sense of getting healt or armor pick ups out of them, or upgrade points for killing enough of them, but also to simply enjoy the utter almost ridiculous level of carnage you can inflict upon a army of demons.   And if you think its too easy, you can ramp it up to ultra nightmare, which is just glorious to behold.   If you liked doom, or like fps in general, you'll want to play this.  Edit: Just a small bit of a personal editorial to this.  There is nothing quiet so satisfying as being able to walk into any room of the game filled with varying demons, and think, 'I have a super shot gun; this is going to be fun'. No reloading, no 'stamina' just you, your gun, your health meter (which does helpfully beep at you when its low, but not annoyingly, just a gentle reminder you need to get up close and physical with a demon to execute it and get a little health back. If only Navi was this helpful.) and a personal arsenal in order to deal a wonderfully realized array of death to demons. Its just satisfying.   Also, Doom guy is a protagonist that plays the 'Strong, silent' type so perfectly well. All you know, is he is the angry marine with a shotgun and to stay out of his way while he does his job.

All in all when it comes to the game for Single player, Multiplayer, and SnapMap features this game is worth every penny.   Single player,  In depth environments that have plenty of atmosphere and little hidden places for you to scavenge goodies and dolls (Fistbump). The attitude of Doom guy as you progress within the game is literally him giving zero ♥♥♥♥♥ about anything. You play as a badass, that’s it. The weapons and upgrades you get for them are pure awesome, the armor upgrades can assist you for much harder levels and difficulties, the Runes are decent adding more of a 'perk' thing within the game. More than plenty Demons to kill and it makes me wanting more, which leads to SnapMap features!  SnapMap, What’s better than killing hordes of demons by yourself? KILLING THEM WITH YOUR FRIENDS OF COURSE! The features of snapmap go way more in depth than I'm even able to explain. You could do almost anything with what it offers and from what I've played, I haven't even scratched the surface of the possibilities. Not even a few hours ago before this review I was playing with a friend and the game mode was literally playing Hide-and-Seek with 2 Hellknights and 1 baron. Craziest thing I've ever done in a game and it was perfect. Dark rooms, custom smoke clouds everywhere, and the only thing keeping you from getting caught was when you could hear the stomping of their feet and their gnarly ♥♥♥ growls as they got closer to you.  Multiplayer, I played Closed-beta and for the most part it was OK at best. Definitely had some balancing issues and to be honest it still does to an extent. Open beta was improved with running speed but that was the only thing I noticed. Finished game weapon balancing is noticeable and much appreciated because when I played the beta it was nothing but Vortex Rifles, Super shotty, and Rocket launchers. Now it feels a little bit more balanced but a few things here and there COULD be improved but I'm not complaining because I love playing with friends painting the place red.  In short, Do your own research and come to your own conclusion to whether or not you want the game. There have been more than enough trolls coming out of the woodwork to detest this game being worth anything JUST BECAUSE OF THE MULTIPLAYER BETA. Don't listen to hipster/nostalgia ♥♥♥♥ that do nothing but ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan about it not being nothing like Doom 1 and 2. I never played 1 or 2 and I don't care to. This game is fun, campaign is long, intense, and non-stop action. Having SnapMap brings replayability to a much larger scale and I appreciate everything ID have done for us.

(Not the following is related to Single Player only, I have not played multiplayer due to performance issues)  I was so excited when i saw the first gameplay trailers for the new DOOM. The unbelivable graphics and fast gameplay filled me with thrills and joy. I couldn't wait for it to release.   That being said, you could imagine my disappointment when I realised that my gaming rig, a 2 year old ASUS ROG g56jr with a measly GTX 760m barely met the minimum graphic card requirements for the game.  Never the less, I was persistent and still bought the game with great optimism. But on native 1080p resolution, the game was slower than a snail. With hours of tinkering and tweaking the settings, I could finally run the game with barely playable FPS of avg 30-35 and Drops as low as 13 on absolute minimum settings at 720p (on a 1080p screen btw).  Even at such dreaded framerates, I played the whole game, and absolutly loved it. The graphics, tho quiet pixelated, were still one of the best I have ever seen (ON MINIMUM I remind you) . The gameplay still action packed and fast paced. The joy of tearing the living sh*t out of demons is unparalled!  Now with the Vulkan API update, the game runs so much smoother and faster. My min FPS has never gone below 30, and averages at around 45, which is a HUGE improvement! This rekindled my excitement for the game, and now i've set out to finish the game again!   I have always loved the doom series, and I always will. This Doom in particular has earned a special place in my heart.  (No comment on Multiplayer)

By far the best Metroid Prime game I've ever played.    It seems like what's old is new again. It feels more like a throwback to Quake II than to the original DOOM, from level design to gameplay, but it works. Take DOOM/II and strip it down to its bare qualities, frankenstein it back together with everything 1990's FPS, then turn the knob to 11.   There wasn't as much psychological strain when it came to overall creep factor though, you can see that the goal of this game was to not repeat DOOM 3. There wasn't a whole lot of fear-inducing moments, and majority of the demons had a very cartoon/caricature quality to them. The level design was superb, but again, a lot of it felt very  Biblical Hell , as if I was walking through a 19th century painting. I only wish there was more absurdity/surrealism to the Hell environment, most of it felt like I was just on another planet.   And I couldn't help but notice the extreme similarities to Metroid Prime I & II though. Replace  Argent Energy  with Phazon, and  Hell  with Dark Aether, and boom, you have Metroid Prime.   Would grin like Doomguy when finding the chaingun again, 10/10

(Although it still felt a bit too easy to stay topped up on ammo.) 5. Monster in-fighting. (Not as common as I'd like as a viable strategy) 6. Glory kills actually aren't repetitive and annoying. (I never saw this coming. Although I turned off the flash) 7. Fast combat suitable for Doom.  Etc etc. I could go on but you get the idea. It has a lot of things going for it. It isn't perfect though and one of my biggest gripe with it is mostly this. Too many monster arenas. You know the ones. You walk in, the doors close, monsters spawn in waves and you kill them all and leave. Common in Serious Sam and Painkiller. I don't find them engaging or interesting. Ok, i have to tell you that i'm an old Doom player. In my long PC gamer career (about 20 years) all my hard disks got Doom on them. And i have huge expectation for this game.  The question for many is: Doom is back? Well, the question is wrong. This isn't Doom HD Remastered. This game has a lot of old Doom's in his veins but a lot of good stuffs were lost and a lot of new good things are in.   Just ask: Is this game good? Overall the new Doom is a very good game. Fast, adrenalinic, bloody, funny to play and difficult as well.  The gunplay rocks. It's the ol' good ID secret formula. You can hate Rage and Doom 3 but, just as all ID games, when you pull the trigger here comes the magic.  The bad things?  1 - The chainsaw. Is not a weapon anymore. It's more like a consumable item that instakill enemies and gift you a lot of ammo performing a kill. Stop. You can't use it as a normal weapon. You can't complete a level using only the CS. Sounds weird, isn't it? I take a couple of hours to get used to. The exploit works as intended (as an item that give you ammo without distract you from the action), but i miss the freedom of using only the chainsaw to clean a room.  2 - The pink demons. They are tankish mob instead of swarming foes. It's only matter of taste but i miss when i used to kill them with one, close range, shot of supershotgun (ofc you can 'easily' kill them from behind even now).    And what about discussed Glory Kills? I was really sceptical about them but i have to change my mind. Glory Kill system works and doesn't annoy me. The animations are fast and the flow of the action is not affected by them. Rather, i think the game gain some rhythm. Shoot, shoot, punch, loot. - Shoot, shoot, punch, loot. - and again and again.  Add to this rhythmic flow a stunning soundtrack and u got it. Let's Dance with demons and guns. :) Yes, soundtrack deserve a few more words. OST change from industrial metal in the Mars facility to gothic gregorian chant in hell. Both styles are very good and pump adrenalin your veins during epic fights. Turn off the music if you want to waste half of the fun.  In the end? Maybe it doesn't deserve 60-70€/$ (just as any other game out there, IMHO), but for the 25/30 price on key stores or in future sales you can take a solid, funny and well polished old style FPS.  Note: I'm probably at half or more of the single player campaign (after 10 hours). I don't even scratched multiplayer or Snapmap. Didn't read very good impressions about the first. In other hand, Snapmap sound promising (except for this 4 player limits).

[PROS] ◆ Great customization options for praetor suit and weapons ◆ Thrilling atmospheric metal/electro music ◆ Stunning graphics with a lot of gore involved ◆ Fast-paced gameplay ◆ Countless hordes of demons ◆ Hidden retro levels as kind of a goodie ◆ No FPS cap, highly adjustable in-game settings <3  [CONS] ◆ Only 13 missions in total (about 13h of actual gameplay) ◆ Secrets are not that hard to find (indicators on map) ◆ Repetitive glory kills  In a nutshell: All needed for a great DOOM comeback ;)   Addendum: After finishing the campaign and looking for the last missing retro chamber levers as well as completing all mission challenges, there are a few downsides to this game for me.  █ Performance █ First of I experienced more than 3 random game crashes in the last hours of gameplay. If that was the case the game either crashed instantly or the framerate started to drop drastically in the beginning. Despiting the fact that this game runs solid smooth on my rig (about 90 fps avg on Ultra settings), it's kind of annoying when this happens in the middle of a fight and you have to repeat all over again.  █ Design Aspects █ Secondly the game heavily feels like it has been optimized for console in the first place, even though its developers intended to make it the ultimate next-gen pc game.  Let's have a look on the weapon wheel. If you're about to switch weapons with the help of the weapon wheel, the in-game time slows down in order to suggest that your player is reacting in a lightning-fast way and - of course - to allow easy weapon selection on a controller. My questions here are, why does id Software implemented this feature for the pc version at all, and why do we - as the Masterrace Community - don't get the option to disable either the weapon wheel itself and/or the slow-motion effect?  Now to the hyped Glory Kill System. This is the reason where DOOM (4) got his fast-paced playstyle from, because every time you perform a Glory Kill on an enemy, he drops a ton of health and ammo packs. Looking for resources by roaming whole sectors on the map is in the past and not necessary anymore, except for armor (!there is already a rune to compensate for that!) and BFG ammunition. What I don't like about this is that you're invincible while you perform a Glory Kill. This, again, only seems to attribute to the console generation in order to make things easier for them.  █ Multiplayer █ Until now I haven't tested the MP, but the COD-like Loadout-System and the inability to change weapons during a fight - by picking up weapons dropped by dead enemy players - seems a bit fishy to me. This won't affect my rating for this game since I only focus on the campaign mode.  █ Conclusion █ After all this still doesn't affect my rating for DOOM (4), but you can tell that all negative aspects of this game are in fact referable to the obnoxious console generation.

Doom is too much fun.  I've played a bit of the original doom games, but i have played and completed the original doom on IOS (dont laugh please) and have played a metric butt-load of brutal doom, which i still love very much.  i was very sceptical of the new doom title ever since the first trailer was released, and my skepticism increased even more when i played the... lukewarm multiplayer beta. Now that the game has released, i can safley say that those worries and doubts have been completley diminished by what is a stellar first person shooter, worthy of the doom title.  Doom builds on what has already been established by the past 20 years of doom games, paying homage to the series when necessary while adding new and exiting mechanics that seperate this game from the other titles in the series. one of the most noteworthy changes to combat is the new glory kill system, which allows players to stagger enemies, get close to them, and begin to rip and tear them to tiny pieces for health and ammunition. this new mechanic keeps you in the action, and lessens the need to run from combat to find armor shards and medkits. this offers a great risk-reward system of attemting to close the gap between you and a horde of monsters for health, or to fall back and avoid further damage.  the chainsaw was introduced in the first trailer caused alot of worry and controversity, and for good reason because it seemed to just be a simple 1-click kill weapon that played a long, boring cutscene of Doom guy ripping and tearing an enemy to bits. thankfully, the chainsaw has been very well implimented, and rewards its use with a shower of health and ammunition, at the cost of fuel for the chainsaw, which is very hard to find.  the level design is better than ever with giant, labrynthian levels with tons of nooks and crannies to explore and tons of different paths to take towards the destination. due the larger and more complex level design, with a greater emphasis on verticality, the map has been updated to include a 3d model of the map which is easy to read, so even players that have poor navigation skills can keep track of where they are.  another fantastic feature is the game's built-in map creator called Snapmap, which allows players to build any level they imagine with the tools the game gives you. you can upload and download any map you want, but keep in mind that a seperate account is required to upload and download maps. Co-op is avalible in snapmap, but not in the singleplayer campaign which is perfectly okay.  I havent played much of the multiplayer, but it is pretty good. dont expect the deepness or complexety found in the likes of CS:GO, Quake, or Reflex, instead expect a fun distraction from the main meat and potatoes of the game. (I may update this portion of the review as i put in more time in the multiplayer, which i intend to do.)  this game is fantastic, and is also a great chalange on the higher difficulties, demanding proper movement, accuracy and reflexes to combat the forces of hell. This game is a love letter to doom fans everywhere, and although some extreme doom zealots may be disgusted by the improvements made in this game, others will be blown away by one of the best FPS games in years, next to games like Wolfenstien the new order and Dying light. this game is a must buy from me.

Pretty rock solid game that feels like the original Doom game but with obvious better visuals. Gameplay takes me back quite a bit to the first release from the way the player moves to the enemies and story line. I enjoyed how some powerups are hidden and take some risk to find and get. They tend to get old real fast as there aren't that many cinematics (atleast per enemy) but you're somewhat forced to trigger the kill glory mechanic as it causes enemies to drop health and in some cases resources like ammo. I feel like if more cinematics were added to address this then the kill glory mechanic wouldn't get as stale as it did for as quick as it did.  The powerups are fun so far but they seem to be few and far between although it may be that I just haven't figured out a good way to unlock them yet.  The soundtrack is very much alike that of something from a Nine Inch Nails album which positively adds to the experience. Nothing like killing multiple enemies from hell while some NIN-type music is keeping up the pace with the mayhem. Parts of the game have an eerie vibe to it as well due to the music which gives it a nice atmosphere.  Pros: - Fast gameplay - Feels like the original Doom - Story is entertaining enough to warrant following - Music matches the gameplay and style of the game - Weapons are pretty fun to use, very Doom-like  Cons: - Kill glory cinematics tend to get old somewhat fast, especially given your reliance on them to get health and ammo  Overall, real positive throwback to the original Doom game. Would recommend.

The original Doom made waves in the gaming community not because of speed, guns or gore alone, but because its developers understood what the market needed and didn't quite have. As a veteran Doomer, I have to give id Software props for being able to make that call again. The gameplay here is a perfect match for the technology and tastes of the current era -- and that's exactly what the original got right during its time.  This new entry in the franchise preserves the classic arcade combat we've come to expect while adding a few layers of customization to both incentivize secret-hunting and keep demon encounters fresh. It's a reward system like that of the original, but buffed to meet the ambitions of the modern gamer. This is a recurring theme throughout the game; everything feels Doomish in that it's lean and kinetic, yet there is AAA-level substance as well. Not an easy balance to achieve as we've seen with hundreds of failed '90s-inspired titles. Respect.  The levels are expansive. The AI is ferocious and can go wherever you can. The weapons kick ♥♥♥. It's worth a buy for the campaign alone, but the multiplayer certainly isn't bad either. Add a decent in-game editor to the package and it's a great value for the money. Rejoice; Doom is back.

The addition of the classic view point for weapons is indicative of just how much this game is meant to pay homage to and revel in it's roots. A fast-paced, straight-forwards shooter with a hellscape aesthetic: it stands as a shot in the arm for the first person and shooter genres that have stagnated in the last decade. While admittedly the art style is hardly fully faithful as its most iconic elements are merely borrowed for recognitions sake and it suffers much of the modern visual trend of all blending together (though it does have some nice color contrast in areas saving it from completely drowning in single colors), and the gameplay is more reminicent of Quake or Unreal than the original Doom, nonethless it is a highly worthwhile addition to anyone's library and one that I've not only returned to a few times already, but that I'll want to play years from now.  That said the multiplayer is as generic and modern as you can get. Absolutely no creativity was employed in putting together the exact same gameplay you could get in Halo, Battlefield or Call of Duty. It should come as no surprise then it was made by the people who put together CoD's multiplayer modes. To be fair, if you like that then here you go, more of the same. However, it departs so heartily from the single-player experience it really makes you question why bother at all? Why play it so straight in the single-player and then revert back to the status quo for online play? I'm guessing despite Bethesda banking on the multiplayer (the season pass is all multiplayer content), we'll see a nice single-player map pack, or dare I dream, full episode expansions in the future so hopefully everyone wins in the end.

I would first like to point out that the always-online DRM was a bug for Vulkan API, and it's since been fixed. Online DRM never existed if you didn't use Vulkan, and it's since been patched out, because it was a bug. Don't listen to the people whining about it because it was a temporary mistake, and it's not there anymore.  TL;DR It's great. The singleplayer is the best shooter I've played in years and years, the multiplayer is meh, and the snapmap has some pretty awesome stuff.  Normally, in a modern shooter, the best tactics involving long bouts of not doing much of anything.  A huge mob of baddies in front of you? Just shoot and back-pedal. That's what you do in, for instance, Left 4 Dead. Low on health? Just take yourself out of the fight, hide behind some cover and wait for the jam to clear off your face and you're right as rain. This part is too tough for you to do normally? Just sit back, snipe at them, and go in when their number is thinned down.  Doom involves pretty much none of that. Sure, you can do the back-pedal and shoot, and it is possible in a couple of places to snipe enemies before engaging. But even in those instances, they're not good tactics. Instead, you'll be constantly rushing into combat because that's the best tactic. Not least because the enemies, though weaker than you, are about as mobile - imps will jump around all over the fantastically designed 3D arenas, Hell Knights will rush into you way faster than you could run away, and even the nearly-stationary Mancubuses can leap between ledges and shoot at you from far away.  The weapons, in stark contrast to most shooters and more akin to Quake or Unreal Tournament, all behave quite differently instead of being just minute stat differences. They all promote more thinking with your environment, and there is progression in the game that allows you to unlock new special abilities for the weapons.  One thing that this game does incredibly well is that whenever you get hit, it's your fault. Everything, and I mean everything, can be dodged or avoided. The design philosophy seemed to be that you should be able to avoid ever getting hit if you're good enough, and it works extremely well. Almost all of the shooting by the enemies is done with non-instant projectiles, and the few that are hitscan give plenty of warning before being used (such as a 'bullet hell'-type laser that shows itself before doing damage).  The way to get health and armor is by finding it in the world. Alternatively, you can weaken enemies until they become staggered, at which point you can initiate a gory and satisfying Glory Kill, immediately killing them and causing them to drop health. This is a fantastic example of give-and-take, because even though that both saves ammo and gives health, it could put you in more danger and makes you think quickly about the environment.  Outside of the unbelievably amazing singleplayer, the game offers a multiplayer and what they call snapmap. The multiplayer is extremely mediocre, and it certainly can serve a couple hours of fun. It's not really that great with friends, and ultimately it feels less like multiplayer and more like random, disjointed running around hoping you find another player that you are allowed to kill.  Snapmap is a great place to find things to do. There are all kinds of different things to find, from trivia quizzes to arenas to entire maps devoted to providing the same kind of experience as the singleplayer. If you played through some of the community content for Warcraft 3 or Starcraft 2, you know exactly the kinds of things you'll be able to find. You can also make your own, and it's pretty simple to learn and still fairly powerful, though there are definitely a few shortcomings.  Ultimately, this game is a purchase I'll never regret. The fighting in it was an absolute breath of fresh air from the stale Battlefield and CoD series, which basically got one super succesful game and never deviated from their formulas.

Short Story, lovers of the classic doom should find new dooms gunplay and violence a new refreshing take on an already amazing series of games.  I enjoyed the single player beginning to end, and snapmap gives the game all the much more playability. Multiplayer, while I havent played much, is fair and fun from my experience. I definetely recommend this to anybody who loves just some mindless, demon slaughtering fun.

Doom 3 came out right when I went to college and I tried many times to get into it. It never really caught my attention after a few hours and I've still to this day never beaten it.  I remember seeing DOOM II on the shelf at 'SUN Electionics' in the east but never buying it.  So basically it's been 20 years or more since there's been a true DOOM follow up, and this game is exactly that. In a way, I like this game the most in the entire series. It's a no-nonsense balls to the wall splatterhouse of fun that is like a constant adrenaline rush you've likely not experienced in a game possibly ever. There have been some very interesting Snapmaps, but not enough people playing them. There is literally almost no one playing any of them in matchmaking right after release, which really sucks.   All in all, this is a ♥♥♥♥ing awesome brutal amazing video game you need to own and play multiple times.

All in all a brilliant return to the classic FPS, with all the benefits of new technologies added.  SP: The campaign is long and keeps you on the tip of your seat for the entire time. There are plenty of difficulty settings, the hardest of which will have you die a lot. The demons feel very powerful, especially when you encounter new ones and don't know what to do against them yet. The demons in the boss fights are very different from each other and will probably kill you a few times before you know how to counter all their attacks. The movement and gameplay is superb. This is a 100% classic id game with full movement control, but now with some nice mobility additions that make it even more fun. The glory kill system is also surprisingly fun and provides you with a way to gain some health back when needed.  I'd rate the SP a solid 10/10. It's a must play for every FPS fan.  MP: The gameplay in MP is fun and has some interesting new additions, like the possibility to play as a demon, but wanders quite far from original id shooters in concept. There are no weapon pickups (except for the BFG), so you choose 2 weapons to start with and will be stuck with those until you die. This takes away some of the important gameplay aspects from the classic shooters, like map control and quick switching to more appropriate weapons when needed. The lack of classic modes as FFA, instagib, CTF,... is also inexcusable. We can only hope they decide to add them in the near future. The unlock system is more fun than I thought it would be. The weapons unlock fast and you're not at a disadvantage with the stock weapons. You can spend some time modifying your character if you're into that stuff. In short, the MP leaves something to be desired, but is not that bad either, I'd rate it 7/10.  Snapmap: It's a good concept, but not at all a replacement for real map making and modding tools. It's clear that the console market has had an impact in the dumbing down of this game. I really hope some proper modding tools get released.

So, straight out of the gate I'll just say the game is a solid 80/100.  I played it for roughly 45 minutes, and spent another 45 minutes burried in menus, console commands, diagonstics, driver installs, forum posts, and Bethesda's technical support. After about 90 minutes I reluctantly gave up and requested a refund.  I'm not kidding.  Grade: B 4 out of 5 stars. Certified fresh on Rotten Tomatoes. Pick whatever metric you like.  Here's the thing:  I had massive technical difficulties that made the game practically unplayable. There was a consistent and cronic stutter that hitched and skipped both audio and framerate. I mean look at this sentence...   'I ho ou know wh ou're g et t ing y oursel f int o.'  That, right there, was CONSTANT. Not only that, but duuring fire fights these lapses in time would translate to falling of ledges or cliffs and plenty of lost targets and unintentional deaths. Between those gaps? 60-70 fps. Completely inexplicable. It's not like I have old hardware either... I run an i7 4770 @ 3.5GHz, 16GBs or RAM, a GTX 960 4GB, and a 2TB SSHDD with 6GBs of transfer, along with the most recent drivers available. Fallout runs a respectable 40 fps in Ultra quality. *shrug*  So, why 8/10?  Two reasons. First, the game itself - while unplayable for me - still looks fun as hell (pun initially not intended but now that I think about it, I'm totally intending it) and I can imagine how awesome it would be whipping around the well-crafted levels that circulate action around like a waterpark ride at break-neck speeds feeling like an absolute badass as I splash-damage and glory-kill my way through demonic hordes. The promise is there, but either my system or the software is unwilling. It looks like the best kind of throwback carnage I used to relish in my early gaming days, and given the so many other broken promises of other reboots and homages claiming to recapture that nostalgia, it's a feat in itself that DOOM appears to succeed at this.  Second, It is totally self-aware of it's absurdity. Doomguy is an ill-adjusted individual in a world of ill-adjusted gospel. Hell is the joke in Doom in very much the same way corruption is the joke in politics, capitolized upon in - I assume - almost every way possible. Hell is 'worth it.'  Now, here's the downside: where Doom succeeds, it simultaneously falls flat. If you ever played the original Doom or Doom II during their heyday, this will be an easier concept to grasp. If you only played Doom or Doom II within the last 10 years for the novelty or simply to experience gaming's roots, then you'll likely miss what I'm getting on about.  Doom in it's heyday was REVOLUTIONARY. No one had seen anything like it, and it was this sense of awe along side the addictive gameplay that made Doom the phenomenon it is known for. Capturing that sense of awe - of something truly new and exciting - is impossible, and in that respect it will never outshine the original - certainly if you covet those fond memories playing for the first time nearly two-and-a-half decades ago. As nice as it looks, it just doesn't recapture that magic.  Assuming there will be a patch that rectifies the performance issues, I will happily pick this puppy up again and charge headlong through those firey gates of blissful carnage. Until then, I'll be living out my demon-slaying fantasies vicariously through twitch streams and youtube speed runs, pining away until the day my machine decides it's ready to play.  Eight out of ten, would suffer through tech support again.

You will love the new Doom if you played the original from the 90's. The game has the same unusually high player movement speed like the original. The weapons feel fun effective and accurate. The combat encourages strafing to avoid getting hit and going back in the level to search for power ups or ammo. All these simple things became uncommon in modern tunnel like first person shooters with self healing players. If you never played the early id Software shooters like Wolfenstein or Doom you will probably find this concept refreshing. Technically the game reaches an extreme level of perfection in graphics and sound. The id Tech engine had really a lot of trouble with graphic card drivers in Rage and the new Wolfenstein. Now in the new Doom it finally feels rock solid even on AMD hardware with the Vulkan API. Not much texture popping, nice anti alias etc. New game elements? There are enough of them to keep you motivated. There are weapon upgrades, challenges and skill upgrades. The levels almost always use the height as a dimension. They are fun to explore and navigate in. 10/10 for me. Get this game if you haven't done yet.

DOOM is a truly excellent game. It's a good return to form for first person shooters, by returning gamers to interior levels that are akin to mazes and some big open exterior levels added in for flavor. In so many ways, it's even better than shooters of the past and feels more like a 'survival shooter' than even classic DOOM. Here are the positives (+) and negatives (-) of DOOM:  + Incredible and fast paced action. Immediately, the game doesn't waste time and throws you right into the fray!  + Tons of secret areas and hidden goodies encourage exploration. This was sorely needed in today's shooter market... and I mean something that isn't open world!  + Level design is TOP NOTCH. An excellent combonation of linear paths connecting to big atriums and even open ended areas. The level design is directly built into the action and encourages a variety of ways to move in combat.  + No regenerating health! Armor and health pickups! Ammo of varying types! Powerups!  + Absolutely EXCELLENT survival and resource management elements during combat! Ammo runs out relatively fast for every gun, encouraging weapon switching, using the chainsaw, and glory kills. Health and armor are drained relatively fast too, encouraging more than just the things I mentioned, such as running around looking for pickups.  + Vulkan Mode ensures massive amounts of scalability even for older gaming hardware!  +/- Upgrades and runes reward players for their efforts and exploring. However, some upgrades feel useless and are far too situational.  +/- Surprisingly good main character who is by far the most expressive silent protagonist so far!  +/- Extensive amount of lore. If you are willing to dig through all the subtle clues, hints, and lore items, you'll find a decent story behind the mayhem.  +/- SnapMap is AWESOME, but feels limited and lacking in a few areas. It's a damn solid treat to return to, especially for community events and free updates.  - Multiplayer is fun and makes this a complete value package, but it's quite frankly just a solid experience. It's not good enough for oldschool shooter multiplayer fans. Weapon balance is still completely off, hack modules still provide too much of an advantage, and armor still acts as a second health bar.  - A tiny amount of bugs and issues that don't hamper the experience too much.

This game is mindless shooting, over and over and over, and it is perfect because of that. It does not have the tension and fear of Doom 3, it is all action, fast and furious with great graphics and a great soundtrack. As FPS go, this is about is purely entertaining as it gets. There is no reason to hide behind things, you must keep moving, jumping, picking things up, all while selecting weapons and blasting everything that moves in to messy bloody chunks. If you want a little bit more depth, there are things to find, both optionally as secrets (models, and more useful 'rune challenges' which give selectable upgrades) and because you have to find keycards. It's much less stress than Doom 3, because you don't wait in fear of being attacked, you are almost always being attacked, there is no time to think, just shoot. If you liked the orginal doom, you will love this. If you never played the original doom, you will probably still love this. If you kind of liked doom 3 but didn't like that feeling of things jumping out at you (like alien isolation), this is nothing like it. Even on the hardest out of the box setting of ultra violence, there is still plenty of ammo to keep blasting. You never die because of a reload either, if you run out of ammo it swaps weapon for you and you just keep shooting.  Perfect FPS, the only problem is it crashes every now and then. There are frequent checkpoints though so if it does crash you don't lose any progress. If you enjoy shooting things without any tactical thought other than using ledges and platforms, this is for you. It's easy to learn how to play it in less than 5 minutes, and then it just gets better and better the more you play.  There is a bit of replayability if you want to get all the collectibles, and anyway, once you finish it you get harder modes unlocked. I didn't try the MP yet, but I have plenty of MP games nd it is nice to have an old school single player game to just blow stuff to bits, and a choice of two shotguns :) It's very fun and very gory. Oh, and the chainsaw is awesome. UPDATE: Now I have finished the game, I will add there is replayability in this game and it carries on being fun. When you are not rushing through and have time to find all the secrets, there are loads of nice little touches and attention to detail. For example, I am getting the collectable models, which involve collecting little mini marines. When you find the doom marine collectable... well I won't spoil it, but let's just say he does something different to all the others :) The challenges on each level are all varied and different, the secrets, some of them take a lot of exploring around, and the weapon challenges are the most fun of all. One of them involves killing 5 hell knights with a headshot, another is killing 5 summoners with locked on missles (they teleport away when you try this). There are dozens of challenges between the weapons, level challenges, and secrets. The game is not overly hard even on ultra violence, apart from the boss levels (espeically Oliva, really hard). Normal demons are easy enough once you have the weapons, but it's good to know there are extra difficulties for when I have unlocked everything to give me another go at it with more challenge. Superb game, and best of all there are hidden maps from the orignal doom as easter eggs. It's the best Doom ever made, and feels like playing the original, but everything bigger and better. Great job ID software! Uodate 2: for all those who say the game is hard to beat, I did this on ultra violence on my first play through, but if you are struggling... now i have all the upgrades and rune challenges, here is a way to make it VERY EASY! Get the Mobile Turrent upgrade for chaingun, AND mastery so it never overheats, along with the Rich get Richer Rune challenge, and upgrade that. You can then spam everything with the chain gun and never run out of ammo. It is so overpowered it feels like a hack, but it's still fun :)

This game is like a breath of fresh air in an industry saturated with developers trying to create ever more realistic and serious first person shooters. The main reason for this is the fact that the story line is completely optional to follow along with. The Doom Slayer/Hell Walker certainly doesn't care, as shown for his disregard for the other characters, so why should you? However, if you're one of those give-me-a-game-with-lore-and-plot-lines types of people, you can always find the collectibles and read the logs to follow along.  The weapons in this game are fantastic. Every weapon feels delicately balanced, leaving you to make your own preferences; whether you switch weapon for different encounter circumstances, or whether you, like I, choose a weapon that you like and stick by it (I got twice as many kills with the shotgun as my second most used weapon).  The downside to this game is the replayability aspect. I can certainly see this sort of game appealing to those who like to speedrun, as combat is very fast and you have harder difficulties that are unlocked through playing the game. However, I have 100% completed the game on a single save file (all collectibles, upgrades, and logs) due to the fact that you can replay missions with all of your previously unlocked weapons and upgrades, and it only took just over 30 hours. The only reason I would have to come back to this game is if I were to get a monster of a computer and play it at max settings 1440p/4k.

The multiplayer aspect -- be it snapmaps or the actual deathmatches -- is obviously a staple part in this game and for people looking for that type of play this game is a must have. I would highly recommend it still for those wanting a great single player campaign. I never had one moment where the single player campaign was not fun, and the collectibles within the game made it necesarry to replay levels, but it was never dry repetitive gameplay. To conclude, if you are wanting a great single player campaign while looking for a new fps for online play, or a map creator with the snapmaps Doom is for you, and it's worth picking up at full cost. If you're not so focused on the multiplayer fps, or the map creation aspect then the game is still one worth playing, however with a complete run through at 34.7hrs it would be hard to justify spending the whole 60 USD on the game. Still a fun experience that if possible everyone should get the chance to at least experience.

I'll be honest. I was scared for Doom at first. I had a formulaic and hilariously terrible gameplay experience in the closed and open multiplayer betas, and I continued to have that same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ time in the multiplayer after release. You've heard the story about how that component was farmed out to the dipsticks that make the halo multiplayer, and it shows: it's halo with doom-flavored window dressing. But the moment the game launched, I heard nothing but good things about the campaign. I watched the Game Grumps play it, tried the demo, and got the game for myself in the recent Steam summer sale.  The glowing reviews don't even do this game justice. Doom 4 is the perfect unholy marriage of everything that was once good in 90s FPS with what little is nice about modern ones, and its success is both a testament to the quality of that subgenre and a slap in the face to the military shooter I hope it will feel for some years to come. Channeling the first two Dooms with a vengeance, Doom 4 hurls you headlong into the action immediately, with brisk movement speed, no cover, no regenerating health, double jumping (eventually), no reloading, armor pickups, secret areas, powerups, the ability to carry every weapon at once and, if you're a stickler about that kind of thing, no cutscenes. It blends these with the amazing visuals you'd expect from ID's in-house engines and the modern mercy of the objective waypoint, sparing me from those long, agonizing hours of my youth spent blundering about Doom 2's infuriating mazes. New to the series also are alternate fire modes for your weapons, which replace the bland and boring iron-sight gameplay of modern FPS with Unreal Tournament-style combat options, with upgrades for these alt fire modes and 'demon rune' perks that both are earned by and help you do more of the Doomy things you'd already be doing- shooting, rip and/or tearing, and finding secrets. I have heard absolute Doom purists complain about these upgrades, but I find them an enriching addition.  On that note, I must speak to the signature mechanic of the game: the glory kills. It was originally feared that these too fundamentally altered and broke up the signature gameplay of Doom, but I view it from a different angle. They are the icing on a new kind of murder cake that this game has created, and I hope other games will follow its example. This Doom is not just a sequel to Doom 1 and 2, spiritually if not directly. It is the culmination and acknowledgement of the memetic evolution of Doom and its nameless protagonist, including the infamous Brutal Doom mod. The achievements reference everything from classic cheat codes to the doom comic to the 'shoot it until it dies' protip, and the phrase 'rip and tear' is even used in-game. This is the story of Doomguy as the legend he has become, a berserker-packing man-and-a-half who can literally rip demons in twain with his bare hands and just happens to like power armor, guns and chainsaws because they make his job easier. There is just enough plot and lore entries to reinforce this idea, telling a story of a lone champion's eternal vengeance.  The fact that glory kills reward you with health does indeed make the game easier, but that's because the game would be a lot harder if you didn't get health that way. You need to move fast because the demons are numerous and aggressive, and you need to carry all the guns because you actually need that much firepower to tackle everything hell throws your way. You need that armor to survive a few seconds longer, you need those upgrades and runes to give you an edge to offset the demons' numerical advantage... it all creates this gameplay loop that works incredibly smoothly. I enjoyed every moment of the campaign from beginning to end: the fights, the jumps, the secrets, and the plot, which through limited character interaction is very effective at what it does. I only hope that there are campaign add-ons in the future.  With the multiplayer as disappointing as it is, with it's stupidly low time-to-kill ratio and various trappings of the CoD/Nexon/Overwatch genre of shooter, such as instant kills, weird hitboxes and total lack of rocket jumping, I thought my experience with Doom ended when the credits rolled after the campaign. The true surprise then, was the Snapmap mode: A built-in editor that allows you to create your own maps for deathmatches as well as solo or cooperative play, using pre-made room segments to create your own maps, and items, weapons, enemies, AI directors, environmental triggers and other bits that allow you to develop your own gameplay within the confines of the game's assets. It's no true set of mod tools and obviously pales in comparison to what is possible and has been done with classic Doom and Quake, but there is some surprising depth in Snapmap and is worth a look. Importantly, it means there is a form of coop in a game that would otherwise have none, which is a shame, really.  ID is mounting an ongoing effort to improve the multiplayer with additional modes and such, but regardless, this game is about the campaign, and it's really damn good.  See you in hell!

I am pleasantly surprised.  After playing the open multiplayer beta, I was 99.9% sure that this game would become a huge fail in light of Overwatch's sounding success. However, ID obviously took the harsh criticism of the beta to heart and polished the game before launch. Its fast and fun. Also pretty, even at ~60FPS on my old 660Ti.  Things I really like is how I got lost several times on Mars. Yes, that is a *good* thing in our era of linear railshooters. DOOM does not take your hand along for the ride. There is a single opaque marker that points you into the general direction, but how you get there is up to you. The game leads you onto the correct path by subtle and immersive helpers like green flashlights instead of waypoints or an all-powerful minimap.  The combat is super-fluid and rewards experimentation with the environment or the enemies. For example, when the shield-bearing guys have to climb to reach you, they drop the shield while climbing, making them a much easier kill.  You could probably write the entire story of this game on a paper coaster, but that is actually a plus. The original Dooms had a few screens of text to tell you what's going on and did the rest by show, not tell. Doom 3 tried it with cutscenes and characters -- and failed, hard. DOOM gives you a snippet here, a short monolog there, that's it. And that's good! I didn't buy DOOM to listen to a sci-fi version of Lord of the Rings. I bought DOOM to kick some demon ♥♥♥ to hell and back. As a die-hard roleplayer I can say that I still feel very immersed into the game, thanks to the detailed environment and the epic sound and music.  Speaking of immersion, there is precious little of the cheap jump-scare horror of Doom 3 left. Also a plus for me. I never linked that kind of horror to the original Dooms and found it very misplaced in Doom 3. DOOM shows a lot of gore and satanic stuff to build atmosphere, but you won't find any demons jumping out of the furniture.  The most unimmersive thing I came across are runes, which open arcade challenges to earn small upgrades. They rip you out of the game world into a separate instance to shoot barrels and alike before the timer runs out. At first, I was sure the game was pulling my leg, but its actually real. Whoever came up with that idea should be sent to hell himself. Luckily they are optional, so I'll ignore them for the most part.   Having said that, Tracer is still faster than Doomguy and can easily run at 120 FPS on old hardware. I also don't think that DOOM will prevail in the long run against Overwatch, cuz if the majority of players were into lightning-fast action with their higher brain functions turned off, Quake Live would have received much more attention in recent years.  Overwatch is more versatile and more fun overall than rocketjumping arround the same few maps, using the same tactics and the same weapons every day. That also goes for DOOM's singleplayer campaign. The scenery tends to become bland and repetetive very fast.  Either way, if you're into the old DOOM (not Doom 3), get it.   Update: My experiences soured a bit when the singleplayer campaign turned out to be a chain of arena fights with little-to-no atmosphere, other than knowing 'When you pull the battery out of that thing, mobs will spawn.', followed by what can only be described as a boring and SLOOOOOW jump'n'run sequence, which has no place in DOOM for me.  The multiplayer also got very stale after just a few games. The maps are uninteresting and the characters all look the same. No matter how pre-schoolish you color your characters, they are all bland-looking Doomguys. Quake 3 Arena had tons of different models to choose from, and that was over a decade ago. DOOM's extremly antiquated multiplayer may very well become its downfall.

Doom is by far one of the greatest shooters I've ever had the pleasure of playing. It's different than pretty much all other contemporary shooters on the market for a few reasons: namely, this is not a game that rewards those who tend to hang back and shoot from cover. In fact, that's a recipe for getting yourself killed quickly and often. No, this game is for those who have a little more fire in their bones and gasoline in their blood. The game rewards those who perform 'Push-forward' combat, in which you do just that: push forward and kill with the utmost brutality and mercilessness. For those who are just starting out with this game, or who are thinking of picking it up, do it- It's such a cathartic experience to unleash your frustrations and hatred upon demons who are so deserving of it.  From a technical standpoint, the game is also a masterpiece. I've not seen a game this well-optimized in a while. I'm running on my EVGA GTX 970 with an i3-4130 (which is a lower-end dual-core CPU with hyperthreading) and I'm getting well over 100fps at 1080p, sometimes in the 120's, but I keep it locked to 60fps with VSYNC. There are never any frame drops, ever. The textures are gorgeous as well. Well done, id games. I was a massive fan of the original Doom's from the 90's, and this has further solidified my love for the series. If id keeps making games like these, they have a customer in me for life.

The shareware version of the original Doom was the first game I ever played, back when I was a wee 5 year old and I pestered my auntie enough that she showed me the 'cool' games she had on her computer. If The Exorcist and Office Space had a baby, and made The Lego Movie the godparent, DOOM would be the result. A little anti-corporate culture demon spawn result.  [Full disclosure: review is for single player only and I’m not done yet…]  Top 3 reasons to play:  1) Non stop action: every level and gameplay decision was made in favor of ‘makes the game flow better’ (or possibly, ‘makes the gibs fly further’).   Health boosts come from mobs. Combination of melee (glory kills), chainsaw, and health/armor/ammo upgrades mean no more hunting around for that forgotten health pack. The chainsaw, especially, is now super useful to get more health/ammo (risky… but useful).    Gore nests, staged spawn in times, and Summoners make it so there’s no chance of getting the levels wired. To complete some of the upgrade challenges, a Summoner can be left up (though that gets out of hand quickly).    Vertical level design, and the mantle and jump mechanics, are well done. The platforming that’s there, which usually never goes well in an FPS, is spot on. Feels like flying and flows well with normal movement.    Related to the above, there aren’t many stupid geometry/terrain designs (lots of stuff to fall off of though). If you can see a ledge top, more than likely you can reach it. If it looks like you can squeeze between columns/rock walls, very likely you can. Makes it easier to concentrate on gibs...   2) Replayability: secrets, level challenges, suit and weapon upgrades, masteries and rune trials are used for completely different load-outs.   Levels can be replayed as part of the main campaign. This makes is easy to complete missed objectives, weapon masteries and rune trials. Then the new abilities can be used in the main campaign, for new areas. So you can use the load-out you prefer for playing the harder areas.     Masteries and challenges might make you use a weapon a way you wouldn’t normally. Can’t say more without spoilers, but the end result is getting new ways to make even more gibs.    Rune challenges are fun enough that they have their own replay value.    Secrets. Not saying. If you are at all a fan of the series then yeah, you WANT to find all the secrets. If you are a completionist, secret hunting can be used as a breather in between the action hot spots. Or not.   3) Subversive as hell humor, voice overs, and story.   DOOM shines with a storyline that mocks holy hell out of corporate culture and religion equally. The HR spiel from some of the holo-people could’ve come right out of the company I work for. It’s disturbing really.  Voice acting/script/interaction between NPCs is high quality and creative. I actually care what happens to the primary NPCs.  10/10 GotY.   Nominated for the ‘Just 5 More Minutes’ category of The Steam Awards.

THIS IS A REVIEW IN PROGRESS, IT WILL BE FINISHED ONCE I HAVE PLAYED EVERY OUNCE OF THIS GAME.   Hell.  Hell is real, and when you awake from what seems to be an eternity since the last game DOOM takes you right back in from the start. However this Doom is not like the last we had, which was a blend of horror and action, no this Doom goes right back to the roots of the series and pulls no punches in the process.  From the get-go you can see how great the game looks from weapon textures to the bloodstains on the wall, and even though the enemys de-spawn when killed, its still a beautiful bloody mess before they do. when you do go outside on mars it still holds true and looks fantastic, I dont let graphics dictate my purchases though, so lets get down to the good stuff.  I didnt have much of an idea how the single player was going to be, since they havent shown too much, but in the time I HAVE spent with the game has been an absolute blast to play, and it feels SO MUCH like the original dooms it almost makes me sick. The gunplay is smooth, fast and punishing if you slip up. the armor/health around the map is just enough to keep you going, but not enough to hold your hand. THIS IS NOT A HORROR GAME and honestly im torn between hating that and loving it, while I will miss the horror factor from the last game I cant help but welcome my old friend with open arms.  The game has a few new things as well, upgradable weapons, armor, and weapon mods and new to the series and a welcome addition as it matches the gameplay this game has taken.  As of right now the game feels like a solid 9/10, however this will be updated when I finish the single player

I came from the 'golden era' of PC FPS gaming - unreal, quake series, and the original DOOM. It was the original and it was a basic format that all games copied since. It is a basic 'run and gun' game play with maps to explore, secrets, and just solid controls. Simple, but responsive. Quake built on this after Doom and then Doom 3 tried to give us a creepy version of the original with jump scares but just didn't grab everyone as much.   This Doom is a great re-visit to the original formula. It gives you run and gun - it gives you secrets to uncover. Also some solid FPS platforming. And the visuals really hammer it home. Audio is also great.   And for me, the icing on the cake is the multiplayer. On the surface you may just see more space marines...but lets recall who gave us the original space marine FPS - Doom. So iD has every right to bring this into the fold among your CODs and Halo copy cats.   The gameplay is straight out of the late 90s-early 2000s. Its fast, its brutal, unforgiving, but also very satisfying. After playing so many games that get a little stale with very flat maps, or lacking in control, this game really delivers. You get your double jump back, you get your arsenal of weapons, and trash talking via the built in mic support.   If you played Unreal/Quake online back in the day, get this.  If you enjoy very basic FPS single player built around 'Run and Gun', get this. It is the original FPS experience.

[PROS] ◆ Great customization options for praetor suit and weapons ◆ Thrilling atmospheric metal/electro music ◆ Stunning graphics with a lot of gore involved ◆ Fast-paced gameplay ◆ Countless hordes of demons ◆ Hidden retro levels as kind of a goodie ◆ No FPS cap, highly adjustable in-game settings <3  [CONS] ◆ Only 13 missions in total (about 13h of actual gameplay) ◆ Secrets are not that hard to find (indicators on map) ◆ Repetitive glory kills  In a nutshell: All needed for a great DOOM comeback ;)   Addendum: After finishing the campaign and looking for the last missing retro chamber levers as well as completing all mission challenges, there are a few downsides to this game for me.  █ Performance █ First of I experienced more than 3 random game crashes in the last hours of gameplay. If that was the case the game either crashed instantly or the framerate started to drop drastically in the beginning. Despiting the fact that this game runs solid smooth on my rig (about 90 fps avg on Ultra settings), it's kind of annoying when this happens in the middle of a fight and you have to repeat all over again.  █ Design Aspects █ Secondly the game heavily feels like it has been optimized for console in the first place, even though its developers intended to make it the ultimate next-gen pc game.  Let's have a look on the weapon wheel. If you're about to switch weapons with the help of the weapon wheel, the in-game time slows down in order to suggest that your player is reacting in a lightning-fast way and - of course - to allow easy weapon selection on a controller. My questions here are, why does id Software implemented this feature for the pc version at all, and why do we - as the Masterrace Community - don't get the option to disable either the weapon wheel itself and/or the slow-motion effect?  Now to the hyped Glory Kill System. This is the reason where DOOM (4) got his fast-paced playstyle from, because every time you perform a Glory Kill on an enemy, he drops a ton of health and ammo packs. Looking for resources by roaming whole sectors on the map is in the past and not necessary anymore, except for armor (!there is already a rune to compensate for that!) and BFG ammunition. What I don't like about this is that you're invincible while you perform a Glory Kill. This, again, only seems to attribute to the console generation in order to make things easier for them.  █ Multiplayer █ Until now I haven't tested the MP, but the COD-like Loadout-System and the inability to change weapons during a fight - by picking up weapons dropped by dead enemy players - seems a bit fishy to me. Rip and tear, until it is finished.   This truly is DOOM, and a vital return to form for the FPS genre. Gorgeous design meets tightly tuned, addictive, gameplay that doesn't slow down. DOOM is a high contender for Game of The Year for any player, and a true marker and reminder of how good a single player FPS can be.  Don't make the mistake of thinking that DOOM is simply a vehical for a new multiplayer FPS (like the Battelfield and Call of Duty Franchises). The single player is the shining star of this release, and the reason to purchase the game.   I and the many other fans of DOOM are quietly waiting and hoping for a single player DLC or Expansion to continue our bloody crusade through hell.

Well, first up is the gameplay. It's a blast! Combat is frantic and fast paced. Quite a few hidden goodies to find. The music is a matter of taste. If you don't like technoy dubstep, you're going to grind your teeth down to nothing while playing, or I suppose you could just mute it...  I bought the game fairly late so I didn't run into many problems, though for some reason the game runs like absolute ♥♥♥♥ until the opening credits are done and you get to the main menu.  The price is one thing that really ircs me about this game. It's currently $80 in Canada, which is just too much for a 12 hour SP campaign. Thankfully I was able to pick it for $60 off GMG just a couple weeks ago during a sale. So provided you can get it for a decent price, I'd say recommended.  The other thing that irks me is because of the way the game has been programed, small additions to the game, like the new DLC, requires a massive 12GB download. Until it has been downloaded, your game won't launch. It also now sits on my HDD eating up 62.2 GB of space.  There's also Denuvo to consider. What happens when they stop supporting it? Does the game become unplayable? What of the performance impact?  While the game is fun, price, DRM, and bloated download and install size keep me from recommending this game.  Edit: Denuvo removed. Though the install size now sits at 76 ♥♥♥♥ing GB, so I still can't recommend it.

DOOM brings a unique fps experience some people that have yet to try it. It's fast paced, has a huge arsenal of weapons to fight with, crazy fun challenges as the difficulty and enemies get harder and has somewhat a simple story line to it. DOOM does not disappoint in terms of it being like the first and second Doom game's which everyone loved. It has references to the old soundtrack in the new one, fast paced gameplay, the right amount of horror and blood and gore. Not to mention the crazy cool new designs to the demons, weapons and Doomguy himself. In most games about hell and demons, normally you'd have to be the 'chosen one' or have some special weapon or blessing to be able to fend off the demons and other satanic related dangers. And on top of that you have to go on some journey to get that blessing, weapon, etc. What's great about DOOM is that you aren't specifically the 'chosen one' to fight em off, you don't have any specific weapon and your already in the battle since the very very beginning of the game. You're just given the normal weapons used in the UAC facility to shoot things until they die. Also DOOM is nothing dirty, doesn't have anything to do with sexual offense, no drugs involved, disrespect of races, genders, etc unlike some popular games out there. If your looking for a 'Kid friendly game' (for audiences at least 12 yrs. and up or if you feel they're already mature enough) then pick DOOM!! :D If you like shooting things mindlessly with intense blood and gore and brutally awesome sequences of you ripping things apart, this game is for you. If you don't like any of those things buy the damn game anyway just cause. 10/10
