*As of the time of writing this, i've only played ~2 hours of the single-player campaign, this is more or less a first impressions review*  Doom is back and better than ever. Despite the hellish development cycle it went through, id and Bethesda have hit the nail on the head with this absolute gem. I'll go into depth on some of the different aspects below;  Gunplay and the Demons:  Arguably the most important aspect of a Doom game is the arsenal of weapons at your disposal. DOOM captures the absolute brutality of the many weapons up for grabs. Old weapons, like the classic shotgun, plasma rifle and Super shotgun make their return, and there are a few new ones in store. Each weapon has its own time and place to be used effectively, and can be adapted to face numerous situations through a weapon modding and upgrading system. The sound design on the weapons is phenomenal - each weapon feels like it has its own kick, and all of them, including the lowly pistol, sound like they pack one hell of a punch. Of course all these weapons need to pack a punch when you're tearing apart the legions of hell with smoldering lead, or plasma, or your bare hands. All your nasty old friends from Doom return once again; including zombies, Imps, Pinkies and the Barons. Most of them function for the most part like their older counterparts, and some have even been giving secondary and tertiary abilities never before seen. The demons are numerous, bloodthirsty and hell bent on trying to kill you, or are they trying to escape? Either way, pick your tool, and nail those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in all the gore spattered glory that is DOOM.   Gameplay:  DOOM welcomes back the fast and fluid gameplay which made the original Doom and Doom II so good, and even introduces a few new aspects that can be observed as derivatives from fan mods (such as Brutal Doom). The glory kills mechanic fits into the fluidity of the combat extremely well. In no sense does it hinder your progress to curb stomp an Imps' head in. Movement, aiming and navigation are smooth, and surprisingly quick, calling back to the old Quake days. The maps (which are bloody massive by the way) can be traversed in a number of different ways; they're often broken up into many interconnected pathways comprised of ledges, tunnels, platforms and pathways. There are secrets around every corner, and a number of unique collectables always keep you peeking around each corner. One of the best things about DOOM is its rewarding of exploration. Whether you find some extra ammo, a new gun, or a Doomguy figurine, finding those secrets is extremely rewarding. The game praises you for taking time to explore your surroundings.   The Soundtrack:  Ho-ly ♥♥♥♥. The composer of the score (who also did the scores for Wolfenstein and numerous other projects) absolutely nails the soundtrack. Go look up 'BFG Division' on YouTube. Seriously - a picture, or in this case a song, speaks a thousand words.   To summarise, if you're interested in one of the most metal single-player FPS experiences to date, absolutely pick up this game. For Doomguys old and new, DOOM is the Doom we've been waiting for. Singleplayer: + Rewarding gameplay + Challenging but not too frustrating + Plenty of secrets to find + Focused storyline - Can become repetitive (arena, find a key, next arena, rinse and repeat) - Rather short  Multiplayer: + They are at least trying - Confusing layout - Too COD-ish - Very limited text chat General: + Atmosphere is spectacularly DOOM + Graphics are amazing, but can still run on modest machines + General badassery  I bought this game for $20 on the sale, and that is in honesty what it is worth. The singleplayer is fantastic, even if a bit short for my taste, and there is some replay value with the arcade. Don't expect anything from the multiplayer though. If you're someone who loves doom, you will enjoy the campaign. If you're looking for a great multiplayer experience, here is not the place to find it. The reason I'm giving the game a recommendation is simply because the campaign is too much fun to give it a negative rating.
